India, for the G-77/CHINA, suggested that the term of the TEC be extended by a year.
The EU asked for clarification on what the “evaluation” function of the proposed permanent forum would entail.
MARSHALL ISLANDS urged parties to identify mitigation potential and specific implementation barriers, instead of simply outlining existing mitigation efforts.
The US presented a proposal by Australia, Canada, Japan, New Zealand and the US on clustering around: guiding concepts; contributions/commitments/actions; institutions; and transparency and reporting processes.
The REPUBLIC OF KOREA said that since most AIJ projects are financed through official funds like ODA and the GEF, credit certification should be treated carefully.
The US, Pakistan and Kazakhstan supported the proposal made by Turkey and this issue was deferred to SB-14.
SAUDI ARABIA, supported by KUWAIT, IRAN and OMAN, expressed surprise at the GEF’s decision to stop financial support for national communications for some non-Annex I countries, particularly the oil producing ones, stressing the need to resolve the issue at this session.
The US said the private sector should become the main source of funding and the EU underlined the role of the carbon market, innovative financing, and leveraging private investments.
The EU stressed that SB-16 should agree on future work and encouraged delegates to agree on definitions.
SAMOA requested clarification on how to indicate demonstrable progress by 2005 if the Protocol has not already entered into force by that time.
Saint Lucia, for AOSIS, expressed hope for progress on the CER registry’s transparency, double counting, and CDM loan schemes.
Referring to the SBSTA-17 conclusions containing a provision on this matter, Co-Chair Sue Barrell asked the G-77/CHINA whether it was necessary to include a request to the SBI to examine additional GEF guidance on this issue in the conclusions.
 PERU felt that the basic aspects being discussed regarding inputs are: priority criterion; a "middle of the road" stance as to whether analysis and assessments should occur simultaneously with negotiations; information on the economic impacts for developing countries of Annex I Parties adopting emissions reductions, and the definition of the Parties\' positions with regard to contributions.
On actions necessary to meet needs and concerns of developing countries, the US and the EU proposed following the language of FCCC Article 4.8.
The UK referred to a Chair and Chair-elect, and clarified that the term limit should not apply retroactively, given that the IPCC is now in the middle of an assessment cycle.
SAMOA expressed concerns over developing an overly-complex institutional structure for the future technology framework.
BOLIVIA and NICARAGUA underscored the importance of rights and participation of local populations.
BULGARIA said her country has enacted legislation on mitigation, renewable energy and energy efficiency.
The US also supported a time frame for reviewing and updating commitments.
Two \t\tadditional paragraphs proposed by the EU also caused some disagreement.
On 28 November, SBSTA addressed this issue, pursuant to Decision 1/CP.16 to establish a Technology Mechanism comprising a Technology Executive Committee (TEC) and a Climate Technology Centre and Network (CTCN), and decided to establish a contact group chaired by Carlos Fuller (Belize) and Zitouni Ould-Dada (UK).
VANUATU, on behalf of the LDCs, urged explicit reference to the group 92s submissions in the revised text as a separate section, to ensure that it provides for the needs of the LDCs.
AILAC suggested, and parties agreed, that the co-facilitators identify the commonalities among the proposals and synthesize them.
Sweden, for the EU, highlighted the importance of: increased ambition on mid-term reductions; inclusion of emissions from the international aviation and maritime transport sectors; fast-track and long-term financing that includes the private sector and carbon market; and action on a performance-based mechanism for REDD.
 FRANCE: Pierre Chemillier spoke on behalf of Corinne Lepage, Minister of the Environment, calling it a duty to adopt the precautionary principle.
Uganda, for the LDCs, proposed convening a short plenary to review progress on Wednesday.
The EU proposed objectives relating to: information exchange and experience; facilitating cooperation between Parties; and facilitating assessment of demonstrable progress.
The UMBRELLA GROUP and the G-77/CHINA preferred setting an \t\tearlier time, whereas the EU preferred a more 93flexible 94 arrangement \t\tthat would allow for later meetings.
The EU asked for comments on the remainder of the text.
The Gambia, for LDCs, welcomed conclusions related to the Adaptation Fund.
The EU said it wanted to see more coherence between the accounting elements in Articles 6.2 and 6.4.
Algeria, for the AFRICAN GROUP, the PHILIPPINES, ARGENTINA, NICARAGUA and other developing countries called for establishing a spin-off group on adaptation, noting the need to further consider national adaptation plans for developing countries that are not LDCs.
The PHILIPPINES, with the US, supported investigating connections between climate change and extreme weather events, while NIGERIA stressed the need for preparedness to cope with such events in developing countries.
  Bolivia, for the G-77/China, Ecuador, for the LMDCs, Saudi Arabia, for the Arab Group, and Sudan, for the African Group, expressed dissatisfaction with the new iteration of the Co-Chairs e2 80 99 draft text on INDCs, lamenting that it fails to reflect the views of all parties.
SWEDEN supported considering the suggestions by Iran and Zimbabwe and involving developing countries in research and development efforts.
On adaptation and mitigation options and responses, the US, supported by New Zealand, Germany, the Netherlands and Saudi Arabia, suggested that authors should consider the same factors for both adaptation and mitigation.
The US, while retaining the "no appeal" option, said any appeal body should be limited to overriding decisions.
The US said multiple ways to achieve robust accounting are recognized in the Durban decisions.
ARGENTINA said no aspect of the FCCC and the Protocol limited its ability to raise the issue of voluntary commitments.
KUWAIT opposed sectoral approaches reflected in the proposals on sectoral crediting and trading.
AOSIS identified four basic functions and the institutional arrangements to carry them out.
SAUDI ARABIA highlighted the need for transparency and expressed concerns over statements by the UNFCCC Executive Secretary regarding biofuels and transport.
NEW ZEALAND expressed a readiness \t\tto take on new quantitative emissions reductions and also identified the \t\tneed to consider new types of commitments.
The \t\tNetherlands and the US called for broad participation in the expert \t\tmeeting.
The RUSSIAN FEDERATION proposed inclusion of systems for the measurement of GHGs and other atmospheric components, reference to satellite systems for data collection, and distinction between anthropogenic and natural climate change variations.
 The MARSHALL ISLANDS, NORWAY, MICRONESIA and INDIA favored deferring consideration of this issue and requesting Parties to submit comments.
NORWAY inserted a paragraph on prioritizing results-based payments for verifiable emission reductions.
JAPAN then reported on work of the Climate Technology Initiative (CTI) to strengthen National Action Plans, increase use of existing climate friendly technology and improve new technology.
NORWAY highlighted its proposal to auction emission allowances to fund adaptation.
Chair Gamede identified the two outstanding LDC issues: guidance to the LDC Fund; and status of implementation of UNFCCC Article 4.9 (LDCs).
Stressing the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities, CHINA said the climate regime should take into account the rising energy demands that will occur as the quality of life in developing countries improves.
On annual inventories of national greenhouse gas data from Annex I Parties, the EU called for a single document containing all available data from Annex I Parties and urged Parties that had not done so to submit their inventories.
On the global stocktake, the AFRICAN GROUP stressed the need to operationalize equity.
G77/CHINA urged the deletion of the entire section.
In the afternoon, delegates considered a proposal by AOSIS on an international mechanism to address loss and damage.
INDIA, for the G-77/CHINA, preferred using the Chair 92s text.
The G-77/CHINA, supported by MALAYSIA, the MARSHALL ISLANDS, MICRONESIA, IRAN, INDIA, the PHILIPPINES, VENEZUELA, NIGERIA, BRAZIL, INDONESIA and THAILAND, emphasized that all sections of Article 4.1 must be considered equally and in an integrated manner.
With the US, he said IPCC should evaluate the consequences of limiting activities that can be included.
EGYPT and others noted \t\tthe need to involve developing countries.
SOUTH AFRICA called for further discussion on: phasing out fossil fuel subsidies; supporting technology transfer; encouraging local innovation; and involving women and youth.
BRAZIL suggested the agreement establish a process for the stocktaking, with inputs deriving from existing processes under the Convention, such as the review of the adequacy of finance; and output timed at least one year before parties submit revised NDCs.
\t\tNorway, the EU and the G-77/China noted that consideration of ocean \t\tstorage is premature.
NORWAY said it would be premature to draw conclusions from the pilot phase and proposed the establishment of an AIJ forum at SBSTA’s December 1996 meeting.
Stressing that adaptation is of greater concern to Central American countries than mitigation, HONDURAS noted its concern about the amount of funding budgeted for CDM activities.
 The US proposed, in light of Germany\'s efforts in organizing the Conference and the leadership of the President, that the Conference should designate this decision as \'The Berlin Mandate.\'
 PERU has completed its inventory with assistance from the US, but it will be difficult to continue commitments under Article 4.1 without financial and technical assistance from Annex I Parties.
 An afternoon contact group, chaired by Stephen Cornelius (UK) and Robert Bamfo (Ghana), focused on consideration of the need for further guidance on safeguards.
JAPAN suggested standard operational procedures for AIJ projects, monitoring and revision and supported the workshop on methodologies.
CHILE, the LDCs, TURKEY and PALAU called for anchoring the GCF in the 2015 agreement.
JAPAN called for legal clarification of the terms “developed country parties” and “developing country parties” in the Bali Action Plan.
The EU also requested more budget information about the \t\t\tITL, and Switzerland said resource issues would need to be \t\t\tconsidered.
Chile, for AILAC, called for a collective commitment towards low-carbon growth.
SWITZERLAND and the US expressed their preference for suspending rather than closing the APA session.
VENEZUELA, for Bolivia, Cuba and Paraguay, expressed concerns with offsetting.
The US stressed the need to work on budgetary issues to ensure that its contributions are used to support the UNFCCC process.
She proposed replacing “the need for a channel” with “the existence of a channel” and also suggested, supported by TURKEY and others, replacing reference to non-Annex I parties with reference to parties, highlighting that all parties, not just non-Annex I parties, could suffer from impacts and consequences of response measures.
BAHRAIN and others highlighted time constraints in reaching an agreement.
NEW ZEALAND expressed optimism on the agriculture work programme on mitigation and adaptation.
INDIA warned that discount factors are arbitrary.
MEXICO, with KUWAIT, underlined uncertainty over the nature of NAMAs.
HONDURAS, SURINAME, COLOMBIA, BRAZIL, TUVALU, GUATEMALA, the DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE CONGO, GUYANA and PAKISTAN supported the proposal.
PARAGUAY said technology transfers should not in any way be discriminatory, and should not exclude local technologies.
On the facilitative nature, the US drew attention to her proposal for a multilateral consultative process.
This was supported by the Russian Federation, the EU and Australia.
Emphasizing inclusive, transparent and democratic negotiations, BOLIVIA observed that the preparatory work for COP 16 and COP/MOP 6 should respect the separate negotiating tracks, mandates and outcomes of the AWG- LCA and AWG-KP.
The EU expressed regret with the African Group’s proposal, highlighting that it is not realistic for one contact group to work faster than another.
AUSTRALIA highlighted the need for an appropriate enabling environment for capacity building.
SAINT LUCIA said that progress is measured to know: “what the atmosphere sees,” and what individual countries are doing.
CHINA called for reflecting the linkages between the collective aspects of mitigation, adaptation and MOI.
The G-77/CHINA, supported by SAUDI ARABIA, stressed that P&amp;Ms should not have adverse impacts on developing country Parties.
SWITZERLAND suggested a global carbon dioxide levy of US$2 per tonne on all fossil fuel emissions, with an exception for less developed countries.
The EU said the AIJ experience gained since COP-1 can provide valuable guidance on questions of flexibility mechanisms in the Protocol.
The AFRICAN GROUP identified intellectual property rights as a major barrier and said adaptation does not attract private sector investment.
AOSIS said that Parties should not distract from Protocol implementation, noting the CDM will assist sustainable growth with climate protection.
BARBADOS said increasing participation through increased pledges is vital, stressing that the issue is not about a participation gap but an ambition gap.
BRAZIL inquired about the French and Moroccan Presidencies’ and co-chairs’ ideas about how agenda item 8 could be addressed.
Egypt, for the Arab Group, called on all Annex I parties to work towards the same goal.
On adaptation communications, the EIG, Maldives, for AOSIS, the LDCs, South Africa, for the AFRICAN GROUP, and BRAZIL, also for ARGENTINA and URUGUAY, supported a call for focused submissions.
ICELAND said single projects, such as a large industrial plant, have a greater proportional impact on emissions in smaller countries, affecting their ability to meet emissions targets.
Guyana, for GRULAC, congratulated the Chairs and Rapporteur of the ADP on their election, adding that they were “pleased” to be part of the leadership of the ADP, and offered the support and cooperation of GRULAC.
Guidance to an operating entity of the financial mechanism on the LDC Fund remained the outstanding issue in consultations towards the end of the first week.
AOSIS expressed concern that a poor message will be sent if exemptions are listed when the Protocol is adopted.
 \t\tThe EU identified a strong degree of consensus on certain building \t\tblocks, including the need for deeper absolute emission reduction \t\tcommitments for developed countries; measurable and incentivized action \t\tby developing countries; adaptation; technology and enhancing the carbon \t\tmarket.
The G-77/CHINA said the Durban Platform: must ensure strong linkages between mitigation, adaptation and means of implementation; and include the principles of equity and CBDR.
The EU stressed sending a signal to the private sector on the need to e2 80 9cshift the trillions e2 80 9d to low-carbon, climate-resilient development.
JAPAN proposed the annual submission of inventories using the 2006 IPCC Guidelines and enhancing the reporting frequency to every two years, with full national communications to be submitted with longer intervals.
The US, with the Russian Federation, addressed the issue of late payment of dues, seeking information on existing practices in other UN forums.
JORDAN objected to references to market mechanisms.
 The US said that he had amendments that he had held in abeyance, but in view of the amendments made by the G-77 and China and AOSIS, he felt compelled to submit and distribute these amendments at this stage.
The EC said a similar approach was used within the EU, where a common model is applied to data from Member States, in addition to projections at the national level.
Regarding draft conclusions on assessing the status of implementation of Article 4.9 (LDCs), TANZANIA, for the LDCs, objected to reference that the SBI expressed satisfaction at the progress achieved so far in implementing the LDC work programme.
INDIA, CHINA and BRAZIL recommended inclusion of a clear definition on assigned amounts, and, opposed by the US, suggested deleting the existing reference to assigned amount units.
On nuclear energy in the CDM, GREECE and TUVALU opposed inclusion.
MALI highlighted that “international consultation and analysis” implies a sequence of how the process should be carried out.
BRAZIL said the agreement should enhance current obligations while finding e2 80 9ccreative ways to indicate that there will be actions from everyone.
On their proposal, Spain, for the EU, highlighted, inter alia: enhanced reporting of capacity building best practices through national communications in order to enable monitoring and evaluation of the implementation of the capacity building framework; and the indicative list of items to consider for further implementation of decision 2/CP.7 (capacity building in developing countries).
On transparency, Co-Facilitator Andrew Rakestraw (US) informed that discussions had focused on the “preliminary materials document” prepared by the co-facilitators.
The US noted that the 2020 finance goal was made in the context of meaningful mitigation action for 2020, questioning whether those parties calling for mid-term finance commitments would also take on mid-term mitigation commitments.
A contact group co-chaired by Fadhel Lari (Kuwait) and Robert Mason (UK) will consider this item and prepare draft conclusions.
On the draft conclusions on cooperation with relevant international organizations, (FCCC/SBSTA/1999/L.7), the EU and ANTIGUA AND BARBUDA inquired about the joint project on capacity building between the UN agencies and the Secretariat, noting that Parties were not aware of the details.
Bart Stoffer, US, presented on \t\t\tinvestments in low and zero emissions technology.

The DOMINICAN REPUBLIC emphasized gender-sensitive and community-based adaptation.

 JAPAN said provisions must incorporate measures that lead to technology transfer, AIJ and review mechanisms.
JAPAN highlighted the importance of examining other multilateral environmental agreements.

On accounting, AUSTRALIA supported a common accounting framework for all parties.
Honduras, for SICA, expressed deep concern over delays concerning the second commitment period under the Protocol, stressing the need for urgent progress.
\t\tSudan, on behalf of the AFRICA GROUP, cautioned that a sectoral approach \t\tmay marginalize local knowledge and called for a thematic and \t\tlivelihoods approach.
NORWAY supported a science-driven approach, and called for emissions to peak in 2015 at the latest and global reductions of 85% by 2050.
The EU suggested paragraph 86 on clarity on scaling up of resources be put under scalable resources.
On the issue of Eligibility, TUVALU and PERU said activities under Article 3.3 subsequent to 1990 should not be eligible.
On   the EU highlighted developments since Bangkok.
The UK and Luxembourg suggested a longer timeline for responses to the questionnaire.
The Democratic Republic of the Congo, for the AFRICAN GROUP, described finance, technology transfer and capacity building as issues on which “Africa expects the SBI to take decisive action” and called for the adoption of terms of reference for the review of the Adaptation Fund and for parties to respect a previous decision on the scope of the review.
It also requests the Secretariat \t\tto organize, before COP-13, three regional workshops, reflecting \t\tregional priorities, and one expert meeting for SIDS, reflecting issues \t\tof priority identified by that group.
The US agreed, stressing that the IPCC is composed of volunteers and noting the importance of not excluding people who could make a valuable contribution while addressing the issue of bias and creating transparency.
c2 a0 Chile, for AILAC, identified three areas in Section C (general/objective) for merging and/or shortening.
KENYA reported on the Cartagena Dialogue on Progressive Action on Climate Change, which took place in Nairobi, Kenya, in April 2012, and addressed, inter alia, the Durban Platform, second commitment period under the Protocol and a new legally-binding instrument.
NEW ZEALAND, the EU and ICELAND said QELROs are subject to negotiation rather than to a decision on methods to calculate them.
JAPAN called for a unified approach to be discussed by the IPCC.
Grenada, for AOSIS, called for: reaching agreement on a five-year second commitment period with 1990 as the single, legally-binding base year; agreeing on LULUCF accounting rules; identifying feasible ways to address surplus assigned amount units (AAUs); agreeing on a transparent process to transform mitigation pledges into quantified emission limitation and reduction objectives (QELROs); and increasing the aggregate level of ambition.
Supported by the EU, New Zealand and others, Uruguay proposed that the SBSTA consider the agriculture sector in 2010.
MOROCCO, on behalf of the African group, reported the following nominees: Mr. Soobaraj Nayroo Sok Appadu (Mauritius) as the Vice-chair of SBSTA and Mr. Alvaro Jose Rodriguez (Colombia) as Rapporteur.
 Brazil, for the G-77/CHINA, said any future reporting framework must reflect differing national circumstances, taking into account the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities, and that enhanced reporting requirements would necessitate increased funding.
The US, with CANADA, proposed moving the cluster on plans and strategies after the cluster on definition and scope of NAMAs, with CANADA clarifying that plans and strategies provide framing for NAMAs.
The US noted the possibility of having a further report at SB 32 on the implementation of the programme, including on technology needs assessments and pilot projects.
AOSIS \t\tcalled for a specific programme for SIDS, consistent with the Mauritius \t\tStrategy.
He stressed the \t\tsignificance of the AWG as part of a larger process both inside and \t\toutside the UNFCCC, noting that the AWG by itself does not have the \t\tmandate to open or encourage contributions from non-Annex I parties or \t\tProtocol non-signatories such as the US.
  Co-Facilitator Andrew Rakestraw (US) reported on informal informal consultations, highlighting, inter alia, general support for: addressing all elements of Paris Agreement Article 13 as well as Decision 1/CP.21 on the enhanced transparency framework; not prejudicing the final outcomes on MPGs; and progressing work through submissions, technical papers and workshops.
AOSIS said a common understanding of terminology in the text should be reached.
The EU and NEW ZEALAND said Protocol development activities should remain in the core budget.
The EU identified the need to consider what stands the test of time and what needs to be amended on a regular basis.
The US underlined that “much good work” has been accomplished under the AWG-LCA and clarified their interpretation of the Doha outcome.
However, CANADA, NORWAY and the EU preferred wording that \t\tdoes not refer to specific organizations.
However, AUSTRALIA required further time before making a decision.

AOSIS said capacity building is a dynamic and iterative process that will be augmented by experiences from implementing other aspects of the FCCC.
The US asked whether it was intended to leave out "the latest developments in science, to the extent possible, and assess the implications thereof."
After consultations, the G-77/CHINA proposed that: the Co-Chairs produce an updated, clean and streamlined text; clear options and bridging proposals be kept in a separate document; spin-off groups be used when necessary; and the contact group agree on the text for consideration by the COP.
Biot concluded that the UK found that portfolio risk screening, though useful, is an insufficient guide for adaptation planning, assisting at the operations level, or assisting partner countries.
The EU underlined that the commitment to act applies to all parties, building on existing commitments, and could include integration of adaptation into national development planning.
Tuvalu, for the LDCs, proposed a compliance mechanism with an enforcement branch dealing with countries with economy-wide targets, and a facilitative branch to assist developing countries.
BRAZIL, INDONESIA, TOGO and INDIA, opposed by SAUDI ARABIA, supported holding consultations on this issue.
The US called for consistency in language used to state that the Secretariat would undertake work requested in light of the budget.
On the special circumstances of Croatia under UNFCCC Article 4.6 (special circumstances of economies in transition), Jim Penman (UK) reported on informal consultations.
 \t\tBangladesh, for LDCs, emphasized \t\tadaptation, CDM, micro-finance and compensation for those impacted by \t\tclimate change.
The EU stressed that Annex B parties represent only 30% of global emissions.
The G-77/CHINA, supported by THAILAND and SAUDI ARABIA, \t\topposed text in the EU 92s proposal, which calls on non-Annex I Parties to \t\tsubmit project proposals not later than one year after submission of \t\ttheir previous communication.

 \t\tOn the question of action encouraged by the COP, parties agreed to an \t\tannex with indicative guidance, as proposed by the EU and modified by \t\tthe US and others, and to 93demonstration activities 94 instead of a pilot \t\tphase, as preferred by Brazil.
ZIMBABWE proposed specifying the voluntary nature of AIJ, and CHINA proposed making specific reference to reports from Parties “participating in the pilot phase of AIJ.” The conclusions, as amended, were adopted.
The G-77/CHINA presented consolidated language on scope.
SAUDI ARABIA supported establishing a new system for MRV rather than using the current national communications system.
AOSIS called for simplified procedures for small island developing states (SIDS) to access resources to implement climate actions.
The US said addressing adaptation could involve: identifying a portfolio of areas of adaptation; identifying actions and actors; and funding from different sources, appropriate to actions and actors, at the local, national and international levels.
NEW ZEALAND said that even in the absence of a second commitment period, developed country mitigation actions and demand for carbon credits would continue, as national emissions trading systems would need access to Certified Emission Reductions (CERs) from the CDM.
On special circumstances of Croatia under Convention Article 4.6 (flexibility for EITs) Co-Chair Jim Penman (UK) introduced draft conclusions, noting that the contact group had considered methodological issues.
In the end, key issues in the UK proposal were incorporated under the existing topics.
The EU highlighted 25-40% emission reductions by Annex I countries through a combination of domestic and international measures, while BRAZIL stressed that reductions using the mechanisms be additional to these Annex I reductions.
Australia, for the UMBRELLA GROUP, supported a limit of 2°C on global temperature rise and a 50% reduction in global emissions by 2050.
POLAND said accommodation was available and a logistics team had been established to assist.
She said SIDS require specific consideration in the funding of NAMA preparation.
BRAZIL supported the idea of preserving the integrity of the elements text.
On Thursday, 5 June, the EU suggested that the budget be more predictable and sustainable for future periods, and expressed surprise over the distinction between Protocol and UNFCCC activities in the budget.
Other countries, including AUSTRALIA, SWITZERLAND, NORWAY, the US and JAPAN, said the shared vision should be based on the two issues mandated from Cancun, i.e., the long-term global goal and the peak year.
NEW ZEALAND emphasized that the starting point with the greatest environmental benefit is from actual emissions.
The G-77/CHINA agreed to consult on whether streamlining could take place and report to the Co-Chairs later in the evening.
This was supported by the RUSSIAN FEDERATION, EU, JAPAN, and AUSTRALIA.
Costa Rica, for AILAC, noted the historic adoption of the UNFCCC’s first gender action plan, emphasizing that gender issues in the Global South are a “matter of life and death.”
The EU, supported by the REPUBLIC OF KOREA, outlined a sequence in the mitigation cycle: a strategic review of implementation in the context of science; communication and commitments, involving the submission of NDCs; an ex ante process to gain an aggregate sense of NDCs in relation to the temperature goal; and the formalization of NDCs.
AOSIS highlighted the need for environmental integrity of emissions trading systems, and sought elaboration on the idea of a compliance reserve.
Australia, for the UMBRELLA GROUP, called for more time for item 5.
GRENADA did not understand how conservation of forests improves the uptake of a sink.
On cooperation with other conventions, Chair Thorgeirsson noted that Clare Breidenich (US) and Yvette Aguilar (El Salvador) had convened informal consultations.
The EU differentiated between sectoral approaches in the context of technology and policy cooperation and those that utilize carbon markets, such as emissions trading, on a sectoral basis.
 \t\tExpressing \t\tdisappointment at the lack of a more substantive outcome, the \t\tG-77/CHINA, opposed by the EU, proposed an alternative text noting that \t\tthe group had ef bf bdfailed to reach conclusions.
SWITZERLAND proposed including a reference to Decision 8/CP.4 (Preparations for the COP serving as the MOP) so that Parties prepare their submissions bearing it in mind and asked whether the co-chairs intended to prepare a more "legally oriented" text based on the synthesis.
AOSIS said that the new market-based mechanism should focus on sectors where substantial emission reductions are needed, such as industry, energy and transport, and emphasized the need to open opportunities for developing country participation.
Tuvalu, for the LDCs, proposed differentiated reporting for countries with economy-wide emission reduction targets and developing countries, emphasizing means of support.

GABON supported a general policy debate to clearly define principles.
Australia, supported by Japan, the US, New Zealand, Canada and the EU, noted convergence on information exchange and encouraged accomplishing this through existing mechanisms such as national communications.
The EU preferred "a compliance system for the Kyoto Protocol" in order to reflect a comprehensive approach to addressing compliance.
CHINA and SAUDI ARABIA expressed concern that a facilitative dialogue could represent an ex ante review and opposed this.
Bahamas, for the G-77/China, called for additional support for the Fund.
CUBA, on behalf of several countries, expressed concern with respect to unilateral measures in relation to aviation emissions, such as under the EU Emissions Trading Scheme.
 SPAIN, on behalf of the EU, said that it would be very difficult to cover the wide range of technical and scientific issues with only 15 experts.
The EU noted the private sector’s role in financing adaptation, and supported market approaches and a combination of options.
The EU, CANADA and MICRONESIA noted the usefulness of the compilation and synthesis report in better understanding the difficulties faced by non-Annex I Parties.
CHINA, opposed by the US, CANADA, JAPAN, RUSSIAN FEDERATION and EU, suggested deleting text in the annex that calls on experts to disclose potential conflicts of interest, noting that this would create an additional burden on expert reviewers.
Nauru, for AOSIS, said next week’s discussions should focus on, inter alia: the outcome of Doha; the 2013 workplan; and closing the ambition gap in 2013.
On the draft conclusions on LULUCF (FCCC/SBSTA/1999/L.9), ANTIGUA AND BARBUDA questioned a sentence he said could be interpreted as signaling that substantive decision-making on LULUCF will take place at SBSTA-11.
In response, the UK and CANADA noted their liberalization of energy markets and renewable energy measures.
The US, supported by CANADA, noted that the IMO and ICAO are specialized independent agencies with their own guiding principles, which limits the application of the Convention’s principles.
BRAZIL opposed linking Article 6 to Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation (REDD+), while PANAMA and BELIZE supported such a link.
On the Co-Chairs 92 text, the EU suggested removing the section on Protocol Article 3.14, and integrating it into the sections on adverse effects and the impact of response measures.
On vulnerability and ability to respond to the impact of potential consequences, the EU, ARGENTINA and the GAMBIA questioned the inclusion of textual proposals, which they said had only been proposed by one party and not agreed upon in the drafting group.
The PHILIPPINES said national adaptation plans should be expanded to other vulnerable developing countries.
The G-77/CHINA said it had highlighted the need for another workshop prior to COP-6.
NICARAGUA said the WIM should be implemented solely “in virtue of” the Convention.
Saint Lucia, for AOSIS, supported by PAPUA NEW GUINEA, called for an AWG-KP output that adopts ratifiable amendments to the Kyoto Protocol and its Annex B that will be provisionally applied.
Spain, for the EU, expressed support for treating mitigation and adaptation equally and for fast-start funding focusing on particularly vulnerable countries, and emphasized that the issue of response measures should be dealt with under mitigation.
The EU, US and CANADA highlighted progress made, including the GEF 92s third replenishment, the establishment of the LDC Fund, and development of guidelines for NAPAs.
Grenada, for the Alliance of Small Island States (AOSIS), expressed “great concern” that current emission reduction pledges would lead to a temperature increase of 4°C and that six months after COP 15, financing for adaptation is yet to materialize.
The EU, AUSTRALIA, NORWAY and JAPAN supported the continued use of GWPs, and NORWAY proposed that the IPCC provide additional information on other metrics.
CHINA proposed communicating the \t\tconclusions to the Expert Group on Technology Transfer (EGTT).
AOSIS supported a facilitative mechanism beyond a clearing house that helps developing national adaptation plans, tracks funds from developed countries, and assists with matching them.
SAUDI ARABIA said maritime and aviation emission levies would negatively impact developing country economic sectors.
SAUDI ARABIA reiterated that adaptation includes adaptation to response measures, and highlighted CCS as an adaptation technology.
On the COP/ MOP rules, NORWAY and the US emphasized that institutional responsibilities be part of the COP-6 decision.
SWITZERLAND, stressing his support for full transparency, proposed that all materials, including parties’ presentations, should be published by the Secretariat in a “dedicated space” on their website.
JAPAN highlighted his country’s views on various approaches, including opportunities for using markets.
JAPAN highlighted the need for clarity on how to define parties’ absolute emission reduction targets, and with AUSTRALIA and NEW ZEALAND, called for coherence with the AWG-LCA.
Mexico, for the EIG, underscored the Dialogue’s message of working as a community.
Chair Stoycheva agreed to suspend the adoption of the agenda to allow the G-77/China to consider the US proposal.
GERMANY and others expressed a preference for the IPCC \t\tto undertake emission scenario development, but a willingness to \t\tcompromise on the IPCC 92s 93coordinating and facilitating 94 emission \t\tscenario development.
TUVALU, supported by SAUDI ARABIA, COLOMBIA and others, suggested adding a new paragraph, after clarifying that the ADP has finished its mandate, which decides to establish the APO.
94 The US noted problems with defining climate policies, and whether these include other non-climate environmental policies that also reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
The US, with AUSTRALIA and Bangladesh, for the G-77/CHINA, highlighted the need for an interim conference venue while awaiting the completion of the permanent conference facilities.
SWITZERLAND said that the carry-over issue should be approached from a comprehensive perspective and that the alternative to the CDM is “the Wild West” of disparate carbon markets.
Saudi Arabia, supported by Oman and the EU, and opposed by Canada, requested the exclusion of a Canadian proposal on modalities for the accounting of assigned amounts in relation to cleaner energy exports.
Saying that they are a group of e2 80 9cbridge building engineers, e2 80 9d Costa Rica, for AILAC, urged all parties to redouble their efforts to find more points of convergence, calling for a mode of work that leads to tangible results in Lima.
SAUDI ARABIA opposed the separate \t\t\tconsideration of these issues.
Australia, for the UMBRELLA GROUP, noted the \t\temphasis at the recent Seminar of Governmental Experts on mobilizing \t\tprivate sector resources and support for an enabling environment.
 SAUDI ARABIA stated that an endorsement from the SBI would require line-by-line consideration and noted that the operational strategy was not exactly aligned with the COP decision on programmes, priorities and guidelines.
MALI, on behalf of the LDCs, highlighted the need for terms of reference for the expert group, and said his group is currently formulating proposals for a draft decision on this matter.
ETHIOPIA, supported by BRAZIL, suggested a technical workshop.
Welcoming the “historic agreement” as a landmark that will provide security and stability, the EU emphasized “we all have to translate this agreement to concrete actions.” Echoing that “today we can celebrate but tomorrow we have to act,” the EU noted the launch of the High-Ambition Coalition and underscored the EU “will scale up financial support as of 2020 and make it more predictable.”
With Canada, Japan and the EU, she emphasized that adaptation should be country-driven and that priority should be given to the most vulnerable.
It included four sub-items on: the fourth review of the financial mechanism (FCCC/SBI/2010/INF.7, FCCC/SBI/2009/MISC.10 and Add.1); the report of the GEF (FCCC/CP/2010/5 and Add.1, FCCC/CP/2009/9 and FCCC/SBI/2010/MISC.5); the assessment of the SCCF; and the LDC Fund (FCCC/CP/2010/5 and Add.1, FCCC/SBI/2010/5, FCCC/SBI/2010/15, 17, 26 and MISC.9, FCCC/SBI/2009/MISC.10 and Add.1).
KENYA, for the G-77/CHINA, said the geographic distribution of projects should be improved, particularly for Africa.
The  G-77/CHINA requested affirmation that the text should be seen as a consolidated list of paragraphs based on the negotiating text and underscored that financing and effective transfer of technology are the two key priority areas.
 SENEGAL said that the AGBM cannot continue to “mutter and stammer” when faced with such historic events.
The G-77/ CHINA supported an annual desk review and a periodic review in conjunction with national communications.
NIGERIA said the paragraph should remain as is because numerous delegations had specifically emphasized no new commitments for developing countries and CHINA said that some proposals had attempted to introduce commitments for developing countries.
CANADA said form should follow function.
NIUE emphasized the need for technological and financial assistance for adaptation.
The FEDERATED STATES OF MICRONESIA, supported by GUATEMALA, objected to SBSTA Chair Konaté’s proposal to close the agenda item.
On the section on Protocol Article 3.14, the US, with the EU and several other developed countries, noted that it dealt primarily with the impact of response measures, and suggested merging it with the previous section that directly addressed this issue.
The EU, Japan, Australia and the US supported use of global warming potentials (GWPs).
CHINA opposed major modifications for the second commitment period and stressed that provisions on LULUCF should apply only to Annex B countries.
The EU stressed that it is premature to decide whether the text will become a COP/MOP decision or conclusions, while South Africa, for the G-77/CHINA, hoped that they would achieve more than a conclusion.
 Argentina, for the G-77/CHINA, reaffirmed the need for a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol, calling for a higher level of ambition by Annex I parties.
 CHINA, the PHILIPPINES, IRAN, JAPAN, THAILAND, CHILE, the RUSSIAN FEDERATION, GAMBIA, KUWAIT and MOROCCO said it would be premature to make conclusions on areas of convergence because the process is still evolving and contributions have been preliminary.
The G-77/China identified some areas \t\t\twhere it might show some flexibility, while the US reiterated its \t\t\tpreference for zero nominal growth, but also expressed willingness \t\t\tto compromise.
The UK, with Germany and the US, called for recognition of historical contributions, including in-kind contributions to the Technical Support Units (TSUs).
The EU noted this is “the right place to discuss pre-2020 finance.” Bolivia, for the G-77/CHINA, requested a workshop on finance needs of developing countries, in particular for adaptation, in 2016.
BOLIVIA lamented that negotiations under the AWG-KP are behind schedule and urged parties to work towards an equitable and just outcome.
Delegates met in a formal meeting and heard a presentation by the G-77/CHINA on its views, contained in a new submission, on consequences under a compliance regime.
On Saturday, following contact group discussions, India and Norway proposed specifying that new and existing technologies and practices are technically proven “at various scales.”The UK suggested that their large-scale deployment “may be,” rather than “is,” limited by various constraints.
A \t\tcontact group co-chaired by Philip Gwage (Uganda) and David Warrilow \t\t(UK) met on Thursday, 9 December, to draft conclusions on this issue \t\tsince there was insufficient time for a decision at COP-10.
CHILE noted that Article 14 calls for settlement of disputes through negotiations or “any other peaceful means,” and that an MCP could fill the latter role.
The EU called for a review of the scope of current education programmes and the development of more specific reporting guidelines.
Switzerland, for the EIG, emphasized the need to leave Panama with clarity on the road ahead, and “a negotiating text in hand.”
Ethiopia, for the LDCs, called for the inclusion of capacity-building support for NDCs.
Colombia, for AILAC, the EU and the US supported early entry into force, and, with the LMDCs, emphasized it should not affect parties’ right to fully participate in the rulemaking process.
CHINA highlighted the need to clarify steps and elements of the readiness phase, including scaling-up fast-start finance for national strategies and action plans, as well as demonstration projects.
The Gambia, for the G-77/China, suggested requesting the Secretariat to compile and synthesize the outcomes and recommendations from the regional workshops held so far, together with the implementation of these outcomes and recommendations.
The Republic of Korea, for the EIG, stated that market and non-market approaches should be guided by principles of transparency, environmental integrity, and avoiding double counting, while considering the diversity of NDCs.
ADP Co-Chair Daniel Reifsnyder (US) stressed the urgency of beginning substantive negotiations.
IRAN commented that the workshop had focused too much on the recent oil price rise, noting that this is not a permanent phenomenon.
Switzerland, Russia, Norway, Japan, Poland, Canada and Australia supported or expanded on various aspects of the US position.
SWITZERLAND urged ex ante consideration of aggregate commitments.
Switzerland, for the Environmental Integrity Group (EIG), said Doha must set out a work plan up to 2015, including milestones.
The EU said the upcoming workshop should consider, inter alia, defining 93best practices 94 and assessing the extent to which international cooperation may enhance effectiveness of P&amp;Ms. AUSTRALIA preferred reference to 93good 94 rather than 93best 94 practices and, with JAPAN and the US, said P&amp;Ms should reflect national circumstances.
Numerous countries, including NEW ZEALAND, ECUADOR, the EU and the RUSSIAN FEDERATION, supported the document’s list of methodological issues that warrant special consideration.
The US added that progress had been made and he remained optimistic.
VENEZUELA, for the G-77/CHINA, said that the recent focus on the Protocol has meant that some UNFCCC issues have been neglected, particularly those relevant to developing countries.
AUSTRALIA expressed concern regarding the singling out of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) and invasive alien species (IAS), while NORWAY expressed preference for stronger text on excluding GMOs and IAS.
 Chair Thorgeirsson indicated that informal conclusions had been conducted by Richard Bradley (US), who then briefed Parties on these discussions, noting agreement on the value of a balanced information package and a process for recommending a draft decision at SB-17 for COP-8.
COLOMBIA urged parties not to debate process, noting that these discussions are being held elsewhere.
Bangladesh supported a multilateral CDM programme for LDCs.
 HUNGARY, Katalin Szili, Parliamentary State Secretary, Ministry for the Environment and Regional Development, described national plans to mitigate GHG, and agreed with the EU position on adoption of legally binding policies and measures.
CANADA, the EU, ZIMBABWE, ITALY, MOROCCO, the PHILIPPINES and CHILE called for equitable geographic representation.
BANGLADESH called for focusing on proposals that highlight the needs of LDCs and SIDS.
Grenada, for AOSIS, noted a number of important outcomes on: Convention Article 6; adaptation in the context of decision 1/CP.10; the Adaptation Fund and its review; and LDCs.
The UMBRELLA GROUP, the EIG and the EU proposed that parties: “unpack issues”; reorganize text; and explain their proposals.
The PHILIPPINES and the GAMBIA stressed focusing attention on new and effective adaptation technologies.
On the process to enable the LDCs to formulate and implement national adaptation plans, the EU proposed language stating the planning process should not be prescriptive and should facilitate country-driven action.
SWAZILAND noted the mandate of the Technology Mechanism from Cancun does not match with that suggested in paragraph 140.1.
The US, \t\twith SWITZERLAND and ARGENTINA, cautioned that outreach activities must \t\tnot become marketing mechanisms, as that would extend beyond the IPCC ef bf bds \t\trole.
On decision-making on the road to COP 17, the EU called for an elaboration of terms of reference for the CTC; The Chair observed the need for: a mechanism that both serves the UNFCCC’s policy needs and meets the operational requirements of developing countries; and further discussion on links with the UNFCCC.
An ALBA country strongly supported developing non-market based approaches focusing on the multiple functions and values of forests.
BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA shared results of sectoral mitigation scenarios, noting potential for a 17% reduction in total GHG emissions over 2010-2040 under the most ambitious scenario presented in its biennial update report (BUR).
Noting that heterogeneity of impacts among countries is unavoidable, the G-77/CHINA said the reference year of 1990 is already established.
GERMANY and the US recommended that “environmental” costs and benefits be considered and EGYPT said their role in enhancing carbon sinks should also be noted.
 The US said deleting paragraph 2 would mean the SBSTA has failed miserably in providing guidance.
The Gambia, for the LDCs, reiterated their commitment to a second commitment period and stressed that the flexibility mechanisms are an integral part of the Kyoto Protocol.
CHINA, supported by INDIA, suggested the "detection of anthropogenic climate change," needed to be put into a historical perspective.
The EU highlighted, inter alia: the multilateral assessment and facilitative sharing of views; review of the Technology Mechanism; an improved response measures forum; and the PCCB meeting.
The RUSSIAN FEDERATION reported that his country was in the process of considering further emission reductions and opposed the adoption of a collective range as this would pre-judge individual obligations.

Regarding the frequency of national communications, the US said capacity building is enhanced by more frequent national communications.

EGYPT, with PARAGUAY, emphasized that adequate and predictable finance should come mainly from public sources.

A number of EU countries are willing to commit themselves to reduce emissions.
SWITZERLAND said the Secretariat should record the difficulties cited by countries and called for revision of in-depth review projects.
On  , Saudi Arabia proposed that the provision exempting SIDS from payment of the registration fee and share of proceeds, as well as that establishing a quota for projects hosted in LDCs, SIDS and African countries, should be extended to all developing countries with fewer than ten registered projects.
With SWITZERLAND, the EU recognized that there is a link between the Montreal and Kyoto Protocols.
The REPUBLIC OF KOREA highlighted the role of incentives, stating that issuing carbon credits based on measurable, reportable and verifiable mitigation can encourage developing countries’ participation.
The EU, JAPAN and the US said the references to "Annex I Party" could be deleted since the articles falling into the scope of that branch only applied to Annex I Parties and since non-Annex I Parties were not submitted to host-country requirements under the CDM.
SWITZERLAND and SOUTH AFRICA inquired about how the placeholders on further work would be populated, including whether to reflect possible divergence in views.
Mali, for the AFRICAN GROUP, stressed, inter alia, the role of the Adaptation Fund in serving the Paris agreement, and, that pre-2020 ambition remains of “critical importance.”
CHINA urged the establishment of a procedure for the replenishment of the SCCF.
The G-77/CHINA said without practical technical know-how, technology transfer would be impossible.
CHINA said the review should not be an \t\topportunity to rewrite the Protocol.
NEW ZEALAND and AUSTRALIA called for further consideration of implications of provisional application of provisions.
PAPUA NEW GUINEA, supported by SOUTH AFRICA, opposed the introduction of new text by the Co-Chairs, stating that the text had already been gaveled during informal consultations last night.
Matthew Webb, UK, and \t\t\tLi Gao, China, presented on the new zero emissions coal initiative, \t\t\twhich includes the construction and operation of a CCS demonstration \t\t\tproject in China between 2010-2014.
The G-77/CHINA pointed to convergence on establishing a technology transfer mechanism and divergence on concepts.
The EIG advocated making climate action more gender-responsive.
The EU, JAPAN, NEW ZEALAND, AOSIS, NORWAY and others supported considering the development of standardized, multi-project baselines, with AOSIS noting the need to improve access to the CDM.
The US stressed the function of assessment over \t\tcoordination and discussed the importance of continued involvement from \t\tthe US climate modeling community.
Underscoring the importance of implementing Article 4.5, the G-77/ CHINA expressed concern over the failure of some Parties to implement their commitments, and stressed the need to make progress on the outstanding issues.
The US said the group is also mandated to clarify concepts.
TUVALU appealed for progress on the Montreal Action Plan, resources for adaptation and capacity building.
BOTSWANA emphasized the role of the CDM in assisting developing countries and urged progress on elaborating this mechanism.
MEXICO, supported by UGANDA, CHILE and BOLIVIA, also suggested text on human rights.
On process and possible outcomes of COP 23, the EU said it was not convinced that compilations of submissions or parties’ views is an efficient way to conduct the process.
The US identified the need to consider the spectrum of countries’ national circumstances and said the registry approach should be considered for both developed and developing countries, while BRAZIL said developed countries must take on commitments and stressed the need to consider comparability of efforts.
NEW ZEALAND said that the TAPs should be established as soon as possible, adding that geographic balance and experience must both be incorporated.
CHINA warned that the use of markets could lead to double counting in terms of fulfilling developed countries’ financial commitments and generating offsets.
On the COP 19 outcome, she called for: a process to review support from Annex I parties; clarity on the delivery of the US$100 billion of annual long-term finance; and options to strengthen the price of carbon.
INDONESIA called for a complete, coherent, and balanced outcome that is applicable to all but still is under the CBDR-RC principle, emphasizing the need for balance between action and support in the transparency framework.
Finland and Denmark pledged support to the LDC Fund.
On cooperation with relevant international organizations, the MARSHALL ISLANDS sought clarification from IPCC regarding how regional implications will be covered in the Third Assessment Report(TAR).
On Tuesday, 10 June, the EU and the US continued to disagree over the issue of indicative scales.
INDIA and others said the Convention reflects the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities appropriately.
The RUSSIAN FEDERATION said any proposal to eliminate or limit carryover is inconsistent with the Kyoto Protocol.

Expressing commitment to building more trust, South Africa, for the G-77/CHINA, wondered if the group’s views “still matter.” With the Maldives, for AOSIS, and Sudan, for the AFRICAN GROUP, she sought clarification on the way forward and called for resuming the stocktaking after the G-77/China had finished their coordination.
EGYPT preferred a uniform level of emissions.
JAPAN said discussions under the AWG-LCA need to be consistent with those under the AWG-KP.

The US stressed that capacity building should be results-based.
The G-77/China, opposed by the EU and Japan, supported including this item on the agenda.
 During the contact group, AUSTRALIA emphasized the role of the UNFCCC process in determining a method for prioritizing support to vulnerable countries based, inter alia, on physical impacts and adaptive capacity.
With the US and Canada, he suggested that the revised uniform reporting format be discussed at SBSTA-14.
CHINA said any discussion on the Protocol should consider the impacts of implementation, and SAUDI ARABIA called for a scientific assessment of these impacts.

CHINA cautioned against e2 80 9cboard-shifting behaviors e2 80 9d in reference to the potential role of the private sector in supporting capacity building.
CANADA said the public versus private sector funding debate was leading to a “false argument” by suggesting that one is more important than the other.
The US, Canada and Belgium expressed concern regarding duplication of TGICA’s functions, such as with the WMO’s Global Framework for Climate Services, and recommended also discussing this issue further.
Switzerland, on behalf of the ENVIRONMENTAL INTEGRITY GROUP (EIG), outlined three deliverables for Doha: concluding the AWG-KP, closing the AWG-LCA, and progressing on the two streams of the ADP.
The UK called attention to a Dutch/British study, coordinated by the World Bank, to provide adaptation practitioners with a guide on, inter alia, how to carry out cost-benefit analyses of adaptation measures.
The US expressed concern over the interdependence of chapters and called for some consolidation and Japan agreed that Chapters 2-5 were interrelated.
TUVALU underscored the need for more inclusive treatment of adaptation, called for separate treatment of sub-paragraphs 1(b)(i) (mitigation commitments and actions by developed countries) and 1(b)(ii) (NAMAs by developing countries) of the BAP, and cautioned against use of text from the Copenhagen Accord.
 SPAIN, on behalf of the EU, submitted an outline for a protocol or legal instrument.
AUSTRALIA favored a menu approach whereby a Party not complying with Article 3.1 could choose from a predetermined set of roughly equivalent consequences.
GUYANA, with COSTA RICA and SURINAME, said the decision to bring REDD to SBSTA was made by the COP and that no party subsequently has the right to remove it from the agenda.
 AUSTRALIA proposed: a collective reduction objective for “Annex A” Parties, which are those listed in Annex I of the FCCC; mitigation activities that result in equal percentage changes in per capita economic welfare among “Annex A” Parties; differentiated commitments; use of indicators in the negotiation process; and further consideration of market-based approaches such as emissions trading and joint implementation.
The Philippines, for the G-77/CHINA, underlined that sectoral approaches should not replace legally binding commitments for developed countries, and that transnational sectoral agreements are not acceptable for developing countries.
The EU, G-77/ CHINA and NEW ZEALAND introduced minor changes.
BRAZIL said eligible activities should continue to be limited to afforestation and deforestation.
 COSTA RICA, on behalf of the G-77/China, said delegates first need to resolve the internal regulations of a protocol.
He stressed that “well-planned cities are an \t\t\tefficient use of space and energy.” FRANCE presented on the \t\t\texperiences of the Lille area in waste management and inland \t\t\twaterway transport.
CANADA noted that his country 92s adaptation support prioritizes LDCs.
The EU acknowledged the possibility of setting a cap, but stressed that such a cap must not be too restrictive and must still provide an incentive for taking further action.
The EU, supported by NORWAY, proposed having an option stating that no decision should be taken on this issue.
The EU stressed the continued provision of climate finance after 2012 and work to scale up finance towards 2020.
SAUDI ARABIA said the issue was unfinished business from the BAPA and stressed preparation of a draft decision for COP/MOP-1.
AOSIS acknowledged the utility of discussing principles, but was ready to work on the basis of the Secretariat’s synthesis of submissions.
SWITZERLAND noted the need to address technicalities for a seamless 2012-2013 transition.
The EU, Australia, Japan, Canada, Czech Republic, Brazil, Switzerland, South Africa and Slovakia expressed favor for Alternative A, provided that a decision to adopt a protocol would be taken by a 3/4 majority.
GABON underscored issues of trust between developed and developing countries.
BOLIVIA called for limiting the temperature increase to 1°C and stabilization at as close to 300 ppm as possible.
The G-77/CHINA disagreed and proposed to submit new text.
The Dominican Republic, for the COALITION FOR RAINFOREST NATIONS, said closing the ambition gap requires a REDD+ mechanism in the future climate regime.
The NETHERLANDS and the INTERNATIONAL ENERGY AGENCY described the Climate Technology Institute, an initiative to support the FCCC in addressing technology transfer needs.
URUGUAY asked what mechanism would facilitate the review process.
Parties agreed to use an existing body, specifically the ADP under a new name, by “importing” its governance arrangements, particularly regarding the Bureau as proposed by Colombia, on behalf of the Independent Alliance of Latin America and the Caribbean (AILAC).
NORWAY, the US, JAPAN and SAINT LUCIA expressed their disappointment that the contact group was unable to agree to a decision on this item.
He described the institutional framework under the \t\t\tUNFCCC to support adaptation, including funds and Convention expert \t\t\tgroups, including the LDC Expert Group (LEG), the Consultative Group \t\t\tof Experts on non-Annex I national communications (CGE) and the \t\t\tExpert Group on Technology Transfer (EGTT).

Various LDC parties outlined areas where support is required, noting the need for strengthening national capacity to ensure integration of adaptation into national development.
ARGENTINA said historical contributions and current circumstances must be considered and called for short-term measures while advancing long-term goals.
SINGAPORE highlighted three aspects for raising ambition: deepening the range of actions, particularly ambition in the context of the Kyoto Protocol, and the range of pledges; broadening the range of actions, saying complementary initiatives are relevant but should strengthen the multilateral system and respect the different competencies of multilateral organizations; and broadening the range of actors.
AOSIS supported inclusion of additional gases to prevent the development of perverse incentives to increase emissions of these gases.
Belgium, for the EU, stressed that while the EU would prefer a single, legally-binding instrument including essential elements of the Protocol, it is flexible regarding the legal form, as long as it is binding.
 SWITZERLAND said that the BM clearly states that analysis and assessments should be conducted in parallel and not prior to the negotiations.
Parties then considered the guidance to an operating entity of the financial mechanism of the UNFCCC on the LDC Fund.
MALAYSIA suggested that borrowers should pay interest, which could be used to set up a fund to safeguard countries against the effects of climate change.
CANADA, the UK, the US and NEW ZEALAND called for regular reviews of the roster as well as inclusion of gender considerations in the identification of persons to recommend.
Emphasizing the need to allow time for group coordination, Bolivia, for the G-77/CHINA, suggested addressing sections of the text thematically and, supported by Jamaica, for AOSIS, beginning with streamlining the text on monitoring and evaluation.
The UK and UNSIDS pointed to the inaccuracy of models based on the assumption of a uniform carbon tax, as many countries plan to implement multiple policies and measures to reduce emissions.
INDIA, SAMOA and BRAZIL expressed concern at this new proposal.
The COP also elected members to the: Adaptation Committee; Adaptation Fund Board; Advisory Board to the CTCN; Consultative Group of Experts (CGE); Compliance Committee, both the facilitative and enforcement branches; Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) Executive Board; WIM Executive Committee (ExCom); Joint Implementation Supervisory Committee; Technology Executive Committee (TEC) and LDC Expert Group (LEG).
The EU and SWITZERLAND said their submissions on baselines for CDM applied to JI.

BRAZIL and MICRONESIA opposed CCS under the CDM, while QATAR highlighted the potential for CCS.
CANADA stressed the importance of enabling a country-driven approach, and identified areas of common interest, including: national actions to drive technology development and deployment; supportive policy and regulatory frameworks; private sector engagement; technology needs assessments (TNAs) as a primary tool; and regional innovation centers.
 Ecuador, for the Group of 77 and China (G-77/China), stressed: the importance of advancing, and maintaining a balance among, all elements of the Paris Agreement; the need to move to textual negotiations by COP 23; and NDCs as a key vehicle for delivering enhanced action under the Paris Agreement.
SUDAN stressed technology transfer irrespective of political relations or racial considerations.
SAUDI ARABIA, noting the number of substantive issues to be addressed, with QATAR, INDIA and CHINA, said that extra time would be “extremely useful.” AUSTRALIA proposed assessing the need for a second informal meeting after the first one.
On a request to continue discussions on, inter alia, increasing capacity-building and support for the involvement of observer organizations, MEXICO and SOUTH AFRICA suggested this should be considered particularly for developing countries observer organizations.

The NETHERLANDS and FRANCE said reliance on inventories alone was insufficient to evaluate the effectiveness of P&amp;Ms.
