 CANADA said the BM does not diminish the commitments of non-Annex I Parties.
The US proposed that Parties should be able to raise questions regarding another Party 92s implementation only with respect to the facilitative branch.
JAPAN urged prompt review of communication results and welcomed the informal workshop.
The US enquired about other possible vehicles for capturing progress.
TUVALU warned against heading towards a “mega-CDM” and highlighted that new market mechanisms will have consequences for targets of Annex I parties and for the atmosphere.
Commenting on the provisional agenda, Argentina, for the G-77/CHINA, warned against transferring unresolved issues from the AWG-LCA to the SBSTA, saying the AWG-LCA should maintain an overview of specific issues that were mandated for consideration by the SBSTA.
The EU said that its ministers had met in Brussels and agreed to a ministerial segment.
The EU, the US, SWITZERLAND and AUSTRALIA said the proposal requires broader discussion and expressed concern about, inter alia: the method for reconstructing historical emissions; indicators that ignore the rate of change; and the availability of data.
SAUDI ARABIA underscored that the discussions on developing country NAMAs also addressed financial support, capacity building and technology transfer as intrinsically related to ICA and the biennial update reports.
BOLIVIA noted, inter alia, her country’s textual proposals on a shared vision and indigenous peoples.
It also takes note on support provided through the LDC Fund and forwarded a decision to the COP.
Nauru, for AOSIS, said the framework should measure progress toward a global goal of 1.5 c2 b0 or 2 c2 b0C and promote participation of all countries.
The African Group, opposed by Colombia, the EU, Japan, Norway and the Federated States of Micronesia, proposed deletion of reference to the Chairs of the two AWGs meeting to identify issues of common concern regarding Annex I parties’ commitments.
NIGERIA added that nothing in the Buenos Aires Plan of Action (BAPA) required the JWG to finish its work by COP-6.
The US said that there should be no change in status until there is a determination by a competent body that non-compliance exists.
CANADA underlined its flexibility on this issue.
CHINA and INDIA proposed deleting clusters on national schedules and the sub-section on MRV.
The EU stressed that for Doha to deliver a balanced outcome, work in the ADP must result in a decision that captures agreed next steps and provides political momentum for adopting an agreement in 2015.
On Classification of Inventory Problems, the EU distributed a non-paper to help form the rationale for problem categorization.
MEXICO, BARBADOS and others underscored the unequal distribution of losses and risks.
SLOVENIA introduced the draft decision that, inter alia, decides to establish a process and create a framework for capacity-building activities in EITs, urges Annex II Parties to ensure financial support required for the implementation of the capacity building process and further urges the GEF to develop an operational strategy to implement the elements of a framework process for capacity building.
The EU preferred a focus on short-term \t\t\tmeasures, as outlined in Decision 9/CMP.2, which authorizes the \t\t\tExecutive Secretary to take action to minimize the risks of \t\t\tdisputes, complaints and claims against individuals serving on these \t\t\tbodies and also advocated considering legally binding measures in \t\t\tthe context of discussions concerning post-2012 legal arrangements.
The EU stressed the urgency of addressing emissions from bunker fuels, while highlighting the AWG-LCA as the best forum to do so.
LEBANON noted its inability to participate in the CDM because of a lack of capacity.
The EU highlighted the Directive’s de minimis rule, stating that most flights from developing countries will be excluded.
The EU, on the other hand, proposed that decisions stand pending the outcome of an appeal.
Algeria, for the G-77/CHINA, proposed closing all the spin-off groups under the AWG-LCA and called for a “central forum” to help parties understand the status of negotiations.
 On the distribution of commitments, the US proposed flat rate reductions that would bind all Annex I Parties to the same QELROs.
 \t\tIdentifying building blocks for future cooperation, the EU and Norway \t\tcalled for a “shared vision” to reach the UNFCCC’s ultimate objective of \t\tstabilizing greenhouse gas concentrations to a level that avoids \t\tdangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system (Article \t\t2).
The \t\ttext also included a compromise between the EU, US and others that \t\trecognized the methodological difficulties and limited availability of \t\tdata for distinguishing between domestic and international fuel \t\tconsumption.
SICA said the decision on NWP does not sufficiently ensure effective work of the programme.
NEW ZEALAND called for early decisions on transparent emissions trading to harness economic efficiency to the achievement of environmental goals, backed by a firm compliance regime.
BURKINA FASO and ALGERIA stressed that procedures to deal with the GEF can be very cumbersome and that efforts made by non-Annex I Parties must be recognized.
The REPUBLIC OF KOREA noted the need to review the transfer of public-funded technology in the consultative process.
This was opposed by Ireland, Germany, Spain, Norway and the UK, who noted this would give the issue of blue carbon too much prominence, and instead proposed a consideration of blue carbon in the guidance for authors.
BRAZIL said polices and measures must be linked with actions to promote renewable energy, technology transfer and capacity-building.
Brazil, for the G-77/China, said proposed actions in sectors should be voluntary and compatible with an open international economic system.
The G-77/CHINA objected to the proposal.
The G-77/CHINA cautioned against confusing compliance with MRV and highlighted the difficulty of ascertaining the extent to which developed countries are complying with their financing commitments based on their national communications.
SAUDI ARABIA underlined the need to incorporate socio-economic indicators on income, health and education, while modeling the impacts of response measures.
SAUDI ARABIA, highlighting the fact that FCCC Article 4.8 and 4.9 and Protocol Article 3.14 were addressed separately under the Buenos Aires Plan of Action (BAPA), called for two draft decisions.
CHINA preferred governmental officials who are experts on Article 13.
The EU noted that the announcements by Japan, Canada and the Russian Federation to not commit to a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol constitute a step backwards that will influence the political context.
The US also expressed procedural concerns on having \t\ta separate agenda item for the IPCC 92s special report.
The European Union (EU) underlined the importance of domestic implementation of INDCs.
 c2 a0The EU presented a proposal on general accounting principles.
CHINA and INDIA emphasized that the Chairs’ proposal for substantive discussions on legal matters is outside the mandate of the AWG-KP.
Chair Stoycheva said that Rob Mason (UK) and Al Waleed Al-Malik (United Arab Emirates) would co-chair a contact group to prepare a draft COP decision on the matter.
 The G-77/CHINA tabled its own draft decision that asks the COP to define funding requirements from the GEF for implementation of the FCCC as follows: agreed full costs incurred by developing country Parties to prepare national communications; agreed incremental costs to implement measures under Article 4.1 (commitments under common but differentiated responsibility); and costs of adaptation to the adverse effects of climate change.
PANAMA, supported by SAUDI ARABIA, suggested replacing text on reporting and accounting with a reference to Agreement Article 4.13 (accounting for NDCs).
BURUNDI expressed concern over access to data from developed countries, and noted the lack of capacity in poor countries to predict local climate impacts.
Spain, for the EU, welcomed the review of the NWP to build a common view on the continuation and strengthening of the programme.
Opposing a proposal by the EU to include references to the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), the G-77/China insisted that such references should only be addressed in the preambular text.
JAPAN suggested establishing an adaptation information-sharing mechanism.
MICRONESIA called for scientific input to clarify the impacts of long-term targets.
NORWAY favored an integrated approach for the identification of needs.
St. Lucia, for AOSIS, proposed prioritizing: operationalizing the accounting structure; establishing environmental integrity safeguards; sustainable development provisions; and, with Egypt, for the ARAB GROUP, allocating a share of proceeds to adaptation.
COSTA RICA said the level of risk associated with the level of mitigation commitments, or lack thereof, should be assessed.
TURKEY noted its status as a non-signatory because it is listed in both Annex I and II, although UNDP considers it a developing country
Barbados, for AOSIS, supported a short and focused preambular section and said that commitments on finance should be legally binding.
ICELAND and JAPAN proposed multi-year targets and VENEZUELA opposed the introduction of targets and timetables.
Stressing that combating poverty is the agreed priority, KUWAIT said issues related to renewable energy should not be introduced at this point.
Parties discussed the inclusion of mitigation activities, with Canada and the EU calling for a balance between adaptation and mitigation measures.
IRAN said it is natural to assess new Annex I commitments.
BRAZIL, supported by CHINA, PAPUA NEW GUINEA and PARAGUAY, highlighted the three-phased approach, and suggested that the text avoid using terminology that links REDD to the flexibility mechanisms.
The UK, opposed by Switzerland, proposed an \t\t\talternative formulation that separates the impacts of taxes and \t\t\tcharges from their implementation.
MEXICO called for complementarities between national and international efforts, and private and public sources of finance.
SOUTH AFRICA called for a redraft of the information paper to provide a clear understanding on the way forward.
During discussions, issues were raised by Indonesia, Norway, Australia, the US, Switzerland, Tuvalu and the EU, including items on: the need for more in-depth work on the distinction between supported and unsupported NAMAs and the role of the Registry; the calculation of BAU scenarios and baselines; identifying the most useful international support for NAMAs; and financial constraints and conditionalities.
ARGENTINA and NEW ZEALAND called for mechanisms for compliance and dispute settlement.
The EU asserted that levies are the most complicated option.
MEXICO emphasized the need for assessing progress along the way and supported ex ante review of commitments, as proposed by AILAC.
The Cook Islands, for AOSIS, underscored that consideration of loss and damage is mandated by Decision 1/CP.16 (outcome of the AWG-LCA).
GERMANY stressed the importance of existing clean technologies in establishing the infrastructure necessary for developing future clean technologies.
TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO, on behalf of AOSIS, proposed deleting language making the option for no allocation of bunker fuels a “priority” for action.
The EU, \t\tUS, Canada and others questioned the need for and mandate of such a \t\tgroup.
CHINA, with SAUDI ARABIA and INDONESIA, said that reference to consequences should be with regard to all developing countries.
The UK praised Penman’s long, distinguished career as a scientist in addition to his warmth and kindness as a man.
AUSTRALIA stated that the range of measures must be comprehensive and cautioned against selective sectoral processes in the absence of established criteria.
The G-77/CHINA said the Secretariat should ensure balance between developed and developing countries when hiring consultants to prepare the technical papers.
NORWAY, the EU and JAPAN opposed an ex ante process to commit to quantified support commensurate with the ambition reflected in the adaptation and mitigation goals, with the EU signaling this as e2 80 9ca red line.
Maldives, for AOSIS, urged parties to engage substantively and move towards a streamlined text before negotiations in Bangkok.
On the decision inviting international organizations to present a status report on their activities relating to P&amp;Ms, the US, supported by the EU and AUSTRALIA, proposed that this should be integrated within the decision requesting the Secretariat to support future work.
NIGERIA, TANZANIA and ZAMBIA warned against overreliance on the private sector.
Switzerland, for the ENVIRONMENTAL INTEGRITY GROUP, stressed the need to strengthen coordination between the AWGs and emphasized that both AWGs should finish their work in Barcelona in November.
INDIA said that HFCs must be addressed under the UNFCCC and cautioned that patents granted on low scientific thresholds inhibit competition.
NEW ZEALAND noted that information reported in national communications is already operationalized because Annex I parties are reporting on the ways they are implementing their policies to avoid potential consequences.
Noting recent studies published since the cutoff date of AR5 that call into question the increase in sea ice extent around Antarctica, the US questioned the usefulness of including very specific numbers in this regard.
SWITZERLAND proposed a common transparency framework, which would evolve over time and be applicable to all parties, encompassing delivery, use and impact of support.
FRANCE underlined the importance of providing \t\tinformation to local decision makers.
JAPAN highlighted: substantial evidence that warming is occurring; the requirement for future emissions lower than 1990 levels, if concentrations are to stabilize; the suggestion that a significant amount of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions can be reduced at small or negligible cost; that diffusion of technology is vital; and that while scientific uncertainty still exists, the possibly huge impact requires action according to the precautionary principle.
ZAMBIA said differentiation needs to be reflected.
PAPUA NEW GUINEA suggested that the SBSTA had “undershot” what could have been achieved and that the AWG-LCA had moved too slowly to address the necessary policy issues.
Gabon, for the AFRICAN GROUP, noted that progress on adaptation communication could be accelerated through a formal linkage with the transparency framework.
Meles Zenawi, Prime Minister of Ethiopia, for the African Group, noted the importance of Africa speaking with one voice, and outlined a short-term finance proposal that includes: US$10 billion per year for 2010-2012; a board of trustees with representatives from an equal number of donor and recipient countries; 40% of funds earmarked for Africa; and a committee of experts to facilitate the launch of the fund.
Pakistan, for the G-77/China, expressed his \t\t\tsatisfaction that parties had finalized a number of recommendations \t\t\tand laid down foundations for COP 13 and COP/MOP 3.
Trinidad and Tobago (on behalf of AOSIS) the Marshall Islands, Samoa, Micronesia, Norway, Mauritius, Solomon Islands and Cuba preferred Alternative A, provided that protocols are adopted by consensus or, as a last resort, a 2/3 majority vote.
The EU preferred the test plan and schedules for the \t\tinitialization of the electronic communications with registry systems to \t\tbe carried out prior to COP/MOP-1 in order to ensure the prompt start of \t\tthe CDM.
INDIA and CHINA underscored the need for information on how to achieve temperature goals.
South Africa, for the AFRICAN GROUP, and Costa Rica, for AILAC, emphasized, inter alia, including commitments on the scale of finance.
The COOK ISLANDS proposed a compensation mechanism for loss and damage based on the polluter-pays principle.
NIGERIA suggested that, as many non-Annex I Parties have yet to submit national communications, information abstracted from relevant government ministries could be provided as an interim measure, as this would facilitate immediate action relating to the impacts of response measures.
BANGLADESH and TIMOR-LESTE requested enhanced financial resources and easier access to implement national adaptation programmes of action (NAPAs).
On the procedures for the enforcement branch, the RUSSIAN FEDERATION, opposed by the EU, suggested text reflecting the right for the Party concerned to have a closed hearing.
 The EU called for progress under all SBSTA agenda items, particularly agriculture as a potential sector to progress on both mitigation and adaptation.
The EU highlighted the importance of further progress on, inter alia, LULUCF, surplus AAUs and the flexibility mechanisms.
Some developing countries urged a more action-oriented approach, with SUDAN suggesting a “mechanism for actions,” while the US and AUSTRALIA stressed the need to focus on the most critical points.
The following countries presented on results and progress related to achieving their quantified, economy-wide emissions reduction targets: the EU, Canada, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and France.
The EU, supported by AUSTRALIA, JAPAN and the US, preferred to drop the list of information requests and to reference an earlier paragraph in the Co-Chairs\' text, on identification of effects and impacts.
The UK, France, \t\t\tGermany, New Zealand and others proposed keeping the explicit \t\t\tcomparison, while China and Saudi Arabia proposed deleting it.
The PHILIPPINES stressed that ambition must be addressed in the context of the mandates of the AWG-LCA and AWG-KP, and that working outside the UNFCCC risks undermining the multilateral process, causes proliferation of redundant institutions and structures, and fosters inequity.
INDIA highlighted that support should cover full costs of measures and not be based on assessments of needs.
CANADA supported working through two groups, which would make progress possible in the discussions to raise the level of ambition and arrive at a “single, global and comprehensive agreement” for all parties.
JAPAN and others highlighted the importance of the private sector.
BOLIVIA expressed concern that requirements being imposed on developed and developing countries are too similar.
CANADA stressed that comparability should take into consideration the full range of contributions including investment in RD&amp;D and support for REDD-readiness in developing countries.
He underscored President Obama’s plans for a federal cap-and-trade system that will set the US pathway to cutting emissions by 15% from current levels by 2020 and 80% by 2050, and highlighted technological leap-frogging by developing countries.

The Democratic Republic of the Congo, for the AFRICAN GROUP, with Grenada, for AOSIS, recommended that parties commence work on the items traditionally included in the SBSTA agenda while consulting on the proposed new items.

 In March 2001, the US administration repudiated the Kyoto Protocol, stating that it considered the Protocol to be "fatally flawed," as it would damage its economy and exempt developing countries from emission reductions.

Sudan, for the G-77/China, called for an equitable outcome in Copenhagen.
Provision is made for fostering LDC participation in the CDM.
The subgroup on Article 5.1 considered the second Draft Guidelines for National Systems under Article 5.1 of the Kyoto Protocol and submissions by the EU and the US.
Switzerland, for the Environmental Integrity Group (EIG), outlined three important steps for Durban: agreeing on key elements of an international regime after 2012; launching a process to further strengthen the regime in the mid-term; and agreeing on the key elements of a shared vision, including a long-term global goal for emission reductions and a date for peaking of global emissions.
Regarding future actions, GERMANY said it would commit itself to a 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions from 1990 levels by 2020 if all developed countries committed themselves to further reductions, and the EU committed itself to emission reductions of about 30%.
IRAN said the CDM should include projects related to both sinks and sources.
The US, NORWAY and CANADA highlighted the importance of the private sector.
On institutions, Maldives, for AOSIS, called for recognizing the Adaptation Committee as the lead institution, and, with Chile, for AILAC, utilizing existing communication channels.
In consultation with regional groups and AOSIS, the AGBM Chair would invite six advisers to participate on the Bureau with equal status to the elected and ex-officio members.
JAPAN expressed doubt over a quantitative goal on adaptation.
The insistence on G-77/China involvement was linked to the level of ambition acceptable by the US and, in response, the G-77/China distanced themselves from attempts to draw developing countries into agreeing to anything that could be interpreted as new commitments.
NORWAY proposed that the reporting of indirect emissions should be made mandatory.
The EU, AUSTRALIA, JAPAN, US and SWITZERLAND preferred a single decision.
