The LDC Expert Group (LEG) reported that it advanced its work to provide guidance on National Adaptation Plans (NAPs) and to consult parties on their needs.
AUSTRALIA supported retaining the reference to "most authoritative and comprehensive" as well as paragraph 2.
On the way forward, SWITZERLAND suggested the Chair provide clarity on the available options and underscored the need for further discussions on “technicalities” on issues such as LULUCF and mechanisms.
Several parties, including China, Saudi Arabia, for the Arab Group, South Africa and AILAC noted it is premature to discuss placement.
 \t\t\tGermany, for \t\t\tthe EU, stated the EU’s commitment to cut emissions by 30% by 2020 \t\t\tcompared with 1990 levels if other developed countries follow suit \t\t\tand economically advanced developing countries “contribute \t\t\tadequately according to their responsibilities and respective \t\t\tcapabilities.” She urged extending the carbon market, addressing \t\t\temissions from international aviation and maritime transportation, \t\t\tand progress on the Adaptation Fund and budget.
Australia, for the Umbrella Group, highlighted the role of major economies and identified the need for a global agreement that is informed by science, achievable, comprehensive, and able to reflect the full spectrum of mitigation and adaptation options.
Australia, for the UMBRELLA GROUP, called for building on the Cancun Agreements, including developing strong outcomes on REDD+.
CANADA opposed Tuvalu’s proposal to classify “removing financial additionality” as a second commitment period issue.
CANADA outlined actions geared toward meeting its economy-wide target of reducing emissions by 17% from 2005 levels.
JAPAN suggested that the contact group reconvene in light of G-77/China\'s willingness to engage.
 NORWAY, ICELAND and AUSTRALIA suggested establishing indicators as a basis for differentiation.
 Nauru, for AOSIS, proposed a technical process to deploy specific mitigation solutions.
China, for BASIC, welcomed the text as open and balanced, and indicated willingness to work towards an outcome that reflects fairness and ambition.
The EU proposed requesting GEF to report to the COP on its funding for developing countries to build capacity for participation in systematic observation networks.
She opposed “weak political solutions,” stressing that AOSIS is not prepared to wait and gamble with the safety and livelihoods of their people, and called for a legally-binding outcome in Copenhagen.
 \t\t\tThe UK \t\t\tidentified the need to consider the role of the UNFCCC in technology \t\t\tcooperation in the longer term, and ICELAND said one element of this \t\t\tcould involve encouraging cooperation between the government and \t\t\tprivate sectors.
Nauru, for AOSIS, discussed elements of equity, science, sustainable development and survival.
  Sudan, for the G-77/CHINA, stressed that the core mandate of the ongoing negotiations is to define ambitious quantified emission reduction targets for future commitment periods.
She \t\tsaid the US wanted to go forward as part of a new framework and to be \t\tpart of the roadmap.
Nauru, for AOSIS, said the framework should measure progress toward a global goal of 1.5 or 2 c2 b0C and promote participation of all countries.
The EU suggested text on effective institutional arrangements.
NORWAY called for an ambitious and long-term global climate change regime and stressed the need for a political response to the IPCC TAR.
Brazil, for the G-77/China, stressed the need for a “solid and strong” definition of comparability, highlighting the Protocol as the basis for comparability assessment and identifying the need to define comparability through international negotiations rather than nationally.
NEW ZEALAND, CANADA, the EU and US supported the revised conclusions, arguing that they provided a balanced compromise.
The REPUBLIC OF KOREA and QATAR observed that they had both offered to host COP 18 and COP/MOP 8 and said they were consulting bilaterally on the matter.
Chair Ojoo-Massawa then presented the draft decision on the CGE, noting that all reference to LDCs and NAPAs remains bracketed pending the decision taken in the LDC consultations on whether mention of LDCs and NAPAs would be included in the CGE decision.
He added that the OECD and the IEA have already begun work on a possible process, and that the UK would regard the reduction of 5% to 10% below 1990 levels as an acceptable figure.
The EU, supported by JAPAN, preferred referring to efforts that parties are able to e2 80 9cundertake, e2 80 9d instead of e2 80 9cmake unilaterally.
SAUDI ARABIA identified the need for new text under the Protocol track.
India, with AOSIS, suggested widening the scope to include an assessment of adequacy in accordance with the latest available scientific literature.
EGYPT invited the Chair to present a balanced proposal.
CANADA suggested requesting the FCCC Secretariat to organize workshops on adverse effects and on response measures, and report the outcomes at COP-7.
Bangladesh urged a focus on proposals that highlight the needs of LDCs and SIDS.
MADAGASCAR highlighted uncertainty over impacts of a voluntary registry.
SOUTH AFRICA proposed the Secretariat prepare a document providing references to existing guidelines and modalities that may be applicable to this and other APA agenda items.
Noting \t\tthat the first commitment period is only an initial step, SWITZERLAND, \t\tfor the Environmental Integrity Group, urged Parties to consider ways \t\tand means to address climate change challenges beyond 2012.
AUSTRALIA, with CANADA, said addressing climate change is best served by a regime that includes commitments from all major emitters and said that the regime constructed under the AWG-LCA should “draw together actions by all.” AUSTRALIA underscored the need to resolve technical issues related to LULUCF under the AWG-KP track.
The RUSSIAN FEDERATION requested clarification of the meaning of e2 80 9cactions e2 80 9d and e2 80 9ccommitments.
FRANCE stated that effective market transformation is \t\tdriven by retailers and manufacturers.
ADOPTION OF AGENDA: Following the opening statements, the COP adopted its agenda (FCCC/CP/1999/1) with the exception of item 5 relating to the second review of the adequacy of commitments under FCCC Article 4.2(a) and (b) (policies and measures by Annex I Parties), following objections to the title by the G-77/CHINA, who preferred to substitute it with the 93review of adequacy of implementation of FCCC Articles 4.2(a) and (b).
The EU, opposed by BRAZIL, the CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC and KENYA, suggested that the CGE 92s findings be presented by June 2001 to contribute to the review of guidelines so as to adopt at COP-7 improved guidelines for the second national communications.
  The EU, opposed by CHINA, said SBSTA conclusions should include a reference to substitutes for ozone depleting substances, as contained in the report of the 20th Meeting of the Parties to the Montreal Protocol.
  The UN Climate Summit was held on 23 September 2014, at UN Headquarters in New York, US, hosted by UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon.
Parties were informed that matters pertaining to guidance to the GEF on implementing the LDC work programme had been moved to the group on the financial mechanism.
The EU proposed holding a workshop, roundtable and high-level discussion at COP 14 on this issue.
AOSIS identified the need for clarity on sectors, the meaning of credits, boundary issues, MRV and source of funds.
e2 80 9d NORWAY said parties will need to decide what status to give to the e2 80 9cimproved non-paper e2 80 9d on elements.
On allowing borrowing of assigned amount from future commitment periods, the G-77/CHINA supported no decision on the issue, while UKRAINE and CANADA preferred maintaining the option.
The US emphasized a consultative period and upfront information as important for promoting ambition and clarity.
In their opening statements, Argentina, for the Group of 77 and China (G-77/China), warned against “transferring unresolved issues” from the AWG-LCA to the SBSTA, saying the AWG-LCA should maintain an overview of specific issues that were mandated for consideration by the SBSTA.
The EU outlined possible elements of a Copenhagen agreement, including: integration of adaptation into national decision making and planning; scaling up of resources for adaptation; and support for LDCs to formulate adaptation plans and programmes.
The LMDCs, opposed by the EU, proposed developing accounting guidance for technology and capacity-building support.
CHINA called for clear temporal goals for addressing critical issues and suggested prioritizing institutional arrangements.
Venezuela, for ALBA, expressed “alarm over certain elements of the report, which would hinder democratic access to resources.” She stressed that the GCF must possess international legal personality, work under the guidance of the COP and have no conflict of interest between the fiduciary and executive trustee functions.
Obasi thanked the UK government for hosting the meeting.
The US also said the registry was an important element for ensuring accurate reporting and tracking, as well as to ensure compliance.
The EU said the SCCF should be a catalyst for leveraging additional resources from bilateral and multilateral sources.
Canada, supported by the US, noted the need to involve both communications specialists as well as scientific writers.
FINLAND said a comprehensive negotiation package should also address the concerns of EITs.
Bolivia, for ALBA, said the Durban outcome did not deliver a solution to developed countries’ lack of political will to undertake ambitious emission reduction commitments.
FINLAND said high resolution climate models are not yet well developed.
On needs assessment, CANADA proposed an integrated approach beyond needs assessment in a narrow sense, to improve the enabling environment for technology transfer.
Lesotho, for the LDCs, emphasized the centrality of the UNFCCC framework and highlighted the need for renewed trust-building among parties.
The AFRICA GROUP said the issue of access to development financing through AIJ required urgent resolution at COP-5.
On the path towards Durban, SOUTH AFRICA, as the incoming Presidency, noted the challenges but expressed optimism that the talks would continue to instill confidence in the UNFCCC process.
JAPAN stressed the need to coordinate work with the AWG-KP and to revise the MRV system to include both Annex I and non-Annex I parties, taking into account differences between them.
The US stated that commitments for all Parties must allow for economic growth while simultaneously protecting the environment.
On the time remaining in Bonn, the G-77/CHINA, the LMDCs and BRAZIL suggested discussing cross-cutting issues, and, with Australia, for the UMBRELLA GROUP, and Angola, for the LDCs, addressing workstream 2.
JAPAN urged speeding up work on the text, and identified the need to discuss overarching mitigation issues and to ensure coherence between the two negotiating tracks.
Regarding research and systematic observations, ARGENTINA, on behalf of the Valdivia Group, sought expanded research on natural climate variability in the region and on oceanic effects.
 \t\tThe EU, CANADA and others said deforestation should be part of the \t\tframework addressing climate change post-2012.
On supplementarity, he identified “a strong wish” to limit the CDM, noting a cap on CDM credits in the EU’s post-2012 climate and energy package.
Grenada, for the Alliance of Small Island States (AOSIS), said the AWG-LCA must expedite its work and AWG-KP 6 should agree on emission reduction ranges for industrialized countries as a group.
SOUTH AFRICA supported the need to develop modeling activities and improve data collection in developing countries.
New Zealand, with the EU, US and Japan, emphasized that such estimates from all sectors should be prepared under good practice guidance, and be adjusted when they are not prepared according to the agreed methodologies.
Regarding the draft decision, the EU, JAPAN and NORWAY questioned the need for text in the decision on principles.
On paragraph 98 on principles and targets regarding the provision of finance post-2020, parties agreed to a proposal by the G-77/CHINA to delete option 3 in favor of option 4.
On the time-frame for market \t\tincentives and government intervention, FRANCE noted that progress in \t\ttechnological innovations is evident before regulation.
Chile, for AILAC, said that e2 80 9ccontributions e2 80 9d should be communicated every five years, with an indication of contributions for the subsequent five-year period, as well as the five-year period following that.
The G-77/CHINA underscored the importance of maintaining the UNFCCC and Protocol as separate and distinct bodies, both legally and procedurally.
The EU expressed willingness to commit to a second commitment period as part of a global, binding framework.
TUVALU also proposed taking up sectoral approaches under the AWGLCA, creating revenues for low emitting countries by auctioning AAUs and reviewing accessibility and geographical allocation rules.
The EU stressed focusing on actual mitigation actions that are additional to those already in place.
The SBI decides to consider further guidance for the operation of the LDC Fund at SBI-19 with a view to recommending a decision to COP-9.
The UNITED ARAB EMIRATES stated that no one indicator gives a complete view of what constitutes a fair commitment and proposed that each party provide an explanation of its commitment using its own yardstick.
MEXICO said he looked forward to using the CDM to supplement national efforts to shift from slash-and-burn techniques, which are responsible for loss of forest cover, to sustainable technologies that would have a positive impact on climate change.
NEW ZEALAND said their interpretation of the text on positive lists meant that any renewable energy project in major developing country would be additional and that they preferred the option of no lists.
Argentina, for ARGENTINA, BRAZIL, AND URUGUAY, said real progress would not be possible without properly addressing finance issues and called for building flexibility for developing countries into the procedures of the transparency framework and the implementation and compliance committee.
 In the morning session on mitigation, on the sub-section on long-term and global aspects, SOUTH AFRICA stressed a long-term goal should be consistent with what is required by science, and Tuvalu, for the LDCs, said the goal should be to keep the temperature increase below 1.5 c2 b0C.
Bangladesh, with the EU and Canada, supported the extension of the LEG 92s mandate, and highlighted complementarity between the LDC Fund and the SCCF.
AUSTRALIA recommended a platform for observers to report and comment on specific outcomes and a forum for observers to provide input to the COP high-level segments.
Pakistan, for the G-77/CHINA, supported by others, requested background material and updates as a basis for negotiating text.
SPAIN called for progress on developing a process of technology transfer and efforts to address the issue of public awareness and education.
KUWAIT and CHINA raised concerns about holding joint meetings.
ARGENTINA expressed concern at the 93hasty 94 \t\tadoption of an amendment to Annex I of the London Protocol to allow for \t\tCCS in sub-seabed geological formations.
CHINA suggested joint consultations between APA work on NDC guidance, and SBI and SBSTA work on information regarding finance.
Noting it had sought “considerable flexibility” and recognizing flexibility by other parties, the EU suggested that the initial capitalization of the GCF and the Lima Call for Climate Action provide a good direction towards an ambitious agreement in Paris.
The US supported observer and private sector engagement with the SCF and the GEF.
Switzerland, for the ENVIRONMENTAL INTEGRITY GROUP, emphasized the importance of progress under the AWG-LCA and said that parties should strive to have a set of draft decisions by the end of the week.
ICELAND said improvements to degraded land should be included in the list of human-induced activities.
JAPAN opposed addressing the flow of climate finance under workstream 2.
CHINA emphasized that the current pledges are not sufficient.
Australia, for the UMBRELLA GROUP, expressed commitment to being part of a durable, fair, effective and comprehensive outcome with the participation of all major economies.
The \t\tG-77/CHINA and the AFRICAN GROUP said an agreement on the AWG 92s \t\ttimetable is necessary given the time required for ratification.
The IPCC will convene three workshops for the further development of the Guidelines for National GHG Inventories on the following topics: sources and removal by sinks of greenhouse gases from land use and forestry (Sao Jos ef bf bd dos Campos, Sao Paulo, 21-22 March 1996); emissions from fuel combustion and industrial processes (Abingdon, UK, 29-30 March 1996); and, methane emissions from rice cultivation (Bangkok, Thailand, 30 April - 2 May 1996).
Japan, Singapore and the EU said the IMO and ICAO are the suitable places to address these issues.
SWITZERLAND proposed that the Secretariat maintain a \t\tmethodologies website.
The EU said it did not “imagine” the ADP continuing beyond Paris.
Egypt, for the ARAB GROUP, noted missing elements from the Chair’s outcome note and called for working on the basis of the August negotiating text.
  The G-77/CHINA highlighted that response measures must be seen in the broader context of sustainable development, including the Rio+20 outcome, and should include qualitative and quantitative assessments in their design and implementation phase that address socio-economic consequences.
 South Africa, for the G-77/CHINA, stressed the need for equal consideration of all SBSTA agenda items and to finish work on REDD+.
On the composition of the Executive Board, delegates agreed to additional text proposed by SAMOA whereby the COP/ MOP will elect an alternate for each member of the Board.
Highlighting the need for draft text on IAR, AUSTRALIA called for making use of existing COP guidance and reviewing the extent to which parties have achieved quantified economy wide emission reduction targets.
NEW ZEALAND called on parties to resolve tensions between a “deep and fluid” carbon market and the use of markets to rectify other problems.
JAPAN asked whether unilaterally-funded projects were consistent with the concept of CDM.
ARGENTINA cautioned against prejudging SBSTA discussions on LULUCF and requested that various approaches be referenced in addition to markets.
CANADA proposed using a table with parties’ targets expressed in terms of multiple base years.
IRELAND, ITALY, GERMANY and SLOVENIA stressed domestic action as the main means of meeting Protocol commitments.
The US further objected to the language used in the Chair\'s report on the work of AG13.

CHINA, with IRAN, KUWAIT, BRAZIL and ARGENTINA said it was inappropriate to give ERTs, a simple fact finding body, a triggering role.
The US accepted the proposed structure of one body with two branches and underlined the US focus on commitments rather than on Parties.
The PHILIPPINES called for information on technology transfer activities in Annex I communications.
The Democratic Republic of the Congo, for the LDCs, highlighted the need to simplify procedures for financial support for NAP implementation.
LIBERIA stressed the vulnerability of LDCs and outlined his country’s energy policy, which includes a low-emissions development path.
BRAZIL supported the AOSIS text but cautioned that too many details may lead to inefficiencies.

Australia, for the Umbrella Group, emphasized that progress in the negotiations should be made based on COP 15’s outcomes, including the Copenhagen Accord, and expressed conviction that agreement can be reached at COP 16.
The EU called for referencing human rights, while ZAMBIA expressed discomfort with such a reference.
CHINA, supported by KUWAIT and others, said a facilitator would not be able to visit and confer with all Parties.

AOSIS called for assessing whether ambition is in line with the 1.5 or 2 c2 b0C limit.

The PHILIPPINES, on behalf of Algeria, Argentina, Bolivia, China, Cuba, The Democratic Republic of the Congo, Dominica, Ecuador, Egypt, El Salvador, India, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Mali, Mauritania, Nicaragua, Pakistan, Paraguay, Saudi Arabia, Sri Lanka, Sudan and Venezuela, called on developed country parties to commit to QELROs to reduce emissions by at least 40-50% below 1990 levels by 2020 and at least 25-40% by 2017.
Maldives, for AOSIS, said the Dialogue’s political outcome should reaffirm the 1.5 c2 b0C goal, and, supported by INDIA, urged it to recognize the emissions and finance gaps.
The African Group emphasized equal treatment of adaptation and mitigation, and the special needs of Africa, small island developing states (SIDS) and the LDCs.

PANAMA said adaptation should be given the same status as mitigation under the UNFCCC.

The US said MRV should not be confined to NAMAs themselves, but should also take into account their context to understand the net results and the direction of global emissions.
The G-77/CHINA called for increased efficiency, expeditious use of resources, and geographical and gender balance in the Secretariat, and supported the inclusion of Protocol-related activities in the Secretariat 92s core budget.

SAUDI ARABIA preferred a contact group.
The final decision, inter alia: approves the programme budget for 2000-2001, amounting to US$25,286,000; approves a contingency fund in case the UN General Assembly decides not to provide resources for these activities in the regular UN budget; requests the Executive Secretary to report to COP-6 on the income and budget performance, and propose any adjustments that might be needed; and authorizes the Executive Secretary to incur additional expenses to offset part of the costs of activities arising from the preparatory process leading to COP-6.
The EU noted the importance of discussing HFCs and bunker fuels, and AUSTRALIA, with MALAWI, proposed establishing a drafting group on bunker fuels.
On the carryover of AAUs, SOUTH AFRICA highlighted several options: allowing carryover of x% of AAUs; adopting stricter emission reduction targets to absorb the surplus; and putting AAUs in a strategic reserve.

 JAPAN expressed disappointment that no agreement was reached, but proposed that further negotiations be conducted during the intersessional period prior to the October AGBM meeting.
The UK explained that the burden of proof regarding eligibility was on the shoulders of the Party submitting its inventory, yet in the case of a Party challenging another Party, it was up to the challenger to prove its case.
ZIMBABWE, for the G-77/CHINA, said the conclusions failed to make a clear reference to the COP-7 decision on adverse effects (5/CP.7), and stressed the importance of reflecting views of implementation progress on wider activities.
Australia, for the Umbrella Group, preferred working from existing informal notes, saying that too few items are mature enough for a single progress document.
NEW ZEALAND questioned if the options can be combined, saying one is general and the other is specific.
SAMOA said that due process must be balanced with the interest of the community to have issues settled.
BRAZIL stressed scaling up actions and linkages to MOI.
The Gambia, for LDCs, said that although integration of adaptation into development planning is important, implementation of NAPAs must not be delayed by this process.
The EU advocated determining the most appropriate body to take work forward on individual issues when the AWG-LCA closes in Doha, and avoiding transferring them to the ADP.
The G-77/China, with Brazil, Samoa and Jamaica, and opposed by the US and Canada, said assigned amounts (AAs) were fixed.
TUVALU said further methodological work is needed on degradation and demand-side measures.
JAPAN said that adaptation is an important issue but expressed \t\tconcern over the discussions underway on decision 5/CP.7.
On Timing and Procedures, the EU said the trial inventory review period under the FCCC would provide useful guidance for the proposed one-year time frame.
The PHILIPPINES underscored that MRV is “meaningless without compliance” and called for a technical panel on comparability.
After brief consultations, the Chair announced that informal consultations on the LDC Fund would be held parallel to a contact group on the Special Climate Change Fund.
AUSTRALIA said the guidelines may be applicable to Protocol inventories.
The Democratic Republic of Congo, on behalf of the AFRICAN GROUP, called for strengthening the mandate of the NWP and further engage the region into the CDM process.
AUSTRALIA noted \t\tthe need for the text to show that the range of technical options may be \t\tgreater than those that could be used legally.
 e2 80 a2 c2 a0 notes that the amount of funding available for the climate change focal area was reduced in the GEF’s sixth replenishment period, and that the allocation of some countries, including some LDCs, SIDS, and African states, has decreased as a consequence;
South Africa, for the G-77/CHINA, stressed the need to avoid lengthy discussions on this issue.
PAPUA NEW GUINEA agreed with the focus on Protocol Article 3.9 but, supported by others, called for also considering forest issues and REDD.
The EU, Switzerland, and Canada indicated commitment to scaling up climate finance to the US$100 billion goal by 2020.
He also demanded the immediate ratification of the Protocol by Australia, Canada, Russia, and the US.
The US stated that movement is only possible with balanced package and highlighted the need to improve text on sub-paragraph 1(b)(ii) of the Bali Action Plan (mitigation by developing countries).

The G-77/CHINA opposed additional workshops, regardless of their TORs, citing budgetary constraints and the need for "a total discussion" on the implementation of decision 13/CP.7.
 , Germany, supported by France and the US, called for reporting all non-CO2 emissions from non-combustion in the energy sector.
The PHILIPPINES, on behalf of the Asian Group, and supported by INDIA, PAKISTAN, CHINA, SAUDI ARABIA, INDONESIA, KUWAIT and IRAN, stated that, on the election of the Vice-Chair, they had asked for a guarantee to honor the UN principle of geographical rotation after the next term, but this had been rejected.
 \t\tChristine Copley, World Coal Institute, UK, spoke on the prospects for \t\tcoal in the context of sustainable development.
South Africa, for the AFRICAN GROUP, expressed concern with proposals to link NAMAs with the carbon market and noted that MRV of NAMA support by developed countries requires more consideration.
ARGENTINA said private funding should be complementary to public funding.
NIGERIA called for inclusion of Africa.
 On this issue, BRAZIL reiterated the importance of the CDM in promoting sustainable development and proposed that definition of forests in exhaustion included in Annex 3 of the CDM Executive Board 50’s proposed agenda should be used as a basis of discussion.
The UMBRELLA GROUP also called for biennial streamlined communications with information on implementation of issues including: targets and/or actions; emissions impacts; methodologies; provision or receipt of finance, technology and capacity building support; and the use of international trading and offsets.
NIGERIA identified the need for the intergovernmental process to continue when the ministers arrive, warning against repeating “a previous situation” where parties end up in separate rooms.
The G-77/CHINA and SAUDI ARABIA, opposed by CANADA and AUSTRALIA, proposed text on the need to minimize the adverse effects of Annex I Parties.
The US preferred treating bunker emissions separately from national inventories, which the EU said results in no direct incentives to limit or reduce bunker emissions.
The LMDCs, opposed by the EU, suggested that a paragraph on identifying policy options differentiate between implementation in developed countries and support to overcome barriers to implementation in developing countries.
Tuvalu, supported by the US and \t\t\tSudan, opposed a statement indicating that such reductions are \t\t\tpermanent, and WGIII removed that language.
BRAZIL suggested that each party submit a contribution for a five-year term and an indicative contribution for the subsequent term.
On reporting of the Committee\'s work, the US queried the frequency, form and content of reports to the COP.
AOSIS said the Kyoto Protocol rules should be the starting point on which all parties should build.
On textual amendments, several parties supported retaining text on the first commitment period and adding new text on the second, while CANADA noted this may become cumbersome, and NEW ZEALAND proposed a case-by-case approach.
GERMANY proposed referring to the declaration as the “Geneva Declaration.”
ANTIGUA AND BARBUDA said the Co-Chairs’ text does not accurately represent the discussions from ADP 2-10.
The US underscored that the per capita gross domestic product of economies benefiting from fossil fuel extraction “is well within the range of developed countries” and that discussions should focus on the most vulnerable.
ZAMBIA criticized some Annex I Parties for saying they are not legally bound to return to 1990 GHG levels.
The US said a long-term goal should be global, realistic, consistent with recent changes in economic development, based on science and aspirational.
AOSIS, with the African Group, highlighted the need for adaptation surcharges to be assessed against all the Protocol mechanisms.
COSTA RICA described the shared vision as the destination with the building blocks determining how to get there.
NEW ZEALAND stressed the need to define the boundaries of a work plan and possible forum and, with CANADA and the US, said the current text is unbalanced.
ZAMBIA suggested that the tables should indicate those parties that are exceeding or have exceeded their first commitment period targets.
AOSIS responded that the COP would make a decision on that, and that lessons learned from past review processes should be taken into account.
On small-scale projects, INDIA \t\tnoted COP/MOP 1 92s request for a simpler methodology.
Addressing the Delhi Declaration, ITALY said it should consider action beyond 2012.
The G-77/CHINA expressed disappointment at the low level of financial resources provided by Annex I Parties, stressing that action so far has been symbolic.
Stressing that a long-term goal is crucial, the EU acknowledged progress has been made on agreement in the MEF to limit warming to not more than 2°C, as well as on the concept of peaking and moving toward low-carbon economies.
IRELAND (on behalf of the EU), UZBEKISTAN and SWITZERLAND also made submissions (FCCC/AG13/1997/ Misc.1).

On decision paragraphs regarding giving effect to the agreement, specifically on efforts of all actors, BOLIVIA opposed juxtaposing local communities and indigenous peoples with the private sector.

On criteria and guiding principles, the EU called for inclusion of further criteria and a guiding principle emphasizing emissions reduction.
On attendance of the meetings, delegates agreed to a proposal by SAMOA opening attendance to stakeholders.
The G-77/CHINA proposed alternative language from Decision 3/CP.3 on undertaking a process.
Viet Nam, for ASEAN, and INDONESIA highlighted stress-tolerant crop varieties, alternate wetting and drying in rice cultivation, and integrated cropping calendars.
BURKINA FASO, for the AFRICA GROUP, underscored the high expectations of the international community that COP-7 will be a success.

New Zealand, with the US, argued that a JI project should be subject to CDM-type scrutiny only where a Party does not comply with Articles 5 and 7, and where non-compliance with both articles impacts the project.
Barbados, for AOSIS, with Colombia, for Chile, Peru, Costa Rica and Guatemala, and others, supported a political process covering the scaling up and mobilization of climate finance, as well as an intensified and more structured work under the Convention, focusing on sources and options for mobilizing climate finance in the short, medium and long term.
The ADP Co-Chairs proposed informal discussions on finance continue coordinated by Gary William Theseira, Malaysia, and Christo Artusio, US.
BANGLADESH said his country is in the initial stages of developing NAMAs and that mitigation action will be focused on energy transformation and consumption, LULUCF and industry.
KIRIBATI called for a framework that ensures that vulnerable countries have access to financing to address the adverse affects of climate change.
Lesotho, for the LDCs, stressed that the Protocol has established the institutional and governance structures that “are and must remain at the heart of the climate regime.” He called for extending the share of proceeds and broadening the scope of eligible LULUCF activities under the CDM.
The EU said the upcoming workshop should consider, inter alia, defining 93best practices 94 and assessing the extent to which international cooperation may enhance effectiveness of policies and measures.
The Philippines, for the G-77/CHINA and others, supported maintaining the preamble, saying it was aimed at identifying the gaps in implementation.
The US stressed adequate consideration of natural climate variability, feedbacks and drivers other than climate change, and the consistent treatment of uncertainty, noting that the sources and quantification of uncertainty should be explicitly addressed within each chapter.
Tuvalu, for the LDCs, suggested a capacity-building institute and earmarking GCF funds for capacity building.
The EU suggested avoiding “show me the money vs. show me the actions” arguments, and supported low carbon development strategies.
The US queried the budgetary implications of discontinuing the Expert Advisory Group and, supported by Belgium, suggested adding to the decision that Committee members could attend meetings virtually rather than in person to ease efforts to achieve quorum.
Switzerland, for the EIG, called on the Co-Chairs to ensure overall balance in the process, gradually deepening the substance and robustness of the text.
The GAMBIA urged the continuation of the Protocol beyond 2012.
CHINA called for a timetable to guide the \t\t\tAWG’s work.

JAPAN outlined its proposed draft protocol, saying it relates to the Protocol’s deficiencies, including that the Kyoto Protocol only covers 30% of global emissions.
NEW ZEALAND distinguished between a common set of rules and full harmonization, saying the latter may not be possible for markets and LULUCF.

AOSIS, Norway and the LDCs stressed that an ex ante assessment of INDCs is necessary to inform whether e2 80 9cwe are on the right track e2 80 9d to achieve the 2 c2 b0C goal, suggesting the Secretariat assess aggregate ambition.

On the way forward, in particular in relation to the work of the AWG-LCA, Spain, for the EU, supported by NORWAY, SWITZERLAND and JAPAN, urged for text reiterating the need for a coherent approach between the Convention and Protocol in relation to commitments by Annex I parties, as agreed by AWG-KP 6 (FCCC/KP/2008/8).
SOUTH AFRICA said that the markets required “legal, loud and long-term signals” from the AWG-KP, while also suggesting that long commitment periods lead to a lower level of ambition in the short-term.
BELARUS noted significant decoupling of its emissions and economic growth in 1995-2012, and highlighted energy conservation and efficiency improvements, and development of renewable energy sources.
TUVALU presented his proposal to give the Adaptation Fund Board the legal capacity to enter into certain legal agreements.
The EU, JAPAN, AUSTRALIA and CANADA underlined the CDM 92s role in advancing technology transfer to developing countries.
The EU supported this and highlighted that it offers the potential to clean up language in other paragraphs.

BRAZIL said cooperative and  non-Annex I sectoral policies are not related to Annex I commitments and should be deleted.
Chair Stoycheva presented the interim financial performance for the biennium 2002-2003, which notes outstanding arrears of US$ 8.5 million and indicates that two-thirds of member States have not made their contributions for 2003.
KUWAIT proposed a glossary that explains what the various proposals mean.
HONDURAS stressed that the efforts made by developing countries are as important as those of Annex I countries.

The G-77/CHINA called for inclusion of migration, displacement, and planned relocation.
Two \t\ttexts were proposed, one from the EU and the other from the G-77/China.
UGANDA said those supporting its deletion were avoiding commitment.
BRAZIL observed that, although information gaps need to be filled, vulnerability and adaptation assessment are not mandatory in non-Annex I communications, meaning that national communications will not necessarily be the appropriate means to fill this gap.
SWITZERLAND called for discussions on sectoral and programmatic approaches, policy-based commitments and means for implementing, measuring, reporting and, when applicable, verifying actions in developed and developing countries.
In the section on designated operational entities, JAPAN, supported by several Parties, proposed adding references to "enhancements by sinks" in order to reflect the acceptance of afforestation and reforestation under the CDM in the Bonn Agreements.
BRAZIL and INDIA called for careful consideration of assumptions underlying scientific arguments.

The EU, supported by SWITZERLAND, suggested mapping issues being addressed under other bodies to avoid duplication.

The US said that there was benefit to seeking compatible approaches between Annex I and non-Annex I Parties.
 Regarding liaison offices, the US, supported by CANADA, proposed performing periodic visits rather than maintaining liaison offices in New York and Geneva.
Although the deal was accepted by most regional groups, including the G-77/China and the EU, the Umbrella Group (a loose alliance of Annex I Parties that includes Australia, Canada, Japan, New Zealand, and the Russian Federation) did not join the consensus.
Grenada, for AOSIS, called for “breaking the deadlocks in time” for a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol, including ambitious emission reduction targets.
The US cautioned against focusing narrowly on the short term and suggested taking into account infrastructure and subsidies in costing.
After a proposal to delete “other parties in a position to do so” and hesitance about the term “finance gap,” parties deleted the paragraph and inserted slightly amended, agreed language, which notes the lack of funding in the LDC Fund (LDCF), and urges parties “and others” to contribute to “the LDCF and/or the GCF.” With other amendments, parties agreed to the draft conclusions.
PAKISTAN and others said existing brackets in the text do not reflect points of disagreement.
The delegates also accepted an EU proposal to merge paragraphs 10 (deliberations) and 11 (governance).
AUSTRALIA, JAPAN, and CANADA highlighted lack of information on certain gases.

The EU was represented by Denmark, Germany and the Netherlands.
Underlining he could speak to past and present emissions trends, but not to future policies, the US reported emissions have declined since 2005 while its GDP increased.

The Federated States of Micronesia, for AOSIS, stressed the need for more specific information from parties to “chisel down into what the numbers actually mean.”
CANADA urged agreeing on guidelines that can immediately be employed by all parties.
SOUTH AFRICA, supported by CHINA, cautioned against focusing on peripheral areas of convergence and avoiding core issues.
The African Group and India proposed deleting the cluster on plans and strategies, while Australia, the EU, New Zealand and Japan supported retaining it.
The final text includes reference to biodiversity, as supported by the EU, SWITZERLAND, THAILAND and NORWAY, and to sustainable forest management.
SWITZERLAND supported retaining its proposal that: JI may contribute up to 50% to meeting a country’s fulfillment of commitments; JI may begin in 2000; JI can also take place with non-Parties to the Protocol.

The EU said SBI is legally obliged to consider items on its agenda and the UMBRELLA GROUP expressed disappointment that the matter would not be discussed at SBI 28.
On methodological issues, the US and EU stressed keeping the guidelines under review and incorporating additional methodological issues raised by the Kyoto Protocol.

On institutional arrangements, the US, Canada, Japan and others saw no need for new institutional arrangements for adaptation.
The EU, Australia, Norway and Japan supported the continued use of GWPs, and Norway proposed that the IPCC provide additional information on other metrics.
ARGENTINA, for a number of developing countries, said that measures should not constitute a disguised restriction on international trade.
The PHILIPPINES said the current pace of negotiations is "grossly inadequate."
Argentina, for the G-77/CHINA, stressed that certain ideas must be clear in the text, including that developed countries must: minimize the consequences of response measures; cooperate in advancing further understanding of the consequences of response measures; exchange information; and take effective action to reduce negative consequences.
On the possibility of Annex B parties strengthening their QELROs during the second commitment period, the EU indicated willingness to explore the ambition mechanism proposed by the G-77/China.

MEXICO reiterated their full commitment to developing a transparent and inclusive process for COP 16.
He urged parties to look again at how Kyoto Protocol commitments had been watered down after the rules were elaborated, adding that the EU would not risk buying a “pig in a poke,” in other words agree to a second commitment period before elaborating the rules it would be subject to.

The non-paper includes amended text as well as a joint submission by the EU and BRAZIL on non-permanence, and a new version of Appendix E. A number of parties, including CHINA, CANADA and SAUDI ARABIA expressed reluctance to discuss compliance in-depth before reaching consensus on the legal form of the agreement.

BRAZIL underscored the CDM as a means of inducing new and mostly private investment, and suggested that it be project-based and include all countries.

AUSTRALIA said the registry for actions seeking support, as specified under the Copenhagen Accord, should be made operational.

INDIA urged that WG I 92s online journal access be extended to other WGs.
On adaptation, PAKISTAN noted the need to broaden the focus from mitigation toward action on adaptation and vulnerability.

PAPUA NEW GUINEA supported creation of an instrument that works for countries reducing their deforestation rates, protecting existing forest and increasing forest area.

The G-77/CHINA proposed that a plenary of the compliance committee perform the allocation function.
 The US said that prematurely specifying individual policies and measures would prejudice the ongoing consideration measures, and added that little consideration has been given to the full range of policies and measures.
With CHINA, he also opposed establishing a high-level expert group, comprising the UNFCCC Secretariat, ICAO and IMO, to examine options for ensuring that revenues from international aviation and shipping can be used for climate finance.
The RUSSIAN FEDERATION proposed that the Plenary be extended to allow the parties to determine how the SAR should be used in making decisions, particularly regarding the Berlin Mandate and how countries will fulfill their obligations.
Following comments from the US, Germany, France, and the UK, text was modified to reflect that the guidance highlights key components and steps to be used when atmospheric measurements and inverse models are used as inputs to, or for comparison with, the inventory emissions estimates.
In a paragraph on elaboration of policies and measures the US, supported by AUSTRALIA, objected to the inclusion of “a menu approach.” FRANCE qualified a reference to harmonized policies and measures by prefacing the reference with “and/or”.
Also expressing disappointment, VENEZUELA noted the lack of a clear signal from developed countries to respect the principles of the Kyoto Protocol.
US President-elect Barack Obama delivered a video message to the Summit promising that his Administration would “engage vigorously” in the climate change negotiations.
COLOMBIA, on behalf of Chile, Panama, the Dominican Republic and Peru, stressed the need for the existing financial mechanism to be used effectively and for national communications to be strengthened and capacities increased.

During the SBI closing plenary on 9 June, Lesotho, for the LDCs: appealed to Annex II parties to increase their contributions to the LDC Fund (LDCF); stressed that the LDCF is expected to support other elements of the LDC work programme in addition to the preparation and implementation of NAPAs; and expressed disappointment that there is no reference to this in the conclusions.

THAILAND said developing countries cannot be expected to undertake commitments in the near future, given the performance of Annex I Parties.

The PHILIPPINES emphasized the paragraph calling on non-Annex I Parties to follow guidelines and format adopted by COP-2.

  The EU observed that the GCF could promote a paradigm shift towards low-carbon, climate resilient development and that long-term target setting is crucial for investors as well as for a legally-binding instrument in 2015.
Because of the heavy agenda, the UK suggested that the next Panel meeting be extended to four days.
The EU underscored that there is no consensus on building a system, that parties had agreed to look at spillover consequences of response measures, and that anything beyond this scope was a “case of too high expectations.”

AUSTRALIA and the RUSSIAN FEDERATION argued for a non-binding regime and said their countries were more concerned about their own compliance than that of others.
Supported by many, the US proposed explicit \t\treference to the Laxemburg workshop in the Task Group mandate.
 The NETHERLANDS said that the IPCC assessment highlights the need for global emissions to be lowered.
The EU, CANADA, AUSTRALIA and JAPAN, opposed by SLOVENIA, supported one combined session for the sake of efficiency, noting some details need to be clarified.
NEW ZEALAND called for addressing trade measures under the World Trade Organization and suggested addressing unforeseen consequences through diplomatic and development assistance channels.
Maldives, for AOSIS, highlighted the 2018 facilitative dialogue as a key moment in history to bring collective ambition in line with science.
MALAYSIA and ROMANIA supported the topic, rather than question format of the Synthesis Report.
Co-facilitators Georg B c3 b8rsting (Norway) and Artur Runge-Metzger (EU) reported respectively on the finance and capacity building facilitated group sessions that took place on Tuesday, 2 June.
The EIG proposed a conceptual discussion on all finance-related paragraphs without shifting them.
 \t\t\tCHINA noted \t\t\tthat the voluntary targets by the EU and Norway correspond to IPCC \t\t\tanalysis on stabilization levels and urged other Annex I parties to \t\t\tcome up with similar figures.
AUSTRALIA said the CDM should be largely private sector driven.
SWITZERLAND suggested a ef bf bdpost-verification model ef bf bd wherein emission reduction units could not be transferred until they have been certified to be excess Assigned Amount Units.
In his  opening remarks  on Friday, 5 June, AG13 Chair Patrick Sz e9ll (UK) recalled that during AG13-5, delegates agreed that the Multilateral Consultative Process (MCP) should be advisory rather than supervisory in nature.
The EU supported a CDM-type project cycle to ensure environmental credibility at the project level.
Peru, for AILAC, stated the importance of making progress on substantive matters, rather than on procedural matters.
BRAZIL supported developing "a common language."
SOUTH AFRICA recalled the AWG-KP’s mandate and preferred taking up such broader architectural questions relating to both AWGs in informal consultations.
The EU suggested that the objectives of guidelines, structures, the modalities for communications and the detail required in biennial reports could be captured in an annex to a decision.
The G-77/CHINA proposed that Annex I parties take on “at least” a 25-40% goal, and INDIA stressed that lifestyle changes could lead to greater reductions.
The EU said developing draft decision text in Panama is key for a successful outcome in Durban and called for a comprehensive legally-binding framework that engages all parties.
ETHIOPIA announced a new submission clarifying the details of market mechanisms in the 2015 agreement.
The EU stressed the need for continuous cooperation.
Saudi Arabia, for the ARAB GROUP, preferring only procedural conclusions, opposed.
China, for BASIC, urged developed countries to raise their level of ambition in line with science and their historical responsibility, and suggested further discussions on ambition under the COP or CMP.
On the question of who will drive the process, UGANDA underscored the role of governments.
 Samoa, on behalf of AOSIS, expressed disappointment that the COP was unable to agree to words as clear and true as the AOSIS protocol.
AOSIS said avoiding further climate change impacts on SIDS should be a benchmark and suggested an upper limit of no more than 350 ppm may be necessary given recent studies.
Tuvalu, for the LDCs, and Trinidad and Tobago, for CARICOM, proposed a compliance committee with enforcement and facilitative branches.
ef bf bd NEW ZEALAND drew attention \t\tto potential tradeoffs between steepness of emission reductions and \t\ttimeframes for implementation.
NORWAY outlined a legally-binding commitment that recognizes industry structures, is equitable and verifiable, and utilizes fiscal measures.
The AFRICAN GROUP suggested that a long-term goal be ambitious and have a base year and clear mid-term targets.
SBSTA \t\tadopted conclusions on Tuesday night, 6 December, and the EU expressed \t\tdisappointment that it had not been possible to agree to a more \t\tambitious programme.
Saint Lucia, for the Alliance of Small Island States (AOSIS), noted linkages among market use, the compliance system, net benefits and eligibility rules to ensure environmental integrity, and recognized the potential to cluster: purpose of market mechanisms and principles for their use; accounting of market transfers; elaboration of further rules; and consistent use of estimation methodologies, adjustments and common metrics.
The REPUBLIC OF KOREA advocated greater focus on supply-side issues.
SWITZERLAND \t\tsaid the work of the \t\t \t\tAWG is related to ongoing \t\tprocesses under the Convention and the Protocol, and called for a \t\tcomprehensive climate regime.
He requested the Secretariat to "tap" all relevant regional organizations in the world including OPEC and OLADE and emphasized the lack of funding for the participation of developing countries.
Regarding adjustments, CANADA noted the lack of clarity in what an adjustment would be.
The Bahamas, supported by the UK, stressed that the document, negotiated by leaders, was important and that a mechanism needed to be found so that the financial offers could be operationalized.
SWITZERLAND, JAPAN and NEW ZEALAND said modalities of the global stocktake may differ for adaptation, mitigation and MOI.
The US announced that it will partially finance the two outstanding regional workshops for Africa and SIDS.
NEW ZEALAND announced a mid-term target to reduce emissions by 10-20% below 1990 levels by 2020.
The LDCs, the EU and the US, opposed by India, suggested considering South-South cooperation in the 2015 agreement.
He also underscored the EU is a special organization because, while not being a state, states have transferred some sovereign powers to it.
Recognizing the common understanding reached on the strategic role of the technology framework in bringing transformational change, Mexico, for the EIG, commended the work of the TEC and CTCN, including on linkages with the Financial Mechanism.
  JAPAN and CANADA noted linkages between AWG-LCA and SBI discussions on technology transfer.
Japan and the EU \t\tstated that there was an overlap between this agenda item and the SBSTA \t\titem on Protocol Article 2.3 (adverse effects of policies and measures).
The US suggested that it should be clarified on who is required to complete the form.
Micronesia, for AOSIS, proposed a new multi-window mechanism that would include insurance, rehabilitation and compensation, and risk management.
Brazil, for the G-77/China, supported by South Africa, China and Saudi Arabia, expressed concern with the compatibility of proposals on common mitigation frameworks with the Convention and the BAP.
Uganda, for the LDCs, highlighted that developed countries’ responsibility under international law to redress damage caused by climate change formed the basis for public funding from those countries.
Australia, Canada, New Zealand, and the US proposed alternative text listing activities relating to implementation of decision 5/CP.7 to reflect that progress had been made.
JAPAN \t\tunderscored that ocean storage potential varies regionally, and that \t\tJapan has more potential for ocean than geological storage.
ECUADOR proposed to: establish an international court of climate justice; promote the UN declaration on the Rights of Nature as an instrument to protect the Earth and its ecosystems; and mandating finance support to enable MRV and establishing a registry thereof in the 2015 agreement.
AUSTRALIA, the EU and JAPAN called for evidence of consequences, while the G-77/CHINA and others voiced concern with this proposal.
Australia, for the Umbrella Group, supported limiting global average temperature increase to 2°C and a 50% reduction in global emissions by 2050.
Mali, for the African Group, and Venezuela, for ALBA, stressed the importance of enhancing the Secretariat’s resources given pre-2020 work and preparations for the Paris Agreement’s implementation.
On the inclusion of definitions and modalities in the Annex to the draft decision as it relates to LULUCF, JAPAN, with CANADA, COLOMBIA, AUSTRALIA and CHILE, proposed a number of references to the enhancement by sources and removals by sinks.
The US called for clarifying the policy/methodology distinction, while COLOMBIA and others said the two are interrelated.
BOLIVIA and VENEZUELA supported the proposal made on Monday evening by China, for the LMDCs, which, inter alia, calls for reorganizing the decision text in the Tool in a “logical” order: transparency of mitigation action; transparency of adaptation action; generally ensuring MRV of support; reporting of support; verification of support; and information on support provided and received.
PAPUA NEW GUINEA stated that “key ideas” had been omitted in the consolidation and, with AUSTRALIA, highlighted that if the outcome was a treaty text, it would require different specificity than a COP decision.
URUGUAY and ARGENTINA underscored non-carbon dioxide emissions and lack of mitigation options in the agricultural sector.
NEW ZEALAND questioned whether this would increase the level of ambition.
The PHILIPPINES proposed establishing a contact group to draft a COP decision.
SAMOA suggested any source the compliance body deemed appropriate, while IRAN said Parties should be the only source.
On confidentiality, the EU introduced new text that provides, inter alia, that the ERTs shall guarantee the confidentiality of information that a Party indicates is confidential, and that if a Party does not provide sufficient information for the assessment of its conformity with the revised IPCC guidelines, the ERT shall assume the estimate was not prepared accordingly.
AUSTRIA is committed to the Toronto Target as a national target and will increase efforts in the face of evidence it may not reach the target.
With AOSIS, he endorsed: holding ministerial discussions on pre-2020 mitigation ambition at the pre-COP and in Doha; and establishing contact groups on the two workstreams, emphasizing different timescales for deliverables.
Micronesia said that COP-1 should set targets beyond 2000 and urged all Parties to give the AOSIS protocol full consideration and support.
INDIA called for outcomes that strengthen the BAP and do not dilute the Convention’s principles and provisions.
 \t\tOn preparations, AOSIS, the EU, CANADA, TANZANIA and NEW ZEALAND \t\tsupported coordination with other processes, including the AWG.
The EU welcomed the initiation of a step-by-step approach to enhancing local communities’ and indigenous peoples’ participation in the UNFCCC.
ECUADOR emphasized the need for fair compensation, just transition of the workforce and support for economic diversification, as well as establishment of a permanent forum.
On future meetings, AOSIS emphasized the value of regional workshops and the need for coordination of FCCC workshops and meetings.
SRI LANKA said a reference to low and high economic growth estimates should preface projections of temperature change and sea level rise.
Bolivia, for the G-77/CHINA, noted the important work of the Adaptation Fund.
It also decides that the GEF should continue to provide and enhance support for the implementation of adaptation activities, including the implementation of National Adaptation Programmes of Action (NAPAs), through the LDC Fund and the SCCF.
BRAZIL underscored the need to ensure assessment mechanisms do not become a barrier to technology transfer themselves.
The G-77/CHINA said the whole of Protocol Article 2 - including provision for minimizing adverse effects - should be referred to in the decision.
The US said the differentiation in assigned amounts in the Protocol allows for differences in national circumstances.
China also questioned \t\t\tlanguage in a statement indicating that “approaches that do not \t\t\tinclude a larger share of global emissions will have higher global \t\t\tcosts” and proposed changing “larger share of global emissions” to \t\t\t“wider participation.” The US \t\t\tquestioned the meaning of “wider participation” and Brazil opposed \t\t\tthe language as policy prescriptive and prejudging future agreement \t\t\tsince also “deeper cuts” would reduce emissions.
The EU said they could increase their target from 20% to a 30% reduction from 1990 levels by 2020 if other countries take on comparable targets.
With CHILE, he proposed an interim phase of the CDM.
The US emphasized the overriding importance of the IPCC 92s \t\tcredibility in assessment, arguing that a separation of function could \t\tnot be maintained if the IPCC engaged in a joint, interactive process of \t\tscenario development with the climate modeling community.
NEW ZEALAND highlighted the importance of quantifying developing country actions for attracting support and for mutual accountability.
CANADA called for cross-reference to paragraph 5 (mandate of the Committee) and avoid use of language that expands or confuses the mandate of Committee.
On the draft decision text on Article 5.2 for COP-6 and that for COP/MOP-1, SAUDI ARABIA, supported by TUVALU, PERU, CHINA and BRAZIL, and opposed by the US and NEW ZEALAND, suggested deleting references to activities under Protocol Article 3.3 and 3.4 at this stage, as outstanding issues are being considered in the LULUCF group.
EGYPT, with VENEZUELA and BOLIVIA, proposed preparing a table with the attribution of paragraphs in the consolidated text, which will be made available to parties before the next meeting on Tuesday.
Stating his dissatisfaction with the report by the Secretariat (FCCC/SBI/2017/INF.4), SAUDI ARABIA suggested the contact group under the sub-item on the programme budget for the biennium 2018-2019 discuss it.
This paragraph was eventually \t\t\taccepted, as amended by the EU, with further minor amendments by the \t\t\tG-77/CHINA.
The EU noted the need to include indicators such as emissions per capita or emissions per unit of output.
The EU said the G-77/China draft programme lacked, inter alia, a clear timeline, deadlines and allocation of work to different bodies.
The EU, AOSIS and GHANA underscored the importance of the Special Climate Change Fund, especially to countries not eligible for support under existing funds.
SAUDI ARABIA, SWITZERLAND, GREENPEACE and others expressed reservations about the proposed timing for deliberation on some issues, noting the relevance of the Special Report.
CHINA said industrialized countries need to make “space” for developing countries to develop.
Egypt, for the LMDCs, and INDONESIA emphasized that a capacity-building mechanism should be based on experience sharing, lessons learned and best practices.
The EU, US, AUSTRALIA and AOSIS expressed disappointment over the lack of agreement and proposed that the draft conclusions include paragraphs on which there was some agreement.
BRAZIL suggested that the data invited from parties address two things: the impact of proposed accounting methods for forest management (such as the bar approach) on potential numbers, given that existing historical data may not be relevant to the forecast nature of the exercise; and how factoring out anthropogenic from non-anthropogenic effects would be addressed.
SWITZERLAND suggested the co-chairs develop terms of reference for the informal discussions.
During the closing SBI plenary, the Philippines, for the G-77/China, expressed disappointment that the benefits of the NEEDS for Climate Change Project could not be extended.
The G-77/CHINA urged discussion of the contact group Co-Chairs\' draft, with CHINA opposing the use of other documents.
Brazil, AOSIS and others opposed fundamental changes to the existing architecture, while Australia and Canada suggested that improvements could be made.

The EU noted that its member states are undertaking significant reductions and proposed that SBI conclusions take note of the report (FCCC/SBI/2009/12).
The RUSSIAN FEDERATION proposed specifically addressing the “mandate” of an MCP at future meetings.

On the update of a paper compiling pledges (FCCC/KP/AWG/2010/INF.1), SOUTH AFRICA, supported by the EU, NORWAY, BOLIVIA, the FEDERATED STATES OF MICRONESIA and the GAMBIA, proposed taking into consideration the information considered at this session, in particular the tables prepared by the Secretariat, showing the translation of current pledges into QELROs.
South Africa, for the G-77/CHINA, supported the general approach but said she needed more time to coordinate.
Switzerland, on behalf of the EIG, said a future agreement must be legally-binding, have global application, recognize differentiation and contain comparable and transparent targets.

 INDIA said the IPCC should continue to synthesize science and technical research, not stray into policy measures or national technologies.
