The EU described the Dialogue as the “first global stocktake” and a credibility test of the Paris Agreement’s ambition cycle.
CHILE called for a “single working method” and supported giving the AWG-LCA Chair a mandate to work towards further consolidating the text so that it could be used as a basis for negotiations.
The US emphasized that JI differs from CDM, as it does not share the goal of promoting sustainable development.

VENEZUELA expressed concern that parties are heading toward a “mitigation and market agreement” that will unfairly benefit developed countries.
COLOMBIA called for a flexible framework.
CHINA and many others noted an interest in a land-based approach, but not for the second commitment period.

The EU and a group of Annex I Parties, including Australia, Canada, Iceland, New Zealand, Norway, the Russian Federation and the US ("Umbrella Group") distributed draft decisions and discussion documents.
China, India and Singapore, opposed by the US, suggested that India’s proposal relating to prohibiting unilateral trade measures against exports from developing countries should also be included in the preambular part of the shared vision section.
The EU proposed that all parties individually and collectively mobilize climate finance with developed country leadership.
CHINA said a shared vision does not necessarily mean concrete targets or numerical goals, but is a statement of long-terms objectives, goals and means.
Germany said the EU would build a coalition of like-minded countries willing to commit themselves to timetables and targets for increasing renewable energy use.
The US, opposed by CHINA, AOSIS and PERU, supported a decision on Article 3.3 and 3.4 as a package at COP-6, arguing that this is critical for the success of the Protocol.
SOUTH AFRICA urged: identifying new opportunities to raise ambition; closing the pre-2020 ambition gap; and securing a direct link between ambition and support.
BOLIVIA noted that it is still developing its position on matters relating to privileges and immunities.
BOLIVIA suggested establishing a “climate resilience and sustainable development mechanism.” KIRIBATI suggested recognizing the need for a special mechanism to fast-track action to assist the most vulnerable countries.
Democratic Republic of the Congo, for the AFRICAN GROUP, stressed the importance of national communications.
BOLIVIA opposed market-based approaches to climate finance.
 Algeria, for the G-77/CHINA, suggested the following benchmarks for a successful outcome in Doha: an ambitious second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol effective as of 1 January 2013; ambitious QELROs by Annex I parties; limited access to flexibility mechanisms by Annex I parties that have not adopted commitments for the second commitment period; and addressing carry-over of surplus AAUs.
FINLAND said the GEF is not the only funding channel, and stressed the availability of bilateral and private sector funds.
The G-77/CHINA, supported by COLOMBIA, INDIA and URAGUAY, noted the need to better distinguish between AIJ projects and those jointly implemented by Annex I countries.
NIGERIA emphasized access to information technology, including telecommunications.
Maldives, for AOSIS, and SOUTH AFRICA lamented that the procedures of accreditation remain too complex.
CANADA, with the US and JAPAN, emphasized that the Copenhagen workshop on P&amp;Ms fulfilled relevant BAPA requirements.
The EU said compliance “means more than just penalties” and that it encompasses facilitating better implementation of parties’ commitments.
 The US proposed that Annex II Parties separately provide information “in accordance with” or “on” each of their commitments under Articles 4.3-4.5, rather than “to fulfill” their commitments.
The UNITED ARAB EMIRATES (UAE) said the consolidated text by the ADP Co-Chairs should: retain all options; not change positions; and serve as the basis for negotiations during the next ADP session.
The EU noted that adaptation projects are limited in scope and scale, and that adaptation measures should be integrated into national, regional and local planning.
MEXICO supported working in a “friends of the chair” format, provided the group discusses only political issues.
ARGENTINA, supported by the G-77/CHINA and others, said that adaptation projects are of global benefit and should be given the highest priority under the SCCF.
BARBADOS said data gathering should not be used as an excuse to avoid instituting an insurance system, with TUVALU cautioning against an “endless assessment process.” The GAMBIA cautioned against maladaptation due to lack of planning, and AUSTRALIA noted potential disincentives for risk reduction resulting from insurance.
The note proposes that the Executive Board comprise equal numbers from each UN regional group, plus one representative from the SIDS.
Opening the discussions on Monday, WG II Co-Chair Christopher Field (US) gave an overview of the proposed outline, noting that it builds on the structure of the AR4 and is organized into two parts: Part A on Global and sectoral aspects and Part B on Regional aspects.
CANADA called for a concise outcome that includes objectives, delineation of national and international cooperative action, and institutional and financing arrangements, as key elements.
The EU stressed the importance of science in guiding the negotiating process.
Malaysia, for the G-77/China, \t\tunderscored the importance of meeting the needs identified in the \t\ttechnological needs assessments (TNAs), and asked for a full review of \t\timplementation of COP decisions related to technology transfer since COP \t\t1.
Venezuela, for the BOLIVARIAN ALLIANCE FOR THE PEOPLES OF OUR AMERICA (ALBA), said the Paris Agreement and its implementation should be governed by the principles and objectives of the Convention, urging not to reframe CBDR-RC.
The PHILIPPINES, with BOLIVIA, VENEZUELA and others, requested retaining reference to the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples to reflect collective rights.
ARGENTINA emphasized the need to centralize all available information in a forum.
NORWAY suggested that TEMs focus not only on adaptation, but also on health and sustainable development co-benefits.
The PHILIPPINES expressed concern that discussions still revolved around assessing needs and suggested renewing the discussions from COP-1 to establish an intergovernmental advisory panel on technology with equitable geographic representation.
During discussion, BOLIVIA highlighted the joint mitigation and adaptation approach with ex ante finance.
 The EU supported a protocol to build on FCCC commitments and objectives and give the Berlin Mandate quantified targets and timetables.
With the EU, he called for the operationalization of the Paris Committee on Capacity-building (PCCB) at COP 22.
CHINA said reduction objectives and policies and measures are integrated, with policies and measures as means to achieve targets.
An open-ended break-out group chaired by Andreas Fischlin (Switzerland) worked on the data reporting format based on proposals by the EU, Australia and the US.
Costa Rica, for AILAC, said the beginning of the PCCB’s work is a “step in the right direction” and stressed the importance of establishing a public registry for NDCs.
The UK supported holding joint expert meetings and the appointment of “bridge authors” for dealing with cross-cutting topics among WGs but, with Chair Pachauri and Stocker, he noted the logistical difficulties of scheduling back-to-back meetings.
Ghana, for the African Group, and Switzerland emphasized the need to consider the most vulnerable countries, particularly Africa, the LDCs and small island developing states (SIDS).
The US urged further discussion of long-term emission pathways and MRV.
The European Union (EU) underscored that the outcome from Katowice must be in line with the spirit and letter of the Paris Agreement, taking into account national capacities and circumstances and ensuring the highest possible ambition over time.
BRAZIL, supported by CHINA, said preparing new texts and focusing subsequent discussions on how to take them forward created the impression that text negotiated by parties would not form the basis of further work.
The US welcomed the list of priority questions as helpful to focus discussions on the issues listed in the Chair’s scenario note, but said some questions are missing from the list.
On the Adaptation Fund, the AFRICAN GROUP underlined that he could not accept the current text.
BRAZIL enquired about ways to \t\tdiscourage incentives for dispute claims.
The PHILIPPINES supported a learning-by-doing approach and information exchange, and asked developed countries to communicate their experiences in, inter alia: integrating adaptation into national development planning and the budgetary implications of doing so.
SWITZERLAND highlighted the need for agreement on the overall framework, including greenhouse gases and flexibility mechanisms.
On appeal, the EU, SAMOA and the FEDERATED STATES OF MICRONESIA doubted the necessity of an appeal, as it would delay the process and merely afford Parties the opportunity to have their case heard twice.
Egypt, for the ARAB GROUP, said success in Durban depends on achieving balanced results based on the Convention’s principles, including common but differentiated responsibilities.
SAUDI ARABIA noted market distortions, and said tax made up 80% of the final price of oil in some OECD countries.

On the CDM, the EU explained that demand for projects and emission reduction credits will continue in Europe, regardless of adoption of a second commitment period.
NEW ZEALAND supported raising the issue of flexibility as each element of the guidelines is addressed.
IRAN, supported by EGYPT, requested that the Secretariat make an attributed version of the new text available, while VENEZUELA and COLOMBIA opposed.
The US favored a target based on all GHGs, sources, and sinks, flexibility, and meaningful participation of key developing countries.
The PHILIPPINES, supported by EL SALVADOR, underscored technology transfer, capacity building, and analysis of social impacts in AIJ projects and called for transparency in reporting.
NEW ZEALAND highlighted an option that would provide parties with flexibility to establish commitments either as QELROs or as absolute emission reductions.
BRAZIL cautioned against clustering accounting and market issues, suggesting accounting relates to transparency and compliance.
The G-77/CHINA and South Africa, for the AFRICAN GROUP, reiterated that a shared vision should be aspirational and inspirational, based on the principles and implementation of the Convention, and should treat all building blocks equally.
On the form of the outcome, the Cook Islands, for AOSIS, preferred a COP decision rather than SBI conclusions.
The US, with Canada and the EU said the proposal addressed issues currently under consideration in other negotiating groups, such as discussions on Stage III adaptation, and cautioned against moving beyond other related negotiations.
SWITZERLAND supported using performance indicators to monitor progress of implementation.
Bulgaria said accounting for trading in projections was a problem for EIT countries, given the lack of information on the willingness of countries to engage in JI projects, and the resulting impact on emissions in EIT countries.
The US clarified that their proposed climate technology hub is designed to enhance technology transfer and the Convention’s implementation.
Brazil, for the G-77/China, called for full implementation of the CGE work programme, expressing concern over the lack of funding for regional workshops.
Chair Thorgeirsson said a contact group would be convened on the issue, co-chaired by David Warrilow (UK) and Rawleston Moore (Barbados).
Australia, for the UMBRELLA GROUP, expressed openness to the Presiding Officers undertaking intersessional work as needed.
Sudan, for the G-77/China, expressed concern over slow progress under the AWG-KP, lamenting delay in adopting conclusions on Annex I parties’ aggregate and individual emission reductions.
TANZANIA said social safeguards should reflect the right to sustainable development in forest and rural communities.
Responding to concerns expressed by INDIA and CHINA about the “imbalance” of technology compared to other elements in the draft agreement, Co-Facilitator Mpanu-Mpanu said it maybe because the ADP Co-Chairs were “overly cautious.”
Highlighting the vulnerability of LDCs, Tanzania, for the LDCs, stressed the need for entry into force of the Protocol and constructive work on matters relating to technology transfer, capacity building and LDCs.
The US and European Business Councils For Sustainable Energy supported a fast track for CDM projects, early crediting, full transferability of CERs, and a binding compliance regime.
AOSIS, with CHINA, Bangladesh, for the LDCs, and AILAC, called for annual high-level engagement.
SOUTH AFRICA recognized the usefulness of market mechanisms, while emphasizing supplementarity.
Switzerland, for the Environmental Integrity Group, stated a possible outcome should reflect the elements of the BAP.
 The Chair attempted to give the floor to an environmental NGO representative, but SAUDI ARABIA objected that this issue was between Parties.
Algeria, for the AFRICAN GROUP, urged Annex I countries to adopt ambitious targets.
Micronesia, supported by the US, highlighted the value of initiatives outside the UNFCCC, such as those focused on HFCs, black carbon, methane and ground-level ozone.
The G-77/CHINA stressed that existing institutions had failed as a finance delivery system, objected to co-financing and said that the architecture should be concentrated in “one house.” The AFRICAN GROUP underscored that financial mechanisms must be subject to MRV.
The Cook Islands, for AOSIS, suggested that Bolivia raise the matter in the COP/MOP plenary.
Delegates also had before them written comments submitted by Gambia, the EU and the US (FCCC/SBI/1966/Misc.1).
The US and the EU proposed listing a menu of activities, noting that different countries have different concerns.
  The 18th Brazil, India, South Africa and China (BASIC) Ministerial Meeting took place from 7-8 August 2014, in New Delhi, India, and concluded with the adoption of a joint statement emphasizing the need to finalize the elements of a draft negotiating text for the 2015 agreement at COP 20.
The EU anticipated a Bali roadmap \t\tconsisting of agreement by all parties to engage in a comprehensive \t\tnegotiating process leading to a global post-2012 agreement by 2009, \t\twith a twin-track including Convention and Protocol elements.
BELGIUM said producing the Synthesis Report by COP-13 need not compromise quality, and opposed postponing delivery.
In the discussion, the REPUBLIC OF KOREA supported expanding the scope of the CDM to attract eco-friendly investment and technology.
The EU stressed that non-permanence reversals require compensation, while Tuvalu suggested that current rules may be functioning and the lack of projects may reflect unwillingness of credit purchasers to bear the risk of reversals.

Brazil, for the G-77/CHINA, stressed that any consideration of further implementation of Convention Article 12.5 should take into account common but differentiated responsibilities and that national communications requirements should not be more onerous for non-Annex I parties than for Annex I parties.

Switzerland, for the EIG, warned that attempting to change the balanced Durban package will put Doha at risk.
JAPAN called for clear SCCF guidelines and for consideration of LDC Fund experiences.
 SWITZERLAND suggested deleting "state-of-the-art" in paragraph XII as it was not part of the language agreed to at COP 1 and replacing "address" with "mitigating and adapting to" in the last line.
BRAZIL highlighted problems with GWPs, and NEW ZEALAND said they would be open to considering other methods.
CHILE, CHINA, the EU, SWITZERLAND and SLOVENIA supported a standing body with a stable and fixed basis.
The DOMINICAN REPUBLIC proposed channeling support from developed countries to advance policies and regulations on climate change.
SENEGAL, supported by BRAZIL, INDIA and the GAMBIA, highlighted the proven additionality of small-scale renewable technology and supported the development of positive lists.
COLOMBIA supported a mechanism to increase ambition through periodic presentation of commitments starting in 2021.
Parties diverged on, inter alia: referring to progress towards the US$100 billion goal; and whether to give guidance to the incoming COP Presidency on the topic of the next high-level ministerial dialogue.
 Yemen, for the G-77/CHINA, identified the need to respect the balance between the two negotiating tracks and emphasized that the outcome should not compromise or prejudge the overall objective of reaching a comprehensive, fair, ambitious and legally-binding outcome in the future.
The EU noted that the TOR only called for starting consideration of modalities at SB-17.
ETHIOPIA reported on the work by the UN Secretary-General’s High-level Advisory Group on Climate Change Financing, describing efforts to identify financing sources and informing delegates that the aim was to report the outcomes by November 2010.
SINGAPORE and several other AOSIS members stated that the AWG-LCA’s outcome must be a global and comprehensive legally-binding agreement that is complementary to the Kyoto Protocol.
Tanzania, for the LDCs, stressed the need for expedited procedures for the approval of NAPAs.
NORWAY \t\tstressed challenges in the transport sector and, with the EU, \t\thighlighted the co-benefits of mitigation measures.
INDIA stressed that there should be no review of adequacy of developing country actions.
CANADA and AUSTRALIA questioned the need for extra informal consultations on the issue.
The G-77/CHINA expressed preference for keeping provisions on the means of implementation in the relevant substantive chapters rather than in the finance chapter.
On  , the G-77/China, with the African Group and AOSIS, emphasized long-term financing that is new and additional to ODA.
On the number and length of commitment periods, the G-77/CHINA and AOSIS supported a single commitment period of 5 years, AUSTRALIA supported one commitment period of 5 or 8 years and the EU proposed one commitment period of 8 years.
The G-77/CHINA \t\tsaid the initiatives should be considered as background information.
BOLIVIA said carbon markets are not the only solution.
NORWAY, with NEW ZEALAND, called for revisiting previous TEM topics and adding sessions on carbon pricing and removal of fossil fuel subsidies.
JAPAN called for extracting elements of the Copenhagen Accord for a balanced set of decisions.
She announced that AILAC and the Caribbean Community (CARICOM) will be submitting a paper on how the Talanoa Dialogue can help realize more ambitious NDCs.
The following countries were assessed: Belarus, Canada, Cyprus, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Japan, Kazakhstan, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Monaco, Portugal, Romania, the Russian Federation, Slovenia, Spain and the US.
In discussions, a number of parties welcomed the Secretariat’s technical paper and Norway, Switzerland and the EU said it would be useful to have an analogous paper on developing country pledges.
The RUSSIAN FEDERATION said that text on mitigation, adaptation and MRV presented problems for his delegation and that the current text does not meet the expectations of countries with economies in transition.
Several developing country Parties and the EU called for sufficient time to consider the report.
The GAMBIA \t\tstressed the importance of a feedback mechanism to continuously review \t\tthe clearing house.
ANTIGUA and BARBUDA pointed out that the group does not have a mandate to discuss amendments to the Convention or the Protocol.
The MARSHALL ISLANDS said a discussion on legal options cannot take place without hearing views on “how we would actually get there,” and stressed flexibility to allow for scaling up of ambition over time.
Bolivia, for the Bolivarian Alliance for the Peoples of Our America (ALBA), identified Cancun as a step back for the AWG-KP and called for agreement on a second commitment period in Durban.
The Philippines, for the G-77/China, proposed adding in the conclusions that the SBI notes the deep concerns raised by several developing countries in accessing the necessary financial resources to fulfill their obligations under the Convention.
With AUSTRALIA, he underscored that unpacking some of the concepts in the section on time frames would be valuable.
AUSTRALIA underlined that some paragraphs in Part 1 had not yet been discussed, but may attract broad agreement.
On the role of the Executive Board in approving new methodologies and guidelines related to baselines, monitoring plans and project boundaries, CHINA, supported by BRAZIL and SAUDI ARABIA, proposed additional text suggesting the Board should review rather than approve new methodologies and guidelines, and should recommend these to the COP/MOP for approval.
 \t\tSwitzerland, for the Environmental Integrity Group, highlighted the \t\tIPCC 92s Fourth Assessment Report (AR4) and called for urgent action.
IPCC Vice-Chair Barrett suggested putting the Principle 10(b) text in a footnote, which was supported by the Netherlands, the Russian Federation, France, the US, Ireland, Algeria, and Norway.
El Salvador, for the CENTRAL AMERICAN INTEGRATION SYSTEM (SICA), emphasized the need to operationalize the GCF in Durban.
On the assessment of the impacts of response measures, ZIMBABWE said this would depend on the availability of information on policies and measures.
Cape Verde, for AOSIS, identified Durban as an important milestone on the eve of the expiration of the first commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol and in the wake of the new commitments agreed in Cancun.
The EU stressed the need for a decision addressing INDCs, in particular upfront information to be included, and the pre-COP 21 process to consider and analyze them.
The Philippines, for the G-77/China, underscored that the fourth review should be a full review of the financial mechanism and not just a review of the operating entity.
Responding to a call by Bahamas, for AOSIS, to hold workshops to improve direct access capacity, AFB Chair Khan explained that the mandate of the Fund is to finance in-country adaptation projects rather than capacity building.
The G-77/China, opposed by the US, New Zealand and Australia, suggested differentiating between Annex I and non-Annex I Parties.
JAPAN, with MEXICO, requested that boundaries be defined for spillover effects, and AUSTRALIA suggested that these could relate to programmes and measures taken by parties in relation to obligations.
On developed country mitigation, the US requested bracketing numbers referring to aggregate range of emission reductions, and for inserting a bracketed option “x” and a footnote explaining that “x is equal to the sum of the reductions by parties.” The US stressed the need for a structure that is “very different” from the Kyoto Protocol, based on a bottom-up structure and actions implemented domestically.
Egypt, on behalf of the ARAB GROUP, highlighted Doha as a turning point in regional efforts to address climate change.
AUSTRALIA and the US supported a stock taking exercise to review available information, including from recent workshops.
Lesotho, for the LDCs, highlighted the importance of the NWP and research and systematic observation, and called for increased attention to the LDC work programme.
CANADA said legally-binding consequences were also justified on competitiveness grounds.
 \t\tOn a sentence explaining why the 93reasons \t\tfor concern 94 are assessed to be stronger than in the TAR, the US called \t\tfor removing 93especially 94 when referring to especially vulnerable \t\tsystems, sectors and regions, noting that the word was not clearly \t\tdefined nor was it fully addressed by WGII.
OPEC reminded delegates of the need to minimize the adverse effects of policies and measures to address climate change and said that adequate provision should be made for the transfer of technology to developing countries.
The EU, SOUTH AFRICA and AUSTRALIA stressed the quantifiability of NDCs.
SAUDI ARABIA highlighted the need, inter alia, to: ensure a comprehensive approach to policies and measures; enhance the research, development and use of fossil fuel sequestration technologies; remove market distortions in the energy sector; encourage the diversification of energy sources; and explicitly refer to compensation.
The UMBRELLA GROUP supported having agriculture as a separate item.
Australia, for the UMBRELLA GROUP, stressed that this session should focus on progressing arrangements under cooperative approaches and further discussing response measures.
IRAN, ALGERIA and BURKINA FASO encouraged establishing links with capacity building and UNFCCC Article 6.
BOLIVIA said that countries, rather than the COP, should decide on which carbon "pools" to include in A&amp;R projects, and that it was important to include geo-referencing in the draft decision.
The CG-11 urged Parties not to reopen or reinterpret the Bonn Agreements.
AUSTRALIA suggested introducing text ensuring definitional and accounting consistencies between first and subsequent commitment periods.
SOUTH AFRICA opposed the "dumping" of unwanted technology by developed countries in developing countries.
On support, the G-77/CHINA lamented a lack of adequate reassurances on MOI.
  On a new non-paper, presented by Facilitator Mukahanana-Sangarwe, Brazil, for the G-77/CHINA, suggested that the cluster on plans and strategies should be moved to the end of the text and opposed including paragraphs referring to, inter alia, targets.
PALAU urged for transfer of locally appropriate technologies and best practices, and disseminating information to local communities.
AUSTRALIA, in outlining its vision for a compliance system, said the compliance process would be initiated through the Article 8 (review of information) expert review process.
On emission reductions, SOUTH AFRICA highlighted the need to reflect specific criteria for determining Annex I emission reductions.
 Thailand, for the G-77/CHINA, emphasized that adaptation, including mitigation co-benefits, continues to be the key priority for developing countries.
SAUDI ARABIA, \t\topposed by SLOVENIA and RUSSIA, was not supportive of the reference in \t\tthe text to nuclear power as a mitigation option.
CHINA referred to multiple windows for financing through specialized funds under the guidance of, and fully accountable to, the COP.
Switzerland, for the Environmental Integrity Group, highlighted linkages between the AWGs and the need for cooperation.
 In paragraph X, on the analysis of environmental and socio-economic effects, SPAIN, on behalf of the EU, proposed replacing "environmental and socio-economic" with "aggregated."
CANADA identified convergence around certain ideas, including that developed countries must take the lead through mid-term emission reductions, and called for a “holistic view” on the comparability of efforts, taking into account a range of mitigation actions.
In a paragraph concerning the impact of Annex I commitments on developing countries, SAUDI ARABIA, supported by KUWAIT, added references to burden sharing for all Parties and relevant studies.
SRI LANKA highlighted the differences between the mechanisms and suggested that there be different registries.
The US, with CANADA and the EU, \t\tproposed that non-Annex I Parties should also be allowed to submit \t\tinformation if they wish to do so.
Switzerland, the US, Ireland and others felt that a proposed additional clause specifying that e2 80 9ca decrease of 0.1 in the pH of ocean surface water since the beginning of the industrial era corresponds to a 26% increase in hydrogen ion concentration e2 80 9d was too technical.
The US noted that capacity building represents a shared activity that is not an end in itself, but rather a means to achieve results.
Argentina, for the G-77/China, Bangladesh, for the LDCs, and others noted the need to strengthen and intensify the means of implementation for adaptation.
Responding to a question by AUSTRALIA on drivers of the increase in Italy e2 80 99s photovoltaic power generation capacity to 18 gigawatts, ITALY mentioned the use of quota and feed-in tariff systems, saying the latter is being adjusted to ensure excessive incentives are not given to mature technologies.
GUYANA, CHINA and others emphasized that the Protocol must continue into the second commitment period.
Participants agreed to integrate the Chinese and EU proposals into the draft text.
CHINA opposed the proposals, noting historical responsibility and the clear distinction between mitigation by developed and developing countries, also reflected in sub-paragraphs 1(b)(i) and 1(b)(ii) of the BAP.
The EU welcomed provisions in the Kyoto Protocol for a review at MOP-2 and for initiating consideration of second period commitments.
As the incoming Presidency, SOUTH AFRICA announced consultations on Saturday on the Durban outcome.
Tuvalu, supported by Saudi Arabia, AILAC and others, suggested adding a new paragraph, after clarifying that the ADP has finished its mandate, which decides to establish the Ad Hoc Working Group on the Paris Outcome.
SAUDI ARABIA and NORWAY cautioned against delaying necessary decisions on the CDM.
Bolivia noted the absence of his proposals in the text, referring to the text as “Copenhagen +.” The Gambia expressed concern that long-term finance and references to LDCs and SIDS were not reflected in the text.
  Discussions under these items focused on requests to the Adaptation Committee regarding the nature and substance of its reporting and workplan, and on various issues of importance to LDCs, including financial support, capacity building, and the LDC Expert Group.
SUDAN suggested continuation of discussions in drafting groups.
Australia, for the UMBRELLA GROUP, noted the importance of improving cooperation with observer organizations.
The US underscored their confidence in allowing the Chair to facilitate negotiations by bringing all documents from Copenhagen together.
AOSIS expressed willingness to move forward on the issue, but \t\temphasized that a dialogue on issues related to the second and \t\tsubsequent commitment periods must consider wider matters.
COLOMBIA, on behalf of Peru and Guatemala, proposed that representatives of the COP, possibly through the Standing Committee and the GCF Board work on drafting the arrangements to complete work by COP 19.
Responding to a question on policies for heavy industries, he highlighted their inclusion in the EU ETS and fluorocarbon regulation.
The G-77/CHINA, opposed by the US and JAPAN, suggested that the \t\tgroup draft a COP decision.
The EU, opposed by SAUDI ARABIA, said that, although enhanced action on financial resources and investment involved net transfer to developing countries, this did not preclude developing countries from acting themselves.
After further comments \t\tfrom CHILE, NEW ZEALAND and GERMANY regarding clarification of the \t\tprocess and time scale of equilibration, delegates agreed to the \t\toriginal version of the draft text, which states that this carbon \t\tdioxide would 93eventually equilibrate with the carbon dioxide in the \t\tatmosphere.
The US cited compromises made on fast-start finance and a finance target for 2020, emphasizing that no further decisions are required for the AWG-LCA to complete its work on this issue.
On factoring out, BRAZIL, for the G-77/China, supported by the EU, said this reflected principles agreed in the Marrakesh Accords and needs to be addressed before the second commitment period.
The EU, supported by Japan and Norway, expressed \t\tconcerns over the heavy agenda and overlap with a SBSTA item on Protocol \t\tArticle 2.3 (see following section, below).
The US underscored the importance of good quality reports and questioned the delay in submission of Annex I inventories.
Opposed by the EU and the US, MEXICO, with BANGLADESH, supported conducting, and offered to host, regional and sub-regional TEMs, with BRAZIL willing to explore this idea.
FRANCE suggested an ultimate per capita reduction in C02 compatible with convergence at a global reduction of 7 percent by 2010.
NORWAY said the Indigenous and Tribal Peoples’ Convention (ILO Convention No.
INDIA and SAUDI ARABIA observed that the item had been deleted because there was no consensus on further discussion.
PANAMA, for the CfRN, noted REDD+ is a central element of the 2015 agreement, and called for bridging the Warsaw Framework for REDD+ and the GCF logic framework.
NORWAY proposed maximizing and incentivizing ambitious mitigation actions, including through payments based on verified results.
The EU said national mitigation plans and adaptation policies should have a technology component and that the institutional structure should be effective, flexible and innovative.
The EU, US, Canada, Australia and New Zealand highlighted progress made, including the GEF 92s third replenishment, the establishment of the LDC Fund, and development of guidelines for National Adaptation Programmes of Action (NAPAs).
On the first section of the draft text, the G-77/ CHINA opposed text qualifying the assessment and evaluation of action related to adaptation.
The G-77/CHINA said any consideration of the LULUCF process should begin after the release of the IPCC Special Report.
She noted a workshop in the UK on regional climate variation and human activities.
The EU stressed its ongoing efforts to encourage progress and a willingness and openness to discuss further relevant issues outside this meeting.
The US supported creating a process with: biennial national reports; compilation of reports; an expert review; a report by the expert review team; international assessment of the expert review team’s report in a facilitative manner under the SBI with written questions and answers; and final compilation into a summary report by the Secretariat.
CARICOM pointed to the e2 80 9cpoor track record e2 80 9d of mid-term reviews under the Convention.
CHINA stated that many differences of opinion are due to misinformation and an MCP could allow Parties to exchange views on interpretation.
CHINA and KUWAIT said it is premature to draw conclusions.
NEW ZEALAND proposed inserting alternative language in the preamble, recalling the definition of supplementarity in decision 2/CMP.1 (principles, nature and scope of the flexibility mechanisms).
The US underscored new announcements on its emissions reduction target in the range of 17% below 2005 levels by 2020, with a trajectory to 42% reduction by 2030 to meet the goal of 83% by 2050.
Barbados, for AOSIS, called for keeping the text’s structure consistent with the BAP and suggested moving proposals relating to the text’s structure to a separate document.
BRAZIL favored the reference as the GEF was the FCCC financial mechanism and a significant proportion of the IPCC ef bf bds finances are used to finance developing country participation.
The US said automaticity of sanctions meant that the consequence of a particular case of non-compliance would be predetermined and applied automatically.
INDIA illustrated an equity or convergence emissions paradigm for mitigation.
During discussions, the EU said a robust accounting system is needed in addition to review and said the US approach to review might suggest a system of post hoc rules, with parties individually deciding, inter alia, on the basket of greenhouse gases, LULUCF accounting and use of offsets.
NEW ZEALAND urged a strategic approach.
 The G-77/CHINA stressed that Annex I parties should take economy-wide quantified emission reduction commitments that are ambitious, comparable and compatible with a long-term goal.
The Democratic Republic of the Congo, for the AFRICAN GROUP, noted, with concern, the lack of political signals that developed countries are prepared to undertake ambitious, legally-binding emission reduction commitments.
INDIA, supported by SAUDI ARABIA, called for an integrated summary of the work done on ambition under the ADP, AWG-LCA and AWG-KP.
VENEZUELA, with BRAZIL and BOLIVIA, underscored that the CDM cannot function outside of the context of QELROs, and therefore without a second commitment period.
BURKINA FASO and MOROCCO said all countries should be eligible for participation.
TUVALU, the RUSSIAN FEDERATION and GEORGIA requested more advance notice for meetings and the topics to be discussed.
Following a request by SAUDI ARABIA and the G-77/CHINA that the cross-cutting issue of funding be addressed in a separate group, President Pronk said the group on "Box A" would be allocated more time to address this issue.
The EU disagreed, preferring a balanced view.
The EU noted that some elements regarding the characteristics of an MCP need further consideration before it can be finalized.
The REPUBLIC OF KOREA said that without a clear idea of the nature of the CDM and the number of expected projects, it would be impossible to elaborate on the EB.
On reporting on technology transfer and financial assistance, CANADA, with the US, said exhaustive reporting on all areas related to climate change, including reporting on private and public technology transfer, is impractical and beyond the means of most Parties’ budgets.
On Monday, 8 June, the G-77/CHINA, supported by SAUDI ARABIA, CHINA, INDIA, VENEZUELA and ETHIOPIA, called on the SBI to identify the needs of developing countries, utilizing the SBSTA and the IPCC.
Supporting this, the US cautioned against creating a hierarchy regarding the importance of products, while Saudi Arabia stressed that the SPMs and the SYR are the main products.
BOLIVIA reminded of Paris Agreement decisions on developing guidance to the GCF to provide finance for alternative policy approaches, and lamented that the GCF postponed considering this issue to its next board meeting.
While the rationale for this position was not openly spelled out, many attributed this initial reluctance to discuss the new finance goal to the US walking away from the Agreement as well as political and economic challenges in many industrialized countries.
The EU said communications should be considered on a country-level basis and more frequent workshops would be beneficial.
Several parties observed the need to recognize the special circumstances of small island developing states (SIDS) and LDCs, with SAUDI ARABIA noting that this is already in the Convention.
The US, with ARGENTINA, CHILE, COLOMBIA, and VENEZUELA, argued for transparent rules of procedure.
TUVALU favored exploring the \t\testablishment of the ad hoc working group and suggested the \t\tidentification of a focal point for indigenous peoples within the \t\tSecretariat.
COLOMBIA cautioned against addressing issues for the first time in Copenhagen and suggested discussion on whether issues should be handled by amendment or decision were best left to the legal group.
NAMIBIA said an adaptive response requires, inter alia, an interdisciplinary and multi-sectoral approach.
IRAN voiced its concern over the current energy policies of industrialized countries that generate market imperfections.
AILAC proposed high-level engagement on a summary of the TEMs and UN Climate Summit follow-up, and called for providing space for new announcements on enhanced mitigation efforts, increased multilateral cooperation and means of implementation to support these.
BRAZIL, supported by the US, and opposed by SOUTH AFRICA, CHINA and SAUDI ARABIA, called for a placeholder for issues that have been mandated to CMA 1 but are not currently under the APA work programme.
Noting that CDM focuses on sustainable development, SRI LANKA said its objective is different from that of the other mechanisms.
The Philippines, for the G-77/CHINA, identified further areas, including additionality of finance and clarifying developing countries’ needs.
The REPUBLIC OF KOREA presented on his country’s low-carbon green growth strategy of reducing emissions by 30% compared to business as usual.
SAUDI ARABIA called for a paragraph in the section on considerations on any further work to reflect negative consequences on developing countries.
The Gambia, for the LDCs, supported: establishing contact groups to progress deliberations; deepening understanding on the ADP roadmap to be adopted in Doha; and progressive discussions on a 2013 work plan on ambition.
The G-77/CHINA proposed adding language on the need to better understand the implementation of policies and measures by developed countries in order to strive to minimize adverse impacts.

PERU supported the third alternative with elements from the second one.
BOLIVIA noted the necessity of removing barriers to technology transfer.
The EU proposals contain concrete and useful measures.
The US called for less emphasis on details of domestic actions or national circumstances and for more time for data collection on emissions trading and CDM projects.
The US said annex-based differentiation is not a path to the new agreement and, with Japan, opposed “bifurcated language.”
The EU, supported by JAPAN, suggested it should be the role of SBSTA, while SAMOA, the G-77/CHINA, said it should be a function of the supervisory committee.
On   (Article 6), the REPUBLIC OF KOREA called for inscribing the GCF and the GEF as financial entities of the agreement.
The EU and Switzerland, among others, stressed the need for clarity on the way forward to COP 24.
AOSIS, the US and AILAC made suggestions regarding their planning and follow up.
COSTA RICA underscored that his country’s proposal reflects the full spectrum of parties’ views and includes a global approach under which all countries mitigate their greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and adequate support will be provided for adaptation.
 SPAIN, on behalf of the EU, said that the SBSTA should provide scientific and technical advice and develop frameworks and methodologies to satisfy the Convention.
They opposed the US suggestion for automatic sanctions.
The EU and Norway supported inclusion of hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) and perfluorocarbons (PFCs), and the Russian Federation cautioned against inclusion of insignificant gases.
JAPAN and the EU identified difficulties in assessing unintended consequences and called for information from those affected.
CHINA, supported by BRAZIL, requested that the importance of context be included in the Facilitator’s report.
She proposed both top-down approaches including economic modeling used by OECD and IEA and bottom-up approaches including examinations of sectors and cost effective technologies.
The PHILIPPINES reiterated that developing country ambition is linked to support from developed countries, and that developed country mitigation ambition relates to discussions in the AWGs.
BOLIVIA emphasized that the work should also include other issues.
The EU said the guidelines should include the elements for review under the FCCC and the Protocol, but would single out those parts of the guidelines not applicable to Annex I Parties that are not Parties to the Protocol.

KUWAIT said there are no satisfactory answers to uncertainties and contradictory data.
 JAPAN emphasized the importance of the issue of technology transfer.

CHINA urged Annex II countries to provide adequate financial support to CGE.
On Friday, 4 December, the EU, supported by Colombia for AILAC, Maldives for the Alliance of Small Islands States (AOSIS), and the US called for clarifying the date for the submission of contributions.
BOLIVIA called for a new mechanism for participation and highlighted the need for a global referendum on climate change.
AUSTRALIA suggested using the scope to bring out areas that are not covered in the AWG-LCA’s negotiating text.
He also pointed out that the COP President, in her absence, can designate a COP Vice-President to preside at a meeting and that in doing so, the COP Vice-President would not represent the interests of GRULAC.
JAPAN called for a ten-year cycle as a signal to investors, and expressed willingness to consider a mid-term review focused on enhancing and understanding contributions.
The EU highlighted the urgency of finalizing draft decision text in Durban so as to operationalize the Adaptation Committee.
On Inventory Management, CANADA noted the lack of reference to confidential information, and JAPAN said the extent of, and access to, confidential information is resolved under Article 8.
Japan stressed the need for explicit discussion on uncertainties, and Co-Chair Field highlighted the link between the treatment of uncertainty and decision-making under uncertainty, with the UK also stressing the communication of uncertainty.

Switzerland and the US expressed their preference for suspending rather than closing the APA session.
 On the section e2 80 99s title, Saudi Arabia requested referring to adaptation and mitigation e2 80 9coptions e2 80 9d instead of e2 80 9cmeasures, e2 80 9d while the UK preferred the more general title e2 80 9cAdaptation and Mitigation, e2 80 9d which was approved.
NICARAGUA and BOLIVIA called for Mother Earth to be reinserted in the text.
SWITZERLAND raised the issue of expert post reviews and evaluation of GHG inventories, and proposed a set of decisions for COP-4, which included calls for consideration of aerosols from combustion of fossil fuels, biomass burning and other greenhouse gas precursors as highlighted by the SAR; and the ratification of, and negotiation for a protocol to the Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution.
The US suggested considering the technical paper first.
Mexico, for the Environmental Integrity Group (EIG), highlighted the NWP, REDD+, and reporting on climate finance, adding that he looked forward to the completion of the 2013-2015 review.
Chile, for AILAC, suggested sub-issues under the use of market mechanisms could be e2 80 9cshuffled e2 80 9d at a later stage.
Sudan, for the African Group, noted progress on purpose (Article 2) in informal consultations, but lamented, with Australia, for the Umbrella Group, that in other areas parties held to positions and did not engage in the negotiations.
CROATIA requested the establishment of a contact group for consideration of this issue.
Swaziland, for the AFRICAN GROUP, said the Doha meeting must result in agreement on: a comparability and compliance framework for developed countries’ mitigation efforts; and clear mid-term targets for finance.
INDONESIA stressed the need for a common accounting system for bilateral, national and sub-national mitigation efforts.
NAMIBIA stressed the importance of tertiary level training for scientists and researchers and proposed that the Secretariat prepare a registry of available training resources.
  Sudan, for the G-77/CHINA, encouraged parties to observe the principles of good faith, transparency, inclusivity and openness, as well as an absolute commitment to the process.
 COSTA RICA, on behalf of the G-77/China, said the AGBM is on a separate track.
Bangladesh, for LDCs, spoke about \t\tmicro-insurance and tools and methodologies to assist LDCs.
Delegates then agreed to a proposal from CHINA reproducing a paragraph from the CDM text on the working language of the committee, the dissemination of its decisions, as well as the languages in which such decisions would be made available.
On "revegetation," the EU, NORWAY and PERU noted the need for a corresponding definition of "de-vegetation."
Regarding text requesting the SBSTA to consider the results obtained from the actions taken and to report them to COP-7, with a view to taking a decision in the lead-up to the COP/MOP, the US urged that the entire decision be bracketed.
SAUDI ARABIA, BOLIVIA and VENEZUELA opposed any change to the consensus rule.
NIGERIA, speaking for the G-77/CHINA, expressed concern that developed countries were not engaging in meaningful FCCC implementation.
The G-77/CHINA expressed concern that their views were not represented in the text.
MALAYSIA said delegates should not prejudge transparency, comparability and consistency until the SBSTA can evaluate the communications.
The US called for defining countries that would submit biennial reports.
The G-77/CHINA proposed a mechanism under the Convention that includes technology panels.
In order to ensure climate objectives, CHILE said CBDR should not be interpreted in a way that blocks ambition or evades responsibility, and that development and climate protection should be seen as complementary, and not clashing, goals.
Mexico, for the EIG, highlighted the importance of including non-party stakeholders in the Dialogue and looked forward to creating inclusive partnerships.
Costa Rica, for the G-77/CHINA, said efforts to address climate change should not be compromised by the current financial crisis.
GUYANA called for Annex I countries to provide data on the contribution of LULUCF to their targets.
Recalling that most items related to MOI and the Paris Agreement are allocated to SBSTA and SBI, CHINA called for also capturing outcomes of these discussions in informal notes, to ensure a balanced approach.
MOROCCO supported holding the global average temperature below 2 c2 b0C above pre-industrial levels, while scaling up efforts to limit temperature increase to below 1.5 c2 b0C.
The EU suggested designing ARD definitions specifically for the purpose of implementing Article 3.3, and the UK raised the possibility of customizing the IPCC scenarios.
The CZECH REPUBLIC said that emissions in his country have decreased more than 20% since 1990 due to extreme economic changes, but such a “shock approach” is not available for all countries.
On institutional arrangements, Swaziland, for the AFRICAN GROUP, SAUDI ARABIA, SOUTH AFRICA, ALGERIA and ARGENTINA preferred anchoring institutional arrangements in the TEC and CTCN.
The Gambia, for the AFRICAN GROUP, stressed that the language on a shared vision needs to be substantive and operative, and cover all four building blocks of the BAP.
Stressing that this is for the SBI to decide, NORWAY, with AUSTRALIA, CANADA and the EU, supported a proposal by NEW ZEALAND to invite the SBI to give appropriate consideration to the issue in considering funding options.
VENEZUELA said the group should not contradict other proposals under Convention Article 17 and consider progress under the AWG-LCA.
JAPAN, SINGAPORE and the EU said the IMO and ICAO are the suitable places to address these issues.
BRAZIL, supported by AUSTRALIA, the US and SWITZERLAND, suggested noting health co-benefits of mitigation policies.
The RUSSIAN FEDERATION cautioned against an overly narrow approach that disregards current realities.
AOSIS underscored the need for further discussion on, inter alia, extending share of proceeds, compliance, new gases and AAU surplus carry over.
Japan, Canada and the US stressed enabling private investment and low-carbon growth, with the EU and the US clarifying that private finance will not replace public finance.
 INDIA underscored the need to identify sources within and outside the UNFCCC and called for reviewing the TOR given to the “financial bodies.” MAURITANIA said the allocation of financial resources should be based on criteria of justice and fairness.
Opposed by CANADA, he said the decisions on the three mechanisms should have three different chapeaus.
The US supported five-year cycles, expressing preference for synchronizing parties e2 80 99 national cycles, so as to garner public attention to drive ambition.
Parties then discussed paragraph 132 of the consolidated text on strengthening the Technology Mechanism/institutional arrangements, with CANADA saying it cannot be further streamlined.
The US also proposed that the CGE use national communications to assess opportunities for mitigation and adaptation in developing countries.
Noting readiness to enter into negotiations, the Philippines, for the G-77/China, called for addressing “crux” issues quickly.
The PHILIPPINES noted that the workshop report reflected recommendations by the co-chairs on the basis of their understanding of what had been discussed.
The G-77/CHINA proposed bracketing reference to sub-paragraphs 1 and b. VENEZUELA, opposed by the US and CANADA, included reference to Protocol Article 2.3 (adverse effects of P&amp;Ms).
The EU suggested adding consideration of the implications of this work, "if any," on the work under Articles 5, 7 and 8 at a later stage.
  Sudan, for the G-77/CHINA, expressed concern at the “insistence” of Annex I parties on a single outcome in Copenhagen and stressed that this undermines the mandate under the Bali Roadmap to finalize negotiations on: further commitments of Annex I parties for the second and subsequent commitment periods under the Protocol; and an agreed outcome under the Convention, aimed at sustained and full implementation of its provisions.
On a paragraph inviting relevant international and intergovernmental organizations to report on their activities to SB-17, delegates compromised by accepting the EU 92s preference for reference to the IPCC, while at the same time accommodating the G-77/ CHINA 92s desire to refer to P&amp;Ms "in Annex I Parties" in another part of the text.
The US, the MARSHALL ISLANDS, the EU, CANADA, NORWAY, JAPAN and AOSIS voiced concern that the text was not balanced and asked that their objection be noted on the record.
The US advocated a clear structure for commitments and for objectively measurable targets.
IRAN stressed that the workshops should also address adaptation to the impact of response measures.
GRENADA stressed the need for an immediate response to the identified needs.
CUBA, for Algeria, Argentina, Brazil, China, Ecuador, Egypt, Malaysia, Nicaragua, the Philippines, Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Thailand, Pakistan, Uruguay, Sierra Leone, Paraguay, India and Bolivia, supported by CHINA, outlined elements that should guide International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) and IMO, including: Article 2.2 of the Kyoto Protocol (Annex I parties emission reductions from international transport); and respect the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities (CDBR); and recognition of the legal distinction between developed and developing countries’ obligations.
Maldives, for AOSIS, called for: initiating work on a new quantified finance goal; reaching a decision on the Adaptation Fund; defining loss and damage; and completing the design of the 2018 facilitative dialogue by COP 23.
The GAMBIA identified shortcomings in the NAPA guidelines, while highlighting achievements such as integration of adaptation into national planning and increased awareness in ministries.
On reference to the CBDR principle in the text on shared vision, the US stated they would not accept the text to the extent it is not read as consistent with the UNFCCC and the Cancun Agreements.
Mali, for the AFRICAN GROUP, noted that national capabilities and differentiation in developing procedures and modalities should also be reflected.
SWITZERLAND said the Secretariat 92s suggestions deserved closer scrutiny.
On the preamble, the US, JAPAN and CANADA, opposed by the EU, SAUDI ARABIA and SAMOA, again urged deleting reference to specific UNFCCC and Protocol provisions.
Sudan, for the G-77/CHINA, expressed concern over lack of progress on capacity building under the Convention and the Protocol, and drew attention to financial and technical constraints related to non-Annex I communications.
TANZANIA called for compliance mechanisms for finance.
CANADA \t\tsaid future action should allow parties to choose the best combination \t\tof results-oriented actions that lead to real reductions in greenhouse \t\tgas emissions.
In response, the US, supported by CANADA and AUSTRALIA, suggested the contact group address four questions: what type of decision should be made, when, by whom, and how it should move forward.
GRENADA and SAUDI ARABIA asked how the second report from the consultants tasked with conducting the study had been dealt with, with GRENADA noting that the CDM EB did not endorse this second report.
BOLIVIA underscored the importance of progress on this issue and highlighted a comprehensive approach, including forest ecosystems.
UKRAINE highlighted that more work is needed before a decision can be finalized.
ARGENTINA expressed concern over the adoption of a compliance regime and a possible amendment of the Protocol before its entry into force.
They also agreed to elect Margaret Mukahanana-Sangarwe (Zimbabwe) as the AWG-LCA Chair, Daniel Reifsnyder (US) as the AWG-LCA Vice-Chair and Teodora Obradovik-Grncarovska (Macedonia) as Rapporteur.
The PHILIPPINES asked for a group on finance and several countries highlighted capacity building.
On inputs, BOLIVIA stressed the content must be consistent with a fair and equitable sharing of the global carbon budget, which she suggested requires considering a country’s historical responsibility, ecological footprint and development and technological capacity.
The PHILIPPINES expressed concern with agreeing on the form of the Reference Manual before agreeing on the substance of its content.
GUYANA explained that from a “pragmatic and realistic standpoint” market sources are needed to complement public funding.
Arguing that linkages to legal matters were premature, SOUTH AFRICA suggested inviting party submissions on technical aspects of possible improvements to the flexibility mechanisms.
EGYPT called for the summary report to reflect hope towards jointly addressing climate change.
CANADA said an MCP could involve a representative group of Parties with expert input, if needed.
Responding to a US suggestion to develop separate scales and budgets for the Protocol and UNFCCC, Chair Ashe proposed developing such an approach to be funded by Parties to the Protocol starting in January 2004.
 \t\tSeveral delegates expressed satisfaction at the Board 92s work and many, \t\tincluding CHINA, the EU, IRAN, JAPAN, and the G-77/CHINA, suggested \t\tfurther improving the Board 92s management and CDM procedures.
The EU expressed concern that the mechanism to raise ambition over time had been significantly weakened.
SOUTH AFRICA supported an equity reference framework.
On the Nairobi work programme, the EU supported making it more relevant for practitioners and a COP decision to enhance its work.
On questions relating to linkages and context, NEW ZEALAND, the US, JAPAN and the EU advocated separating the context of the global stocktake from a question on increasing ambition.
ARGENTINA emphasized that establishing a forum is fundamental to address compliance by Annex I parties with their obligations under Protocol Articles 2.3 (adverse impacts of polices and measures) and 3.14 (adverse effects).
NEW ZEALAND said a registry of voluntary actions and MRV through national communications were insufficient.
The US reiterated its position on the need to include sinks during the first commitment period and said its proposal provided flexibility and was based on a long-term perspective.
El Salvador, for the CENTRAL AMERICAN INTEGRATION SYSTEM (SICA), urged recognition of the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities and respective capabilities (CBDR-RC).
INDIA, with CHINA and IRAN, recommended the use of Article 4.2 (g) (provision for non-Annex I Parties to bind themselves to commitments in 4.2 (a) and (b)).
JAPAN preferred discussing their proposals on policies and measures, MRV and review in the overarching contact group on mitigation.
The RUSSIAN FEDERATION underscored the need for \t\tregional adaptation, regional projections and observation systems.
e2 80 9d AOSIS proposed disseminating the summary through a e2 80 9cweb-based manual on policy options.
GHANA, on behalf of the African Group, expressed disappointment at the inability to reach agreement.
Opposed by AOSIS, BOTSWANA and IRAN, the EU, with SWITZERLAND, proposed that AIJ should be credited retroactively.
The US, supported by CANADA and SWITZERLAND and opposed by CHINA, said the revision of guidelines was fundamental to improving second national communications.
Australia, for the Umbrella Group, said Copenhagen should produce a robust and resilient foundation to steer collective efforts, and welcomed discussions on a shared vision.
On international cooperation and R&amp;D, JAPAN and others underscored the need for cooperation on technology between governments, academics and industry.
He noted that long-term financing, capacity building and technology transfer are matters of survival for the LDCs.
On emissions trading, NEW ZEALAND noted interest in extending emissions trading to developing countries and proposed text reflecting this.
He highlighted the OECD Policy Guidance on Integrating Climate Change Adaptation into Development Cooperation, which provides a template for adaptation integration and ongoing work to develop manuals to implement the Guidance.
CANADA and JAPAN raised concerns about introducing new criteria concerning compliance action plans.
Stressing “this is a global crisis,” MARSHALL ISLANDS reminded that, while a “favorite phrase here is nationally determined,” parties are in Paris “to fight for what is globally necessary.”
NORWAY, SAUDI ARABIA, KUWAIT, UAE and IRAN supported \t\tCCS as a viable option under the CDM.
In discussions of means to deal with uncertainties, Canada, India, Thailand and others supported referring to a “principle of conservativeness.” Parties disagreed as to whether this was a policy or technical issue, with the US insisting that it be excluded because it has not been defined.
On further rules, the US emphasized the need for a system that can accommodate all, so as to maximize both effort and participation.
The US highlighted the importance of considering longer-term emission pathways and several countries highlighted there are multiple pathways to achieve given stabilization levels.
She underscored direct access as a separate principle, while the EU questioned whether all the principles were required.
China, for the LMDCs, and the EU noted that the paragraph’s placement could suggest that the focus of workstream 2 is only on voluntary activities.
PAPUA NEW GUINEA suggested that the Secretariat explore funding options for different national circumstances.
The EU highlighted its experience with an annual compliance regime under the EU Emissions Trading Scheme.
AOSIS called for considering adaptation and loss and damage as separate issues.
AUSTRALIA said that outcomes from processes such as the G-8, MEF and the Pacific Islands Forum could provide useful input.
AOSIS, supported by BRAZIL, also on behalf of ARGENTINA and URUGUAY, stressed the need for in-depth dialogue on the governance and operational modalities of the Adaptation Fund serving the Paris Agreement.
The G-77/CHINA, supported by the MARSHALL ISLANDS, called for SBSTA work on this item and a possible expert meeting before COP-4.
NORWAY underscored the need for incentives to take action.
LIBERIA asked if consultants \t\thad considered investment for countries with natural assets such as \t\tforests that provide benefits to the global environment.
AUSTRALIA, the EU, NORWAY and SWITZERLAND emphasized the importance of framing Kyoto Protocol commitments in the context of a global legally-binding agreement.
Mexico, for the ENVIRONMENTAL INTEGRITY GROUP (EIG), expressed commitment to working towards early completion of the AWG-KP’s work to avoid a gap between commitment periods, while highlighting links between the two tracks.
JAPAN said the issue of reporting on supplementarity relating to mechanisms should be forwarded to ministers for consideration.
JAPAN noted a prospective proposal on incentives.
 POLAND proposed replacing the text in paragraph XII on modeling with text from the FCCC: "Modeling of different scenarios of the stabilization of greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere."
Saudi Arabia and Algeria stressed all developing countries must adapt to spillover effects and, opposed by the African Group, AOSIS, the US and the EU, supported inclusion of response measures under adaptation.
 Malaysia shared the disappointment of AOSIS and said the language is as ambiguous as the original commitments adopted in 1992.
Australia, for the UMBRELLA GROUP, said assistance should be provided through existing mechanisms, called for a legally-binding regime applicable to all parties, and stressed the need to update the existing regime in line with 21st century realities.
MEXICO, AOSIS and TUVALU suggested considering regional TEMs.
AUSTRALIA proposed text on national schedules and intended mitigation contributions, including that each party individually update their respective national schedules in accordance with modalities to be agreed by the governing body.
AOSIS suggested a committee on adaptation under the Convention and enhancing regional mechanisms.
Micronesia, for AOSIS, highlighted the latest science and urged stabilization at below 350 ppm, peaking emissions by 2015 and emission reductions of more than 95% by 2050.
On paragraphs 13-16 (INDCs communication), ARGENTINA, Chile, for AILAC, CHINA, INDIA, Algeria, for the ARAB GROUP, SOUTH AFRICA, TANZANIA and many others emphasized the relevance of the principles and provisions of the Convention.
INDIA stressed the need to discuss MRV separately for Annex I and non-Annex I countries.
Ghana, for the AFRICAN GROUP, with AUSTRALIA, Vanuatu, for AOSIS, and the US, underlined the importance of feedback and guidance from the LEG.
 Regarding commitments of non-Annex I Parties, the US slide presentation prompted numerous complaints from developing countries by suggesting that greenhouse forcing from developing countries will exceed that of developed countries emissions in the next century.
CHINA and BRAZIL sought accelerated funding of second national communications.
Tanzania, for the G-77/China, called for separate discussions on capacity building for developing countries and countries with economies in transition.
The EU also noted the need to include their proposal that developed countries must reduce emissions in aggregate by 30% from 1990 levels by 2020, and by 80-95% by 2050.
JAPAN cautioned that a reference to Protocol Articles 2.3 and 3.14 suggested implementation of the Protocol.
TUVALU said it would be premature to have conclusions on text that had yet to be discussed by the group.
The EU said the focus should be placed on the network rather than the creation of a centralized institution.
 The RUSSIAN FEDERATION said groups of Parties can be differentiated according to emissions, indicators of development or other factors.
The US said the issue should be deferred until SBSTA clarifies the tasks for experts that do not duplicate the work of other fora.
BRAZIL, \t\topposed by SWITZERLAND, proposed new text, pending approval by the \t\tG-77/China, on confirmation of involvement by low-income communities \t\tprior to validation.
Bolivia, for the G-77/CHINA, called for, inter alia: enhanced provision of MOI by developed countries; coordination between the technology and financial mechanisms; and equal treatment of mitigation, adaptation, MOI, and transparency of action and support in the 2015 agreement.
The EU, Canada and Norway said the draft decision provided a good basis for negotiations.
 The PHILIPPINES, on behalf of the G-77 and China, said that there were diverse capacities within developing countries regarding technology and finances.
INDIA said financing is about incremental costs for mitigation and adaptation, which provide no returns on investment, and therefore will not be supplied by the private sector.
COLOMBIA emphasized that the aim of its proposal is not to transfer Annex I commitments.
The EU restated its target \t\t(15-50% reductions by 2050), highlighted its Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) \t\tand said commitments must be clearly defined and fair.
Expressing confidence in the ability of parties to move forward, the US highlighted recent developments in his country, including the introduction of a new climate bill in the Senate and the intention of the Environmental Protection Agency to move towards regulation of greenhouse gas emissions.
MEXICO proposed including language indicating that market-based approaches shall be “country-driven.” KENYA asked for the inclusion of principles on upfront funding and equity.
Regarding historical cumulative emissions, she said that history does not begin until 1984 according to the US presentation.
The EU, opposed by CANADA, JAPAN and AUSTRALIA, emphasized the establishment of a consultative process to ensure continuity of information exchange.
AUSTRALIA and the US proposed language on convening a contact group during SBSTA-5 to further this work.
ANTIGUA AND BARBUDA expressed support for the second alternative, and noted the AOSIS position highlighting, inter alia, best available science, urgency and impacts on LDCs and SIDS as the benchmark.
The US said ICA should go hand-in-hand with biennial reports and should provide input for the Review.
Saudi Arabia, for the Arab Group, said the balance struck in the Paris outcome between mitigation and adaptation needs to be maintained, and that intellectual property rights should not be a barrier for technology transfer.
The EU, AILAC, the US and others supported a common framework, with flexibility regarding the timing and detail in the reporting, and with support to developing countries.
The G-77/CHINA presented a revised text on objectives and guiding principles.
Australia, for the Umbrella Group, called for COP 22 to be an “implementation and action COP.”
CHILE, the EU and US objected to referring to the importance of adhering to adopted principles of free and unrestricted exchange of information, noting that such principles do not exist.
On progress made in climate change negotiations, PALAU said it was disappointed at the lack of progress being made at COP-5.
The US supported developing a clearer sense of potential demand, while avoiding lock-in, and the collection of a range of information on the supply-side on possible host institutions.
ECUADOR called for a focus on linkages between gaps in mitigation, finance, technology and adaptation.
However, the EU and US questioned the added value of such a \t\tgroup, and the EU suggested further consideration at SBSTA 28.
IRAN distinguished CDM from other mechanisms as a multilateral rather than bilateral mechanism, with international supervision.
Opposed by Saudi Arabia and supported by Mexico and the EU, Brazil recommended renewing SBSTA 92s mandate on this issue.
Regarding the decision that future work should enable an assessment of demonstrable progress of Annex I Parties in achieving their Protocol commitments, the G-77/CHINA, SAUDI ARABIA and the EU underlined the importance of this issue.
Mali, for the AFRICAN GROUP, stressed that the APA must be comprehensive, and reflect the “delicate” balance achieved in the Paris Agreement.
SAUDI ARABIA, supported by IRAN, noted Article 4.8, stating that funding action be considered in regard to the specific needs of developing countries.
AUSTRALIA \t\tcalled for analysis of available tools and methods, and for targeted \t\tworkshops.
On the strategic plan, Germany, the UK, the US, Tanzania and others underlined that the two SRs, one on oceans and cryosphere, and the other on climate change, desertification, land degradation, sustainable land management, food security, and GHG fluxes in terrestrial ecosystems should not be approved in parallel at the same meeting.
SAUDI ARABIA noted that the views of all delegations, including his own, were not acknowledged in the Chair’s summary.
The EU highlighted, inter alia: enhanced reporting of capacity building best practices through national communications, in order to enable monitoring and evaluation of the implementation of the capacity-building framework; and the indicative list of items to consider for further implementation of decision 2/CP.7 (capacity building in developing countries).
BOTSWANA, for the G-77/CHINA, proposed an amendment to the conclusions to reaffirm the need for a work programme, taking into account national circumstances and the availability of resources.
Albert Binger, CCCCC, noted that although SIDS have identified climate change as the number one issue, politicians have yet to act on this.
The AFRICAN GROUP, supported by Bangladesh, for the LDCs, called for a focus on actions rather than processes.
CANADA said the reports were the factual basis that determined the need for further steps.
Guatemala, for the countries comprising the Central American Integration System (SICA), with, the Gambia, for the LDCs, said it is essential to reach agreement on a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol.
He outlined a proposal on behalf of the US, JAPAN and CANADA to account for the contribution of forests in Annex I Parties.
The EU stated that the process should be governed by the COP.
The EIG stressed the limitation of carry-over of surplus AAUs.
Honduras, for SICA, stressed the need to complete the AWG-LCA’s mandate under the Bali Action Plan and evaluate which of its elements have not been completed by COP 18.

Regarding a COP decision on a mandate to conclude an LBI with a clear roadmap, the EU proposed six elements that should be included in such a mandate, including a clear end date for negotiations.
SBI also addressed various administrative and financial matters, \t\teventually agreeing on the programme budget for 2006-2007 at a level \t\tthat was US$1.75 million less than had been proposed.
COLOMBIA highlighted the benefits of a mid-term review of commitments.
The US said expanding access to only one type of NGO would be inappropriate and suggested strengthening existing channels.
The G-77/CHINA called for the will to implement "long overdue" actions on FCCC Article 4.8 and 4.9 at COP-6 and, supported by SAUDI ARABIA, UNITED ARAB EMIRATES, and JAMAICA, called for two separate decisions.
Cautioning that CMA 1 may be a cause for celebration but not complacency, Maldives for AOSIS, called on building on the momentum of when “the international community puts its collective well-being over its individual interest.”
The EU said the challenge to ensure sufficient financing for climate change is significant but affordable.
BRAZIL requested clarification on the meaning of divergence and convergence.
SAUDI ARABIA sought clarification on the high-level segment at COP-4.
AOSIS said flexibility should be expressed in the individual provisions of the modalities, procedures, and guidance.
He explained that the shared vision should be underpinned by concrete action in the operative part with equal importance given to adaptation and mitigation, taking into account national circumstances, especially of the LDCs and SIDS.
CHINA stressed the importance of both quality and speed of the process under the Durban Platform and said that a lot of work remains under AWG-LCA.

MAURITIUS and others highlighted the value of the Synthesis Report in increasing public awareness.
EL SALVADOR suggested closer links with the Adaptation Committee and Adaption Fund.

The US suggested removing reference to the level of adaptation, and maintaining reference to the global stocktake in the framing chapter (Chapter 1).
On consequences applied by the facilitative branch, the RUSSIAN FEDERATION, opposed by the G-77/CHINA, called for the deletion of text requiring that UNFCCC Article 4.3 (financial resources), 4.4 (costs of adaptation), 4.5 (technology transfer) and 4.7 (conditionality in the fulfillment of commitments) be taken into account.
