The Maldives, for the G-77/CHINA, emphasized the need for equal treatment of mitigation and adaptation.
While the agenda was \t\tprovisionally agreed, a dispute resurfaced over the agenda item relating \t\tto small island developing States (SIDS).
 Chair Patrick Sz ef bf bdll (UK) opened the fourth session of the Ad Hoc Group on Article 13 (AG13-4) on Tuesday, 25 February.
A contact group will be convened, co-chaired by SBI Chair John Ashe and Dan Reifsnyder (US).
The US supported improving software, particularly in the synthesis and inventory assessment phase.
BRUNEI DARUSSALAM highlighted the Heart of Borneo forest \t\tconservation initiative, and VIET NAM said the CDM should include \t\tincentives for reducing deforestation.
The EU and US agreed to develop a common text on Article 5.2 as a basis for further negotiation.
NEW ZEALAND said there was no need to spend a lot of time negotiating comparability criteria.
AOSIS presented alternative text for this section, suggesting the deletion of the paragraph.
Drawing an analogy with apartheid, the G-77/CHINA lamented that developing countries had to justify themselves, questioning the approach of the ADP Co-Chairs.
MEXICO elaborated on her proposal for a green fund, noting that institutional arrangements should be under the COP.
JAPAN also submitted a proposal outlining options setting limits on the possibility of a Party-to-Party trigger.
CHINA suggested capacity building as an element of the guidelines and underlined the diversity of domestic systems.
The EU stressed that the SCCF should have a catalytic function.
JAPAN proposed an open-ended expert meeting format and called for avoiding duplicating the work of the IPCC.
The EU expressed concern that using multiple base years would require a Protocol amendment, as several provisions, including Protocol Articles 3.5 and 3.7, refer to “1990” rather than to “base year.” AUSTRALIA noted that multiple base years present challenges in the calculation of AAUs.
The US, with CANADA, also expressed frustration at the rate of progress, and indicated support for continuing work towards resolving the G-77/China 92s concern about the situation.
POLAND said reduced emission levels in countries with economies in transition helped to offset slight increases by OECD country Parties.
Noting the requirement for increasingly global participation, he said the EU was ready for discussions with all Parties at COP- 4 and beyond, under FCCC Article 7.2, on regular review of the Convention implementation.
CHILE emphasized the need to understand the mitigation potential of pledges ex ante (to the 2015 agreement)to avoid double-counting and assess whether mitigation pledges are fair and based on equity.
The EU hoped for upcoming workshops, input from the secretariat and submissions from Parties addressing technology transfer issues.
AOSIS highlighted the importance of adequacy and predictability of climate finance and support.
Nepal, for the LDCs, said Bonn had provided a good opportunity to enhance understanding on each other e2 80 99s positions.
On the treatment of confidential data, the EU, supported by CHINA, said that confidential information should be available to review teams during desk reviews and stressed the development of guidelines for managing electronic information.
The US recalled his country’s decision to withdraw from the Paris Agreement, but stressed intent to continue engagement, including in laying the foundations for guidelines for implementing the Paris Agreement.
Actions to minimize the impacts of response measures: SAUDI ARABIA said Annex I Parties should: eliminate tax distortions and remove subsidies; discourage nuclear energy; support wider use of CO2 sequestration technologies; help with economic diversification; and provide compensation where adverse effects are demonstrated.
Before breaking, President Pronk summarized the main unanswered questions: how to give substance to the request for compensation on Article 3.14; how to organize special facilities for LDCs; how EITs can also benefit from funding mechanisms, technology transfer and capacity building; whether the decision language should be mandatory for all decisions, or only for specific issues; whether to have one or two decisions on adverse effects; and how to resolve questions on the role of the GEF.
SAUDI ARABIA called for action as well as research.
The contact group considered the Co-Chairs 92 proposal for a draft decision on capacity building that was based on a G-77/China proposal and incorporated submissions from the EU and other Annex I Parties.
JAPAN supporting Australia, US and Norway, stated that the Chair\'s draft conclusions were well balanced and acceptable.
SWITZERLAND noted the IPCC report provides a clear signal, but added that mitigation measures are available and many will cost little.
SWITZERLAND, with AOSIS, supported using the EU proposal as the basis for the COP-6 decision.
 The INTERNATIONAL OCEANOGRAPHIC COMMISSION (IOC) OF UNESCO reported on recent IOC activities related to the UNFCCC and highlighted proposed actions, including strengthening the cooperative links between IOC, IPCC and SBSTA, preparation of a sea-level database for distribution among AOSIS States at COP-2, initiation of a coral reefs study from the carbon accumulation viewpoint and provision to the IPCC of the list of IOC experts.
Australia, for the Umbrella Group, welcomed the progress on CCS and agriculture.
CUBA stressed that the shared vision goes beyond a long-term goal.
On  , China, Algeria, Bolivia, Venezuela and AOSIS emphasized the need for ambitious commitments from Annex I parties.
 \t\tCANADA, with the US and NORWAY, proposed including information on \t\tstorage as well as capture when stating the percentages of global fossil \t\tfuel carbon dioxide emissions that could be suitable for capture.
SAUDI ARABIA called for attention to: water; marine protection and blue carbon; economic diversification; land use; urban planning; and food security.
COLOMBIA called for attention to “missing policy options,” such as transport.
The consolidation of paragraphs 30 and 32 referencing regional economic integration organizations and joint implementation of commitments was not agreed upon, as TUVALU opposed this, explaining it would create unnecessary complications.
The agreed version of the guidelines follows the US suggestions.
Nauru, for the Alliance of Small Island States (AOSIS), expressed hope that the ADP would demonstrate a “sober, serious and determined sense of urgency and ambition.” She called for a mitigation work plan that makes strides in closing the recognized mitigation ambition gap.
  Tuvalu, for the LDCs, proposed a legally-binding agreement and a system based on two annexes, including the possibility of making amendments for parties to increase their level of mitigation ambition through COP decisions.
AOSIS suggested ensuring transparency, accuracy, completeness, comparability and consistency.
BANGLADESH requested the COP President to engage with parties constructively.
The US supported market mechanisms that facilitate action and are efficient, environmentally robust, credible and sustainable.
On accreditation, BRAZIL suggested replacing a reference to the accreditation body with the EB.
On relevant Convention processes, URUGUAY said embarking on a NAP process with seven other countries will enhance its identification and assessment of relevant technologies and practices.
SAUDI ARABIA and NIGERIA requested retaining paragraphs relating to loss of income.
Noting uneven progress across facilitated groups, South Africa, for the G-77/CHINA, Angola, for the LDCs, Maldives, for AOSIS, Guatemala, for AILAC, Bolivia, for ALBA, and Sudan, for the AFRICAN GROUP, called for clarity on the intended outcome of this session, and for a clear mandate for the co-facilitators.
SAUDI ARABIA called for immediate action to create structures for dealing with impacts of response measures, with compensation occurring after the extent of impact has been proved.
AOSIS, the LDCs and COLOMBIA supported retaining it also in the context of COP/MOP decisions.
Participants developed an LDC proposal for the COP-6 negotiations, requesting "immediate" and "long-term" adaptation funds for the purpose of preparing and implementing national adaptation programmes of action.
 The COP adopted a decision on the extension of the mandate of the LDC Expert Group (FCCC/SBI/2015/10/Add.1).
SAUDI ARABIA insisted on references to sinks and greenhouse gases other than CO2.
INDIA cautioned against conflating adaptation planning and action with communication.
On the proposed title for the non-inventory part of the guidelines, the EU suggested shortening it to read "UNFCCC reporting guidelines on national reports," as agreed in the contact group.
Argentina, for the G-77/China, acknowledged flexibility shown in enabling progress and expressed hope that this constructive spirit would prevail in Durban.
Underscoring the need for continuity, INDIA emphasized that business and markets respond to mitigation policies and expect predictability; and therefore changes must be weighed against the scale of necessity.
CHINA, with CHILE, emphasized that action from developing countries should be carried out within the framework of sustainable development and requires financial and technological support from developed countries.
The EU noted that INDCs are nationally determined and called for a rules-based approach that is multilaterally determined.
In the contact group, Costa Rica read out a joint submission by Colombia for AILAC, Australia, Canada, the EU, Japan, Mexico, New Zealand, and Switzerland on the need for corresponding adjustments in connection with transfers of mitigation outcomes and emission reductions under Article 6.
CANADA supported a coordinated response among existing efforts in capacity building and proposed three steps: assessment of needs; overview of actions currently undertaken by various actors; and definition of a clear scope for action.
JAPAN proposed mapping out potential areas of convergence and divergence as undertaken in the technology group, and said the UNFCCC should play a catalytic role in strengthening adaptation.
The EU, Tuvalu, Samoa, China and Jamaica urged that the CDM exclude provision for sinks.
NIGERIA said the SAR is a preliminary document that the IPCC will continue to develop.
The G-77/CHINA agreed to the two drafting groups, but asked for flexibility to discuss issues as appropriate in the groups, which parties accepted.
Several speakers, including the G-77/CHINA, the EU and CG-11, supported entry into force of the Protocol in time for the WSSD.
The EU clarified that e2 80 9cevolving responsibilities and capabilities e2 80 9d captures the growth in the levels of prosperity and GHG emissions of developing countries, noting that some are currently more prosperous than some EU member states.
  CHINA stressed the importance of the timing of the agreement, including precise dates for the starting and ending of its implementation, and a timeframe related to commitments.
Egypt, for the Arab Group, said that decisions taken in Doha represent hope for the future of multilateral action on climate change; noted success on ambitious objectives and the opening the second commitment period; and looked forward to full and continuous implementation of the decisions.
 During the morning contact group, chaired by Anke Herold (Germany), UKRAINE preferred one decision with five annexes.
Saudi Arabia, for the ARAB GROUP, called for: balanced attention to adaptation and mitigation, including their linkages; no unilateral actions by developed countries; and provision of support.
The EU welcomed progress on the Nairobi work programme and technology transfer, and indicated research dialogue and CCS in the CDM as areas for further work.
SAUDI ARABIA suggested that consideration on the proposed draft decision not proceed until methodological and legal issues are resolved, and proposed organizing a workshop and an IPCC evaluation.
No movement was reported on the operation of the LDC Fund.
INDIA expressed concern that TEMs are shifting the onus of mitigation away from Annex I parties.
The UK indicated that there is a \t\trequirement beyond pure assessment that needs to be recognized.
Miguel Arias Ca c3 b1ete, Commissioner for Climate Action and Energy, European Commission, highlighted that the EU had, in 2016, reduced GHG emissions by 23% compared with 1990 levels.
The Gambia, for LDCs, called for a meeting before Doha to advance the ADP’s work and avoiding lengthy discussion on the organization of work.
India, for BASIC, highlighted the need to maintain the delicate balance under the two-track approach and emphasized the importance of equitable access to sustainable development.
Tuvalu, for the LDCs, and ARGENTINA stressed possible resolutions for legal issues raised.
SAUDI ARABIA indicated no agreement exists to supersede the Convention or replace its principles, including the balance of obligations.
Opposed by the EU and CANADA, he said that the G-77/China 92s text should serve as the basis for negotiation.
 On scope and key issues, several parties noted the need to address all elements of the transparency framework in a balanced manner, and Kenya, for the AFRICAN GROUP, emphasized transparency of action and support.
The EIG expressed disappointment that so many issues remain open.
The G-77/CHINA and the EU suggested annexing a summary of conclusions and recommendations to full reports.
The Philippines, for the G-77/CHINA, said a shared vision means developed countries taking the lead in reducing emissions and developing countries pursuing a clean development path avoiding past mistakes, with adaptation as an integral element.
The REPUBLIC OF KOREA stressed the importance of private-sector engagement and supported strong public-private partnerships.
The RUSSIAN FEDERATION suggested that an MCP could be a special ad hoc group of experts on legal and economic questions.
South Africa, for the G-77/CHINA, noted that significant progress on LULUCF may facilitate progress on Annex I emission reductions and that issues on the flexibility mechanisms and methodologies, in turn, could be unlocked by movement in Annex I emission reductions.
The UN DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMME underscored their large portfolio of adaptation projects, noting their role as a GEF implementing agency for LDC Fund projects.
AUSTRALIA suggested giving the highest priority to methods for assessing mitigation and emissions projections.
The EU said that the preparations should focus on policy-making, and there should be a ministerial segment aimed at providing guidance to activities under the Convention.
INDIA noted problematic aspects in some proposals such as harmonization of standards, which can impose large costs on developing countries.
CHINA noted that there are challenges related to market mechanisms and conditions for considering them.
NORWAY, supported by several others, suggested establishing a contact group on REDD.
 The EU asked that the full range of issues covered in the SAR be considered in the Third Assessment Report (TAR).
JAPAN called for a more clearly defined in-depth review process.
The US responded that this change should await a written submission from the EU.
The EU responded that the Council decision is not part of the EU proposal for the protocol.
He supported the US on the membership of panels and said national experts could be provided to both TAPs.
The EU suggested that discussions focus on the legal form and the overall level of ambition.
On multiplication and discount factors under the CDM, JAPAN, CHINA, KUWAIT, INDIA, BRAZIL and others preferred no decision.
CANADA, AOSIS and others proposed changes, and discussions continued late into the night.
The EU presented a proposal for a new six-part structure for the guidelines under Article 8: general approach, national inventory submissions, information on assigned amounts, national systems, national registries, and national communications and other commitments.
JAPAN said it preferred repayment to the Parties.
SWITZERLAND underscored the need for strong IPR protection, noting that in many cases low-carbon technologies are not IPR-protected.
The US emphasized that “the times have changed” and that the US anticipates being more active, expressing interest in various issues under the AWG-KP, including the flexibility mechanisms and LULUCF.
 \t\tParties agreed that the Adaptation Fund Board will have 16 members from \t\tparties to the Protocol, with representation as follows: two from each \t\tof the five UN regional groups; one from SIDS; one from LDCs; two others \t\tfrom non-Annex I; and two others from Annex I.
SAUDI ARABIA said he could only accept text that states that an \t\texchange of views was held on UNFCCC activities relevant to other \t\tintergovernmental meetings and that requests the Secretariat to report \t\ton these activities.
AUSTRALIA was also disappointed that a favorable compromise could not be reached and requested guidance on the follow-up process of consultations.
The EU argued that it would be difficult to establish standardized baselines without discount factors, but opposed multiplication factors.
Germany, the Maldives, the UK, Switzerland, Belgium, Sweden, and Saudi Arabia urged the ATG-Finance to continue working with other UN organizations.
GRENADA expressed concern over a number of recommendations, including devolving responsibility for validation to host countries and the option of issuing emission reduction units (ERUs) after 2012 in the transition period before countries take on second commitment period QELROs.
With SWITZERLAND and HUNGARY, she emphasized the need for increased domestic action and called for continuation of AIJ and a smooth transition in the future to the CDM and JI.
JAPAN said parties who provide and receive support should work together to mobilize private finance.
TRINIDAD and TOBAGO supported China and proposed references to the AOSIS statement throughout the report.
SAUDI ARABIA underlined that mitigation actions should not hinder developing countries’ diversification.
With AILAC, he stressed the need for flexibility to allow qualitative NDCs.
COLOMBIA stressed the need to retain the structure of the BAP and not reinvent Convention language, noting that regarding adaptation, the Chair’s text “appears as if two years of negotiations never happened.” On finance, TIMOR-LESTE suggested that this should be in the form of a percentage of developed countries’ Gross Domestic Product.
On pre-session briefings, the UK supported the aims of holding pre-session briefings but, with the US, France and Germany noted the budgetary implications of such meetings.
CANADA raised majority voting and provision for minority decisions.
GUATEMALA identified barriers to \t\ttechnology transfer, including financial, implementation, and \t\tdissemination issues.
The EU stressed, inter alia: the need to adopt a gender action plan and launch the local communities and indigenous peoples platform; transparency discussions under the SBs; and the need to start work on common NDC timeframes, and on enhancing the implementation of training and public awareness, participation and access to information under the Paris Agreement.
Egypt, for the ARAB GROUP, underscored that an agreement under the AWG-LCA will not be possible unless agreement is reached on a second Kyoto Protocol commitment period.
NEW ZEALAND suggested that some of these proposals would likely require amendments to the Kyoto Protocol.
 \t\tFinally, Parties discussed the decision on the LDC Fund.
BANGLADESH supported the speedy application of the Adaptation and LDC Funds, and highlighted the particular vulnerability of low lying and small island states.
The EU suggested including appendices on technical issues such as baselines and monitoring.
BOLIVIA highlighted the reluctance of some parties to join a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol, and questioned why parties want to “kill” a system that works for many.
On sinks in the CDM, the US, CANADA, JAPAN, COSTA RICA, AUSTRALIA, COLOMBIA, HONDURAS and BOLIVIA, opposed by the EU, CHINA and GHANA, argued in favor of including sinks.
The US said cooperative action to promote and enhance technology development and transfer should include existing technology and financial mechanisms.
The EU identified several issues for further consideration, including: contribution criteria based on ability to pay and responsibility for emissions; the need for assessed contributions; defining funding recipients; and determining how funding resources should be delivered.
BANGLADESH highlighted the need for additional funding representing 1.5% of annual GDP of Annex I countries.
Maldives, for AOSIS, emphasized a review of CDM modalities would create greater confidence in the CDM as a mitigation tool.
Noting that some aspects of the climate are changing faster than foreseen in the AR4, such as those leading to the rapid reduction in Arctic sea ice, the UK explained its proposal for an update report on current climate trends and emerging science, to be prepared within the next 18-24 months.
CHINA restated support for the “balanced package” reached at Durban, and emphasized the need to continue work under the AWG-LCA according to the Bali Action Plan.
94 GERMANY highlighted that ocean and geological storage \t\tpotential cannot be directly compared given their different retention \t\ttimes, and JAPAN noted that this difference is addressed elsewhere in \t\tthe SPM.
SWITZERLAND said that in considering the types of projects that are eligible, possible negative spillover effects into other multilateral domains should be taken into consideration.
JAPAN said the issue was complex and the expertise of IMO and ICAO was needed.
This item was taken up in informal consultations, co-facilitated by Andrew Rakestraw (US) and Xiang Gao (China), which met six times.
SAUDI ARABIA suggested that a modified multilateral consultative process serve as a facilitative body in this structure.
The EU and Switzerland said the CDM should commence immediately after COP-6 on a permanent rather than interim basis.
The NETHERLANDS then reported on the outcome of consultations on outstanding issues not reflected in the Co-Chairs 92 new non-paper.
Regarding issuance and cancellation of assigned amounts (AA) related to Protocol Article 3.3 and 3.4, the G-77/CHINA, supported by the EU and US, suggested referring to "additions" and "subtractions" from AA in the guidelines under Article 7.
JAPAN and AUSTRALIA highlighted information exchange on cross-sectoral issues.
AUSTRALIA said the TCN and TEC should have operational autonomy and should regularly report to the SBSTA for finance, review and guidance.
The US pointed to five emerging themes among the many SR proposals: desertification; cryosphere; oceans; food and agriculture; and mitigation and adaptation linkages.
94 BELGIUM proposed, and delegates agreed, to reference the \t\tsection of the Special Report on environmental impacts, risk, and risk \t\tmanagement.
Bangladesh, for the G-77/CHINA, called for the full implementation of NAPAs and the LDC work programme, highlighting the need for support and resources.
 The US proposal contains: emissions budgets (banking and borrowing emissions); annual reports on measurement, reporting and compliance by "Annex A" and "Annex B" countries.
SAUDI ARABIA supported progress in discussions on potential consequences.
MEXICO, for Colombia, Costa Rica and Honduras, elaborated on elements of a national financial arrangement for REDD+, introducing the concept of a REDD+ unit equivalent to one ton of carbon dioxide, which should be issued on the basis of: MRVed actions; established forest reference levels; a safeguards information system; and a national REDD+ registry.
CANADA said sufficient evidence should be provided to support cases.
JAPAN, INDIA, the EU, NEW ZEALAND and JAPAN stated that the Revised Guidelines should be applied to recalculate 1990 base year GHG inventories and all subsequent years.
Philippines, for the G-77/CHINA, called on the Presidency to ensure bilateral consultations both with the G-77/China as a whole, and with the main sub-groups of the G-77/China.
Barbados, for AOSIS, said enhanced action on adaptation should deal first with current, then anticipated, climate change impacts.
GERMANY stated that it would make a considerable contribution towards facilitating the participation of developing countries.
NEW ZEALAND explained his proposed amendments, stressing, inter alia, that the review process, which will be electronic, should not be prejudged.
BRAZIL urged consideration of inputs that would be necessary to assess equity in the global stocktake.
The G-77/CHINA stressed inclusion of financial additionality among methodological issues.
The UMBRELLA GROUP said the text needed elaboration on issues such as forestry, international consultation and analysis (ICA), mitigation and MRV, as well as tighter, more operative language.
ALGERIA \t\tstressed the importance of decoupling economic growth from greenhouse \t\tgas emissions, and looking beyond the first commitment period.
Switzerland, for the EIG, thanked the Chair for his proposed agenda and for including additional items.
